Quote:
F69 will be sunk off
the south coast of
Wellington in
November, creating
an artificial reef
for divers.

There also seems to
be embarrassment
that some Samoans
were suggesting that
fa'a Samoa, Samoan
culture, required
reciprocity for
favours done.

Author: MEAD
Quote:
A child will use the
term fa`a Samoa, in
`in Samoan fashion'.

Author: KEESING
Quote:
Yet the old Samoan
ways, fa`a Samoa,..
still appear to
predominate.

Author: FOX & CUMBERLAND
Quote:
Ceremony is an
integral part of
fa`a Samoa.

Author: WENDT
Quote:
Our way of life, our
precious faa-Samoa,
is changing - some
say for the worse,
some say for the
better.

In apparent
retaliation for
going outside the
faa Samoa,or Samoan
way, Tariu
Tuivaiti's house was
burned.

It was deliberately
established here by
the churches as an
enduring expression
of faa Samoa among
the uncertainty
which confronts ...
any newly arrived
immigrant group. Faa
samoa is a carefully
ordered living
system of rules and
obligations which in
Auckland,
particularly, finds
expression through
the churches; ...

Author: BURCHFIELD
Quote:
faa-Samoa /|fa a
sa:moa/. Also
fa`a-Samoa and
without hyphen.
[Samoan fa`a-Samoa.]
The Samoan way of
life; the language,
customs, etc., of
Samoa.

Satoa is steeped in
fa'a Samoa - the
traditional Samoan
way - and although
the relatively new
Christian religion
is in its
ascendency, the old
gods still cast long
shadows.
On a drive around Savai'i you encounter fa'a Samoa - the Samoan way.

"They usually stayed
home during school
trips and didn't
have holidays.
"That's not part of
the fa'a-Samoa."

New Zealand Samoans
continue to keep
fa'a Samoa - Samoan
ways - even though
today over half the
New Zealand
community is born
here.

Pacific culture has
some wonderful
qualities: alofa
(generosity and
love), tautua
(service and hard
work) and fa'aaloalo
(respect), which can
be intertwined into
the world in which
we live and work.

Author: Fiu
Quote:
Sometimes, boys in
the islands choose
to start being
fafafines because
they are awash with
feminine mannerisms.

Short, pithy and
succinct jokes and
stories that cover
such topics as
Samoan weddings,
Fafafine, his
childhood in both
Samoa and New
Zealand, and his
visits to America,
produced wave after
wave of laughter
rolling through the
audience.

A Frigate Bird Sings follows the struggle of a fa'afafine.. trying to understand and redefine her contribution to her Samoan family, now living in New Zealand. "It's an extremely delicate subject.. particularly among older Polynesians, because in New Zealand the fa'afafine are part of the gay scene; they've become much more visible and upfront about something that in Samoa is an accepted part of their culture. I think some Polynesians feel that the fa'afafine have become an embarrassment to who we are."

They are incensed
that New Zealand
have a
quasi-fa'afafine
playing at second
five...

Boys will be girls in Samoa. That's the theme of Paradise Bent, a documentary about fa'afafine showing this weekend at the Outtakes Film Festival... "Most of the families consider having a fa'afafine in the house an asset, because in the plantations they are men and in the home they are very useful. They do the sewing, the ironing and the cooking and they look after people," says one of the women. Then there is the next generation of fa'afafine who are seen more as drag queens.

Lindah Lepou has
many titles -
Fa'afafine
Extrordinaire, First
Fa'afafine of Soul.

A fa'afafine has
been jailed for 15
months for pushing a
glass into a woman's
chin at a Porirua
club.

Daryla is what is
known as a
fa'afafine or
feminine man... The
tradition of
fa'afafines, which
literally means
"like a woman", is
unique to Samoan and
Tonga culture. A
fa'afafine dresses
in women's clothes,
has a woman's name
and talks and walks
like a woman. They
prefer straight
men... My
understanding of the
fa'afafine tradition
was that in Samoan
culture, if a family
had no daughters,
then the youngest
boys is treated as a
girl and kept at
home to help the
mother. These boys
then grow up to be
fa'afafines.

"The fat fa'afafine
is singing!"

Pinot noir, pinot
blanc, and pinot
gris.. all hang
under the same name
because their
bunches cluster in
neatly packed shapes
similar to pine
cones, 'pinot' to
Latins. The
relationship doesn't
end there; under the
skin all are part of
one of the grape
world's most
genetically unstable
families; the
fafafini of the
grape world.

Miss Tuttu Frutti is
Samoa's queen of
transvestites,
crowned in a pageant
that raucously
celebrates the
fa'afafine, or
transvestite,
lifestyle.

"Is that a taro in
your pocket or are
you a
fa'afafine?"... "I
didn't realise we
were writing a play
about fa'afafines
until we saw the
play. I thought I
wrote about a
drunken father. Next
minute there's all
these homosexuals
running around!

But the President of
the Samoa Fa'afafine
Association, Roger
Stanley, has warned
some [fa'afafine]
are tempting fate by
getting tattoos that
are traditionally
worn only by women.

I like the think of
the pinot family as
the fa'afafines of
the grape world.

Recently fa'afafine
performer Lindah
Lepou was given an
apology for her
removal from the
stage at the
Auckland Pasifica
Festival because it
was feared she would
offend Christians in
the audience.

"He wanted to see
how I did the
fa'afine," says Ete.

Native home-brew,
fa`amafu, flows
exceedingly freely.

Author: MARSACK
Quote:
The making of
fa`amafu may well at
present be
considered a major
Samoan industry.

The natives brew
their own `beer',
called Faamafu, out
of potato peelings,
malt and sugar.
The faamafu that costs two shillings a bottle. Ibid.274 The matai council ruthlessly suppressed all faamafu-brewing. Ibid. 275 The rest of the matai .. took furtive trips to the Apia faamafu dens.

Author: BURCHFIELD
Quote:
faamafu /|fa amafu/.
Also Fa`amafu.
[Samoan fa`amafu.]
Home-brewed liquor.
Also attrib. or as
adj.; also Comb., as
faamafu-brewing.

Author: HEINZ
Quote:
Face: The end of a
tunnel, or edge of a
terrace being
sluiced.

Author: MAY
Quote:
FACE: the end of a
tunnel or a drive;
the wall, cheek or
side of a terrace or
a reef.

When these
difficulties are
considered and when
[they?] were taken
`on a face' (as the
diggers say), the
times made by these
two [climbers] are
very good.

Head Word: face as long as a crowbar
Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
Gus had been moping
about with a face as
long as a crow-bar
for nearly a week,
and the motor-bike
was getting a spell,
...

Author: MASSEY
Quote:
Face check A drying
split on the faces
of boards and
flitches.

Systematic work on
face cover on Romney
sheep has been
carried out at
Massey College over
the last six years
...

Author: BAINES
Quote:
Suppose a piece of
timber - a flitch
nine inches by
twenty-four and
sixteen feet long -
is on the carriage,
and that we intend
cutting nine by
three-quarter
boards. After taking
off a `face' cut,
setting the gauger
rollers, and placing
the flitch in
position, the man at
the head starts the
machinery. `Kreash,'
says the saw. and in
twelve seconds she
is out at the other
end. The man at the
`tail' at that
instant reverses the
motion of the table,
which gigs back.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
So far we had asked
for `facecuts', the
first slices off the
logs with the bark
adhering ...

Author: WILSON
Quote:
There were good
boards among these
facecuts which today
would be classed as
O.B.

Let's take a
face-doesn't-fit
situation.

MPs who had built
fortresses around
their electorates -
Brian Neeson and
Warren Kyd - were
overthrown under the
new 'face doesn't
fit' clause.

Within three days of
the Government
taking power, State
Services honcho
Michael Wintringham
had sent a letter to
his new Minister
with the words "face
doesn't fit" in an
attached note...
"Face doesn't fit"
is a term used to
described clauses
which have been
included in some
public service
contracts, creating
provision for
termination of the
job if there are
irreconcilable
differences between
two parties.

Their careers are
surely jeopardised
because they stood
by her, especially
if we are to have
government that's
churned over each
time a new
government is
elected, each time a
bureaucrat's face
doesn't fit.

It's equally likely,
though, that her
problem is her brute
refusal to accept
political reality.
Sometimes, in public
life, it's no more
complicated that
that your face
doesn't fit.

We have seen the
argument taking
place where
ministers want to be
able to sack chief
executives whose
face doesn't fit.

"Other senior
figures in the state
sector will now
wonder who will be
next for the 'Rankin
treatment' when
Helen Clark and her
colleagues decided
the face doesn't fit
any more," Dr Newman
said.

Legal advice had
made it clear that
the "face doesn't
fit" clause could
not have been used
to oust Ms Rankin as
soon as the new
Government came to
office - and that
its use may never
have been legal, he
said.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote: The three [15] brothers spent the first few weeks clearing, learning the art of chopping, scarfing, driving and working a face. Ibid. k 168 He and a mate took on a contract to cut about 20 acres of light bush and scrub, but as neither of them knew anything about how to work out a face ... they soon got into difficulties.

Sheep seem all right
as all on steep
sunny faces which
have partly cleared.

expensive lawsuits
which have occurred,

boundaries where the
`faces' are from 100

height;

Face, Facing: Side

Face and sidling.-S.
is generally used in

roughness, and is
never used when

aspect. You do not
say `a dark s.,'
though you often
hear `dark side';
but f. can be used
in either sense.

Quote:

Sidling is generally

They chased that old
boar .../ Through

face ... 15. N.Z.
the exposed slope of

face ... NZ open
hillside or slope

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
It was quite a
common practice for
experienced bushmen,
to have a drive'. If
you are chopping up
a `face' and there
is a large tree
behind you further
up the face, you
select that as the
`key'. To save time
... you do not waste
time by chopping
down each tree
individually, but
just `scarf' and
partly chop each
tree. When all is
ready and you have
worked back to the
key, you scarf it
very carefully. ...
If everything goes
according to plan it
will `drive' the one
below, which will in
turn drive the next,
and so on ...

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote:
Esp. work (out) a
face, open a face.
This is seen on all
sunny and shady
slopes (the `sunny'
and `dark faces' of
the shepherds) ...

Author: AYSON
Quote:
So up a pig track he
started to the ferny
face where the dogs
were barking.

Here it must be
pointed out that
what Cockayne
described as sunny
and dark faces are
for the most part,
and especially in
Central Otago,
essentially windward
and leeward faces
respectively.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
It was country with
great open shingle
faces.

Author: DUFF
Quote:
but I face north,
and no rabbit goes
voluntarily to the
cold faces when the
warm ones are open.

Subsequently, cattle
have been used for
grazing, and
subdivision fences
erected to
adequately control
the grazing of dark
and sunny faces.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
during the summer on
these high
altitudes, sheep
throve, and had to
be mustered to the
sunny faces of the
ridges where the
snow first melted,
...

Quote:
The lambs stopped
about halfway down
the spur on a big
tussock face, ...

Quote:
[a shady face] That
year (1908) it was

Author: CHARLES
Quote:
The dogs flushed the
boar on a high ferny
face,/

Though the sunny

Author: FRANCIS
Quote:
The dark faces of
the spurs were now
dangerous and it was
easy to slip and
fall disatrously.
(The so-called dark
faces were slopes
and hillsides that
got no sun during
the winter and

We got past them all
too soon.. getting a
close view of the
big bare clay
"faces" on one side
of the river, which
look like cuttings.

Sheep seem all right
as all on steep
sunny faces which
have been partly
cleared.

Vegetating of loose
faces in high
country .. Under
what conditions will
marram grass grow?
Would it be suitable
in the MacKenzie
country to prevent
shale-rock faces
from slipping...?

On account of the
extreme roughness of
the country and the
lack of suitable
vegetation, the
sheep do not graze
on the high faces of
the main range.

Author: NEWTON
Quote: Face: open hillside.

Open faces and great
shingle basins, it

Author: THOMSON
Quote:

- all of the 1423
acres of their
property, with the

Author: NEWTON

part of the property
and takes in some

.. a bulldozed track
winds its way up a

It's plain logic to
me that the dog
who'll hunt three
sheep up a face or
pen a trio, will be

throat back on the

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
There are several
species of lice
found on sheep, but
those which occur in
New Zealand are: 1)
the red louse or
body louse, or wool
louse (Damalinia
ovis); 2) the face
louse (Linognathus
ovillus); and 30 the
leg louse
(Linognathus
pedalis). The face
louse is rare and
the leg louse more
common in New
Zealand...

"Falling off is nature's way of telling you you've found your limit," is a philosophical definition of a very pertinent problem to readers of Classic New Zealand Mountain Bike Rides..." The inevitable result is a Face plant.

Each time I get off,
I face-plant into
the snow or almost
do the splits. The
only consolation is
when I ride next to
a girl who is
carrying her board.
When I ask why, she
says she fell over
so many times when
getting off, she
gave up.

Source: Journal Kept at Rockwood and the Point

Quote: Soot for use as colouring matter for tattooing the body was sometimes made from the burnt awheto or `vegetable caterpillar' (Cordiceps robertsii), but was not black enough for face-moko.

Acute facial eczema
in sheep: This
disease, which is
mainfested by an
eruption on the face
and ears of lambs,
is solely due to
dietetic errors.
Notes: Eighth Report of the Dept. of Ag

Quote:
The prevalence of
so-called facial
eczema among sheep
last year.

Another and more
practical use of
chloromycetin is in
the treatment of
pink eye, which is
often seen in sheep
that have travelled
in mobs or are being
held in paddocks
during periods of
danger in facial
eczema.

The goal of the
Houghton's breeding
programme is simple:
to breed into their
flocks such a level
of resistance to
facial eczema (FE)
that they can safely
expect the disease
to be a
production-reducing
nuisance only once
every half-century.

We've been here for
30 years, and we'd
never had a problem
with FE until two
years ago. Facial
eczema is caused by
the spores of a
fungus, Pithomyces
chartarum, which
lives in the base of
the pasture. [FE]

The incidence ...
[is] best described
by reviewing the
farming conditions
... in the 1938
facial eczema
outbreak.

Author: LEVY
Quote:
In seasons when
facial eczema is
likely to occur, ...
Weather conditions
... appear to have
an intimate
relationship with
facial eczema
outbreaks.

Acute Facial Eczema
in Sheep/ [heading]
This disease, which
is manifested by an
eruption on the face
and ears of lambs,
is solely due to
dietetic errors.
Some years ago I
investigated what
might have been
termed an outbreak.

Breeding-ewes have
been at times heavy
sufferers from
facial eczema (or
facial dermatitis),
as this trouble of
the skin of the head
is termed.

Facial eczema
appeared in areas of
plentiful growth of
autumn feed ...
Notes: 1916 Dept Ag. Annual report in 1941 NZJST 22/38A

Quote:
It was considered
desirable to
determine ... the
effect of the
so-called `facial
eczema' on
sheep-skins ...

Out breaks of facial
eczema occurred ...
in 1916, 1917, ...
1928, 1929, and
1933.

The name `facial
eczema' was first
applied years ago,
and was later
changed to `facial
dermatitis'. Popular
preference was,
however, so strongly
in favour of `facial
eczema' that this,
though not truly
descriptive, was
finally adopted as
the common name of
this disease.

Author: LEVY
Quote: In seasons when facial eczema is likely to occur, ... Weather conditions ... appear to have an intimate relationship with facial eczema outbreaks. -Ibid For many years facial eczema was linked with a certain autumn pasture condition ... Ibid 334 The year 1938 saw one of the worst incidences of facial eczema ever encountered in New Zealand, or for that matter in the world.

facial eczema NZ
contagious disease
of sheep.
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 175]

Quote:
Although the Facial
Eczema Advisory
Committee.. had
agreed that it could
see no benefit from
spending more money
on facial eczema at
this stage, it was
proposed to maintain
the same commitment
of research staff.

The factory system is now fairly well established.... It is hardly necessary to point out that all butter and cheese intended for export will have to be factory-made, ... Ibid Classification of Dairies. - Dairies are registered as - `Factories' or `creameries,'i.e., milking at least fifty cows; ...

Author: WOOLLASTON
Quote:
[cWW1, Taranaki] ...
the cows were dry
and our fathers not
going to the factory
(called that
[instead of
`creamery'] now that
they made cheese
there instead of

factory butter (or
shop butter) as

Quote: `Cow' is a common word of abuse, not so surprising when so many of the people have to struggle with the beasts. If something is godawful, they'll say it's a `fair cow,' or they'll call a bad day a `cow of a day.' Ibid. 39 Cow - may just mean cow, but may also mean an unpleasant man, woman, or situation. These things may also be called progressively, a fair cow, and a fair adjectival cow.

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: The rarest tern breeding in New Zealand is the fairy tern (Sterna nereis,) reported from Lake Ellesmere in 1944, and breeding also, sparingly, in Northland and a few other places.

For the first time
in this district
Mrs. Moncrieff saw a
little fairy tern on
7th March, and on
4th April a large
Caspian tern put in
an appearance.

According to the
observations of Mr.
A. C. O'Connor, of
Wellington, the
fairy tern,
black-fronted tern,
and black-billed
gulls have been seen
by him in the North
Island during the
past few years.

One of our rarest
birds, the New
Zealand fairy tern,
had a successful
summer breeding with
11 chicks surviving,
including one at
Papakanui Spit on
the Kaipara Harbour
for the first time
in five years.

The New Zealand
fairy tern, once
widespread in the
North island, has
teetered on the
brink of extinction
since the 1970s ..
Fairy terns nest on
shell and sand banks
just above high tide
.. The fairy tern
now breeds at only
four nesting sites,
at Papakanui Spit,
Pakiri, Waipu and
Mangawhai.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
This fungus was used
as food [by Maoris]
in times of
scarcity. It was
washed and cooked
before it burst when
the white
mushroom-like sphere
becomes an expanded
net-work, the meshes
covered with an
offensive brown
slime. ... Its
sudden appearance,
often after thunder,
caused it to be
given two very
expressive names -
tutae-kehua and
tutae-whatitiri
(ghost-dirt and
thunder-dirt
[=shit])

Dredging through
false bottom of
green sandy pug,
very hard pipe clay
bottom, about 8
colours to the dish,
under the false
bottom.

The basement rock is
known to alluvial
miners as `reef
bottom'; and the
clays or other
material interposed
between the wash and
the bed-rock as
`false bottom.'

Author: HEINZ
Quote:
False bottom: A
bottom on which gold
has been deposited
above the true
bottom.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
In some places it
was found that the
original claims had
been worked on a
`false' bottom of
tough, stony clay,
...

Author: MAY
Quote:
False bottoms fooled
even seasoned
diggers,
particularly at
Kaniere. Claims
considered worked
out were frequently
re-worked at a
different level.
This explains the
many small rushes
which occurred on
`old ground'.

Author: NOLAN
Quote:
False bottom: a
floor of compact
clay or cemented
material appearing
to be the base of
the alluvial deposit
but beneath which
lies a further,
perhaps richer,
deposit and the true
bottom.

Author: MAY
Quote:
FALSE BOTTOM: a
movable or floor in
a cradle,
sluice-box,
stamper-box or
puddling machine; a
stratum on which
alluvial gold rests
but which has other
bottoms below it.
The last bottom is
the `true' one.

The terraces on
either side of.. the
Kawarau river, if
examinedi minutely,
will show that the
only deposits of
auriferous wash have
been made at various
periods upon clayey
sand-drifts (called
by the miners "false
bottoms").

Author: MAY

DUFFER: applied to a
rush, a shaft, or a

failure. Synonyms

`stringer' or, in
the case of a false
rush,
`store-keepers'
rush'.

Author: BAXTER
Quote:
Under the sub-clause
in the Conscription
Act, popularly known
as the Family
Shirkers' Clause,

the War, could be
called up without
having appeared in

The total number
called up under the
"Family Shirker"
section (35) of the
Military Service Act
is 2851.

An Act to make Further Provision for the Raising and Maintenance of Expeditionary Forces during the Present War. Ibid. 95 35. (1). If the Minister of Defence is satisfied with respect to any family that it consists of or includes two or more brothers who belong to the First Division of the Reserve,and are not permanently unfit for military service, he may.. give or cause to be given notice to all or any of those brothers to show cause before a Military Service Board why they should not be called up for service with the Expeditionary Force.
Notes: The act to which the term "family shirker" applies

geological
formations of New
Zealand, have
adopted for the
formation of those
subaerial
accumulations the
expression `Fan',
for those of regular
watercourses; and of
`Half-cone', for
those of
intermittent
mountain torrents,
and we shall for the
future use these two
expressions.

In previous
publications
(amongst others,
`Report ...
Canterbury Plains,
1864' page 22 et
seq) I have shown
how in post-pliocene
times from the
material brought
down by the enormous
glacier torrents
forming huge shingle
fans at the foot of
the glaciers, two
bars were thrown
across the sea;

Content with our
day's walk, we
camped on the large
fan of Pass Creek.

[The Canterbury
Plains] have been
formed by the
overlapping fans of
great glacier
streams ...

Author: SPEIGHT
Quote:
One word now
universally accepted
in geological
literature, viz.,
`fan', was first
used by [Haast].

Fan: Hill creeks in
Canterbury and Otago
bring a lot of
shingle down with
them when they are
in flood. On steep
hillsides this
shingle shingle
spreads on each side
of the creek, narrow
at the top and wide
at the bottom. This
natural feature is
called a fan. In
time tussocks grow
over the shingle and
some large fans of
500 to 1000 or more
acres contain very
good land. (C.)

Author: DAWSON
Quote: In the Cook Strait area the grey-leaved spaniard (Aciphylla squarrosa) is also a common plant on fans.

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
It was proposed to
subsidise the
topdressing and
oversowing of 1450
acres on the
uncultivatible fan
country and on part
of the hill ewe
block.

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
The fifth year was
to include 120
chains of fencing on
another hill block
.. and the
cultivation of
turnips on a further
80 acres of native
tussock or the
better fan country.

... extensive
surveys ...; made
for railway and
other purposes, have
confirmed in a
remarkable degree my
views concerning the
`fan' character of
the deposits of the
principal rivers in
every respect.

During growth the
young leaves arise
from the centre of
the [flax-] plants,
so that the outer
leaves of a `fan'
are the oldest, ...

Egg-laying is
carried out during
the night. ... A
favourite place is
between the tree
edges of leaves at
the base of fans,
where a single row
may be inserted.

Author: BAUME
Quote:
Paul gulped his tea
and Tapere fanged
the bread.

It isn't worth
trying to explain to
them (truthfully)
that I am by far the
slowest fanger of
the lot - the rest
have been fanging
themselves silly for
decades, while I am
strictly a novice.

The people spat and
cursed: "But the
bleedin' cars will
still bottleneck
after fanging it up
the flash new road,
and merging into a
50km zone at Pukerua
Bay!"

The road trip has
been in the planning
for years, but one
day they seize the
moment and off they
fang through the
provinces of their
native Argentina to
Chile...

Not for me the noisy
proline/ but the
quiet of the auger
and fang-spanner - /
long tom and jim
crow,/ strumming on
the old banjo./ ...

Cross-cultural
differences mean the
Germans can't
understand the New
Zealanders' passion
for what the hacks
call "fanging" -
basically
sophisticated
hooning.

German-Kiwi
relations
deteriorate during a
further anti-fanging
lecture but then
it's on with the
show after
diplomatic talks
soothe ruffled
feathers on both
sides.

Source: Codes for Species in NZ Waters
Quote: [species name] anoplogaster cornuta .. [scientific name] Anoplogaster cornuta .. [other name(s)] fangtooth

opening window over

sash window

radiating glass

Author: CHURCHMAN & HURST
Quote:
The 6.35 am from
Greymouth was the
'Miner's Train',
while the return
working, the 7.35 am
from Rewanui was the
'Fannie Train", as
the women from
Dunollie and Rewanui
used it to go to
work in Greymouth.

They [the bees] are
facing the hives
with their abdomens
pointing upwards.
This work is called
"fanning" and they
are ventilating the
interior of the
hive.

I have got a great
many birds since you
have been away,
which I shot with
your gun or a
catapult (excuse
spelling), and which
I stuff and hang up
by the beak. ... One
of them is a New
Zealand bittern ...
I have also the
mako-mako,
silver-eye,
riro-riro,
miro-miro, fanny
etc. ...

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The
Author: TURNER
Quote:
... the way to ask
for a truce in a
game is to call Pax
... At the school I
went to, the word
was Fritz, and the
truce was terminated
by the call Fritz
all over, but we
knew that some
schools used Fans
(from south-west
English dialect fain
I or fainits ?).
Apparently some New
Zealand schools use
or have used baldy,
which sounds like a
variant of English
barley.

Thanks to a flood of
correspondence, my
ignorance is now
abated. The
commonest truce word
in New Zealand seems
to be `fans' with a
variant, `fangs' ...
As children grow up,
the words fall into
disuse. They are not
forgotten. One of my
daughters complained
that I had not
consulted. Her word
had been `fans'.

Air travel - it's
fantabulous.
Notes: this is also OED2's first citation

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The

Quote: Fantail Rhipidura fuliginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787) North Island Fantail R.f. placabilis BANGS, 1921. South Island Fantail R.f. fulginosa (SPARRMAN, 1787). Chatham Island Fantail R.f. penitus BANGS, 1911. OTHER NAMES: Piwakawaka, pied fantail, black fantail.

... Read the papers
& did Maori, went
for about half an
hour in the Domain &
found a fantail nest
(young ones) & a
riroriro's with two
young ones & an egg.
I am inclined to
think the egg is a
pipiwharauroa's
(white, with purple
spots at the larger
end). Splitting
firewood in the afn.
I found a fine large
centipede - a weri -
body brown, with the
articulations very
plainly marked, legs
a pale blue ... c.
have an appetite
like a fantail. See
appetite.

There are thought to
be about 10
subspecies of
fantail, three of
which occur in New
Zealand: the North
Island, South Island
and Chatham Islands
fantail.

The small piwakawaka
(fantail) sings most
cheerfully at the
head of the spring.

It's an old Maori
belief - when I was
growing up a fantail
in the house meant
death.

It sits in scattered
beech forest in
which fantails and
bellbirds flit and
sing, and is right
on the edge of Abel
Tasman National Park
where the Takaka
Hill tumbles to the
sea.

That special little
bird, the fantail
flycatcher,
Rhipidura
flabellifera,
accompanied me.

The last I shal
[sic] mention is the
Fan-Tail. Of these
there are different
sorts, but the body
of the most
remarkable one is
scarce larger than a
good Filbert, yet
spreads a tail of
most beautiful
plumage full 3/4 of
a semi-circle, of,
at least, 4 or 5
Inches radius.

Two fantails follow
us down through the
trees, flitting for
invisible insects.

Numbers of native
birds such as
tomtits, white
heads, grey warblers
and fantails are
expected to increase
in the Otaki
catchment of the
Tararua Forest Park
...

Fantails
particularly love
the water's edge.

Quote:
The Fantail crutch,
involving two
positions, is
physically harder,
and in operation is
slower.

In the morning the

of the season. I was

prefer the first
style.

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote: In the lower regions the forest was much enlivened by birds. I shot some parrots [fn Nestor meridionalis. Kaka of the natives.], pigeons [fn Columba spadicea, Lath. Kukupa.], and wattle-birds [fn Glaucopis cinerea, Gmel. Kokako.]. Among the branches of the trees hopped the Neat fantail flycatcher [fn Muscicapa flabellifera, Gml. Piwakawaka.], and a social bird of a yellow colour, which has been depicted by Forster [fn Orthornyx heteroclytus, Lef. Popokatea.], and which had much the habits of the finch. Ibid. 1/77 Sometimes, indeed, the mako-mako [fn Philedon Dumerilii] pours forth ... its melodious notes; or perhaps a hawk [fn Falco brunnea] is seen watching the movements of a smaller bird; or the fan-tail flycatcher busy in the lower branches.
Small birds, such as the fan-tailed fly-catcher (Rhipidura flabellifera) ... are also introduced into the [Maori] ear as ornaments; ...

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson

The tamest little

It is believed the
18-year-old took the
gamma hydroxybutyric
acid (GBH), commonly
known as Fantasy or
Liquid E, during the
ball.

Fantasy (liquid
Fantasy, GHB,):
Central nervous
system depressant.
Comes in various
forms, most
notorious one is
1,4-B which has been
blamed for a couple
of deaths in New
Zealand in recent
years. Also known as
date rape drug.

Fantasy produces a
euphoria similar to
alcohol but its side
effects include
severe respiratory
depression, coma and
death.

than those in the
GAQ grade and they
may be less plump
and longer in the

carcasses of

will be graded FAQ

One of the effects
of the disappearance
of the rabbit in the
far back is the
increase spread of
the blue tussock.

I have been

The title The Far

more northern

(Fox Glacier) and

will enjoy meeting
the Far Downers as I
[sic] much as I

It was the beginning

'Far Downers' ...
[far-downer]

Yes, these folk in

Some of the smaller

country have been

On the Snares the
penguins are in what

isolated groups,

Bounty Islands they
are all over.

A farm bike is a
substitute for a
horse. It is a
small-engined
off-road motorcycle,
two wheels with
knobby tyres
decently arranged
one behind the other
and usually with a
platform at the back
for dogs to ride on.

with a shepherd, ...

Author: BANKS
Quote: We also once or twice met with a herb like that which the country people in England call Lambs quarters or Fat hen, which we boiled instead of Greens. [fn 10] The New Zealand variety of this herb is Chenopodium triandrum. It may be added, as a philogical curiosity, that Bank's words, taken over into Hawkesworth, become in OED the first literary mention of `lambs' quarters', though `fat-hen' is here ignored in favour of a 1795 appearance.

Author: TAYLOR

This cosmopolitan plant is widespread in New Zealand but not abundant enough to cause much trouble.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote: In 1908 there was a local strike [on the West Coast] and shortly afterwards the miners formed a Federation of Labour to which, within a few years, were affiliated most of the miners and waterside workers. The 1912 constitution of the `Red Federation' began with the preamble of the IWW ... Ibid. 280 The more militant unionists were unhappy about their regimentation in the Federation of Labour, which was formed in 1937, or the restriction of their action by compulsory arbitration and the Government's `stabilization' policy.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
One professional

used to watch a
rabbiter `feed' his
block - that is, to
cut up pieces of
carrot along the
intended poison
lines so that the
rabbits would get
used to the feed
before the
strychnine was
applied - and then,
after two feeds, he
would step in one
night ahead of the
rabbiter with his
own poison and make
a kill.

Author: STRONACH

The rabbits are then

feeding is usually
done three times,
and the rabbits eat
up the carrot each
time. On the fourth
night the poison is
laid ...

Author: CARR

When the flax
arrives at the mill
it is weighed and
credited to the
cutter. The `bench
loader' then takes
two or three bundles
and puts them in a
barrel (heavy end
down). He then takes
the longest leaves
and places them on a
bench convenient to
the `feeder'.
...[44] The `feeder'
takes each blade
separately and
places the butt end
into the `stripper'
which takes the
green outer covering
off. ... The fibre
as it leaves the
stripper is caught
by the `fly boy',
who collects enough
to make into a hank,
which he places
convenient for the
`shaker'. The
latter, with a
motion like cracking
a whip, gets rid of
as much rubbish as
possible, after
which he places the
hank handy for the
`washer'. This man
places the fibre in
a vat, through which
... clean water is
running.

Author: BURTON
Quote: A native of South America, the feijoa is grown in many parts of the world only as an ornamental plant. ...[19]In fact, by

locomotives started
service on the

behind his invention
had already fallen
from favour in

The famous Fell

They have toiled

The Fell railway

The unique Fell

grip the rails on

Plans are now under

magnificent engines

their way up what
was the
longest-running fell
railway in the
world... The fell
patent system was
developed by English
engineer John Fell.
In addition to
conventional wheels,
it equipped
locomotives with
wheels that
horizontally gripped
a centre rail,
providing extra
traction and
braking.

cottages for the New
Zealand Fencibles.
Notes: 1847 Nov 23 Letter (Auckland) in 1849 Power Sketches in NZ 283

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
During the year
1847, ... about 500
veteran
out-pensioners,
constituted into a
regiment of New
Zealand Fencibles,
have been sent to
Auckland at public
expense, with their
wives and families;
...

Author: COWAN
Quote:
The corps known as
the Royal New
Zealand Fencibles,
... was a body of
veteran soldiers
converted into
military settlers,
established through
Governor Grey's
efforts as a
protection for the
southern frontier of
the Auckland
Settlement. It
consisted of
discharged British
soldiers, about
three-fourths of
them pensioners, and
all men of approved
character and
physique. The corps
was enrolled in
England in 1847. The
term of service in
New Zealand was to
be seven years (most
of the soldiers
became permanent
settlers); ... on
arrival in the
colony each Fencible
was given possession
of a two-roomed
cottage and an acre
of land ... The
members of the corps
were required to
attend six days'
drill in the spring
and six in autumn,
and to attend church
parade every Sunday,
fully armed, for
inspection. ... The
settlements in which
the pensioners were
established were
Onehunga, Otahuhu,
[451] Panmure, and
Howick; these places
were practically
founded as villages
by the Fencibles.

Author: NORRIS
Quote:
After Hone Heke's
rebellion ... in
1845, military
settlements to
provide a bulwark
between Auckland and
the Maoris had been
established, at
Onehunga, Otahuhu,
Howick and Panmure.
These settlers were
military pensioners,
called `Fencibles'
and their villages
were to form a ring
of husbandsmen
trained to the use
of arms; a
self-supporting
guard.

Author: BUCKLEY
Quote:
The first families
[of military
settlers] reached
Auckland in August
1847 on the Ramilies
from Tilbury. ...
Known as the
`Fencibles' -
soldiers liable only
for home service -
they were provided
with a house and
land at the outpost
settlements.

Author: CRESSWELL
Quote:
The Fencibles were
pensioners from
various regiments of
the British Army,
all of whom had seen
over 20 years of
active service in
India, China,
Afghanistan, or
other countries.
Although no longer
fit for the rigours
of overseas
campaigns, they were
all under 48 years
of age, of good
physique and
character, and quite
fit for the garrison
duty which was
theirs when they
came to New Zealand
in the years 1847-8;
a few following in
1852.

The vibrant history
of the fencibles and
their Maori
neighbours is very
much alive at the
village...

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
Several natives on
the beach from
Waikari who had
brought Tacopa for
fencing.

Author: MARSDEN
Quote:
There was no wood
for building and
fencing for miles,
or even firewood.

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
Set two parties on
getting posts for
fencing, and some to
saw fencing.

This day the Men
employed fencing and
clearing ground for
a Garden.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Fencing and ditching
cost little, as
labourers were
numerous in
comparison with the
demand for labour;
...

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
I want a man for
about two months to
do all sort [sic] of
station work - a
little fencing sod
work and post and
rails -
Notes: 1861 Oct 13 Butler to Tripp in 1960 Maling Samuel Butler 56

Quote:
Fencing all the day
and finished all the
places that can be
mended with sods,
the remaining ones
must have rails.

About [pound]1.3/-
per acre for fencing
if done in blocks of
not less than 640
acres.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
After a spell of
`quill-driving' it
takes one a week or
so to get into one's
stride of splitting,
fencing,
bullock-punching
again; ...
Meanwhile, one can
make good money at
hard graft.

Author: FEATON
Quote:
The next afternoon,
two men ..., whilst
engaged in fencing
behind Mr. Hay's
house near Papakura,
were fired upon by a
party of the enemy.

Walter was a fencing
contractor, and he
was away from home
for long periods.

Author: HILL
Quote:
The phone starts
ringing at 5am most
mornings as
share-milkers,
fencing contractors,
milk-tanker drivers,
and general purpose
farmers with calving
problems all try to
get on the line at
once

Chas and I put up
post and rail
fencing ... The
first Overland Mail
to the West Coast
went through today.
They had to borrow a
horse from Enys to
go on one stage.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
... there was quite
an excitement in ...
seeing the changes
the flood had made,
and the mischief it
had done to the
fencing; - this was
in process of being
repaired.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
[Refce 1836] burning
some of the fencing.

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The
Author: WILLIAMS
Quote:
Boys fencing and
digging.

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
Gilbert was much
impressed with the
beauty of the birch
[beech] trees ..
observing that there
was a 'deal of good
fencing in them'.

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
Later, broadleaf was
the timber chiefly
used for fencing,
because it was much
less inflammable
than totara.

Author: MULGAN
Quote:
Packing fencing in
tussock land.

Author: CHINN
Quote:
I remained with my
brothers for some
time, felling bush
and cutting fencing
for settlers in the
district.

Author: WESTMACOTT
Quote:
We put up
three-quarters of a
mile of this
fencing.

I would include
among New Zealand
English words:
fencing-gang

Author: WATERS
Quote:
Looking round at the
fencing gang he said
"By hell they were
close."

Source: Pigs and Me: Tales of the Bygone Bush.
Author: COWAN
Quote:
He used to do
contract fencing at
Awakino and my
mother would end up
cooking for the
fencing gang in the
camps, with old camp
ovens.

Author: HILL
Quote:
Where in the city
would you find.. the
newest thing in
pop-up, infra-wave,
micro-red toaster
standing on coils of
fencing wire?

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
Fend off. To take:
New Zealand c.
(-1932). I.e. fend a
thing off from
another, i.e. for
oneself.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Fend off.

[In local criminal
slang] ... `to
clout,' `to pole,'
`to fend off' are to
steal; ...

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote:
6 To take; to steal:
New Zealand: since
ca. 1920: 1932,
Nelson Baylis
(private letter).
Perhaps to fend off
the inquisitive and
take what one
requires.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
fend off to take or
steal; c.1932.

FENDER. A log, pole
or stake placed
alongside a snig
track to protect
trees from damage in
hauling.

In real life, a town
like that would be
full of racist
senior citizens,
violent ferals
living out their Mad
Max fantasies and
other assorted white
trash.

Okay, mate, I
thought to myself, I
can see where you're
coming from -
something about
ferals and coal
smoke that the
cappucino drinkers
can smile over.

The pinot noir ($45)
is a delicately
spiced berried wine
with what Larry
describes as
"feral", as opposed
to "wild" flavours..

We scatter goats and
feral cats on the
road to Raetihi,
turn a corner and
suddenly,
majestically,
there's Mt Ruapehu
in the distance -
its piping running
all the way beneath
us to the Whanganui.

By the turn of the
19th century,
Hauturu's original
population of tieke
had become extinct -
wiped out by feral
cats... in the
1880s, the notorious
tomb-robber and
collector of rare
bird skins Andreas
Reischek reported
Maori dogs and feral
pigs wandering free
all over the island.

[Hdg] Fifty furry
ferine felines
found... We had long
been concerned about
the effect of feral
cats on native
bird-life, the
health of people
walking in the area
and the risk of
infection to
domestic cats.

The feral geese
managed to stay out
of range, sidling
along steep slopes
and complaining and
they went.

They were, Frame
wrote, "feral
children who ran
wild, did not come
when called, pulled
faces and said bum
and fart and f***"

There was a time,
just before goats
became valuable,
when I had to stop
the car to allow a
herd of feral goats
to cross the road.

Any one of those MPs
might go feral on
Shipley.

The car parks are
becoming quite feral
places.

She managed the
unpredictable
Tamihere's exit from
cabinet while
avoiding having him
go feral and quit
Parliament, forcing
a by-election.

While he sports
nautical tattoos and
looks slightly
"feral", he enjoys
what the city has to
offer - the chance
to play music.

Waikato also has a
long and dubious
history of playing
the man at the
bottom of the
ruck... It's a sort
of feral Taranaki.

Mr Dunne spoke
scathingly of
Winston and his
"feral inbreds" at a
PR company's
political breakfast
this week.

At times it felt
like I was on one of
those Landmark
personal courses,
except that this one
had gone feral.

The situation arose
from a contaminated
feral-game meat
scare, and a press
statement by the
Minister of
Agriculture
threatening a ban on
feral-game exports,
which put a stop to
most feral-game
processing.

Author: TINSLEY
Quote:
The little Fergie
tractor bucked as
the last of the
three cans was
rolled off the
moss-covered
trailer.

Now, when I take the
Fergie up the farm,
tears pour down as I
remember what those
poor animals went
through.

Source: High Times in the High Country
Author: KERR
Quote:
The Fergie's wheels
spun uselessly for a
while, but the tail
twisting eventually
got her in. I
explained that the
old Fergie wasn't
even one cowpower.

I use the Fergie for
the same jobs any
farmer would ..
lifting, carting,
spreading metal,
carting fencing
materials and weed
spraying.

Apart from the
ever-popular
'Fergie,' there are
many tractor
choices.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Fergusson's Kelpfish Chironemus fergussoni (Hector)
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 408

Author: SELWYN
Quote:
Walked over fern
hills, to a small
village called
Taupo; and on,
through swampy
plains, to Mangonui
...
Notes: 1843 Aug 21 Selwyn Journal in 1845 NZ Part II (Church in the Colonies VII) 12

Author: DONALDSON
Quote:
... away over the
fern-flats.

Source: Report on Topographical Exploration of Nelson
Author: HAAST
Quote:
He conducted us ...
through the bush,
where we found a
good blazed line,
which brought us ...
to the open terraced
fern flat ...

The track we followed ran along a long valley lying behind high fern hills, ... Ibid. For miles and miles now there was an unbroken stream of soldiers, bullock-drays, artillery, packhorses and orderlies meandering over the plains and fern ridges of the sacred Maori delta.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
Flats are
alternating along
the course of the
river with
fern-hills.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
`We then had a
stroll round until
time to turn in to
our fern bed under
canvas, the novelty
of which my friend
enjoyed immensely.'
Notes: >c1880s an anonymous tourist in 1959 L. Masters Tales of the Mails 47

Quote: fern clubmoss n : an epiphytic Australasian fern ally (Tmesipteris tannensis) with large lanceolate green leaves that grows on trunks of tree ferns

The greater part of
that block was
originally swampy
and fern country.

Author: MARKHAM
Quote:
... we ... got on an
open plain, fine
foot Path, through
fern country
undulating and quite
pleasant for the
Feet.

Author: ANGAS
Quote:
.. many swamps had
to be crossed,
during our passage
through an [95] open
fern country, the
valleys of which
were clothed with a
coarse wiry grass,
called by the
natives wiwi.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
[Kapiti
neighbourhood]
consists of open
grass or fern
country,
interspersed with
swamps and marshes
easy of drainage.

Author: WALLACE
Quote:
The land for
reclamation in New
Zealand may be
divided into three
kinds: (1) The fern
country, (2) the
bush country, and
(3) the flat or
swampy country.

`Fern-bird' is
rather a misnomer
nowadays, for,
whatever the habit
of the utick may
have been, I have
never yet, though
riding over hundreds
of miles of
fern-country ...,
observed the bird in
this kind of
herbage.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Fern country is found throughout New Zealand but becomes more plentiful towards the North. Here there are large areas covered with the bracken (Pteridium esculentum).

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
It was open fern
country for the most
part, extending from
the foothills of the
Ruahine and Kaweka
ranges to the ocean.

It is a charming
little spot,
surrounded by bush
on three sides and
with pretty, but
worthless fern
country on the
other.

Author: WALLACE
Quote:
Of the fern country,
that upon a
limestone formation
is the best and
least expensive to
break in.

500 acres flat,
balance good strong
fern country,
well-watered, partly
fenced.

In the North Island
light fern-country
is often ploughed in
September, as the
young fern-shoots
are very vulnerable.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Fern stain - sheep
grazing on fern
country in spring or
early summer may
gather up this
powdery material in
the fleece.

It will deal with
another class of
hill country for
which there appears
to be good scope for
economic development
in the district -
bracken-fern
country.

Source: Sheep Farming in the NZ Bush
Author: WILLIAMSON
Quote:
I am referring not
to the areas of fern
country that one
sees in certain
parts, but to
country that has
been bush and then
grassed according to
the usual methods
and has subsequently
been allowed to go
back into this
state.
[fern-country;
bracken-fern
country]

`... instead of bread they eat the roots of a kind of Fern Pteris crenulata, very like that which grows upon our commons in England.' [fn] The common N.Z. bracken fern, Pteridium aquilinium var. esculentum (Forst.)

Firn(?) roots they
likewise heat ...
than beat them out
flat ...; these
firns[sic] are much
alike if not the
same as the Mountain
ferns in England.
[fn] Bracken,
Pteridium aquilinum,
var. esculentum.

Author: SAVAGE
Quote:
[Savage talks about
root of fern, but
does not use
fernroot] The fern
grows here in great
abundance

Author: ELDER
Quote:
Those parts which
are not cultivated
are generally
covered with fern.
Notes: 1814 Sep 6 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 59

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote:
[sc. bracken] The
fern is an
invaluable
production to these
people, who subsist
in a great measure
on the roots of it,
from which they
prepare a sort of
bread. As it grows
here in the greatest
abundance, they may
be always sure of an
inexhaustible
supply.

Author: McCRAE
Quote:
... covered with
fern excepting two
or three small
patches ... some
parts swampy and
covered with reeds.
Towards the close of
the day we passed
through 2 large wood
separated from each
other by a tract of
open country ...

The hair seal,
generally resort to
places where there
is plenty of fern
growing and here
they breed; ...

Author: MATHEW
Quote:
I found, however,
that what has the
appearance of Downs
is in reality
covered with Fern,
so thick and strong
as to be almost
impenetrable, ...
added to which it is
entangled ... with
the vines of the
wild Convolvulus,
which grows
everywhere in the
greatest luxuriance,
so that to traverse
it is all but
impossible.
Notes: 1840 Feb 27 F.Mathew Journal in 1940 Founding of NZ 64

Author: BIDWILL
Quote:
The country about
Tawranga for about
ten miles inland is
almost a perfect
level covered with
fern; ...

Natives and self off
exploring, when we
found a patch of
fern, which we
quickly began
rooting up to
examine its quality.
Notes: 1848 Feb 7 Brunner Nelson Examiner in 1952 Brunner 74

Author: SENIOR
Quote:
The fern (bracken)
is dense.

Author: FROUDE
Quote: (And) Pteridium esculentum
(And) Pteridium esculentum

Author: DOBBIE
Quote: (And) Pteridium esculentum
Fern: This name covers any fern growing outside the bush. The two chief kinds are bracken (Pteris) and the shiny green kind (Blechnum). (C.R., p. 3).
FERN. A general term for heath associations dominated by bracken fern (Pteridium esculentum).

Author: WHITE
Quote:
Fern-seekers would
have little or no
sport in the depths
of the Bush, but
just inside, it is
deeply carpeted with
Ferns.

Author: POTTS
Quote:
We will ramble
together in search
of some of our New
Zealand ferns.

Author: WOODHOUSE
Quote:
[Mr Buchanan]
remembered walking
along a track made
by wild pigs through
tall fern and flax
to the site of the
present homestead.

Source: From New Plymouth to New Plymouth
Author: HURSTHOUSE IN WOOD (1959)
Quote:
In cultivating fern
land, the first
operation is to
clear away the fern.

Author: PARK
Quote:
Chimney stumps stood
amongst ragwort and
tutu, which killed
cattle, and always
the intractable
fern, which had been
waiting outside the
fence all the time.

Author: SWAN
Quote:
Today, however, the
fern face was
deserted so I
wandered back to
Terry's via a
fast-running creek.

Author: DONALDSON
Quote:
... away over the
fern-flats.

He had had no
valuable horses and
expensive implements
in those days - only
one old nag and an
axe and a slasher
and a fern hook.

Author: SARGESON
Quote:
... as for the fern,
it was up to him, he
could please
himself, although it
was usually reckoned
a fern-hook was the
best; but he could
see how he got on
and stick to the
slasher if he
preferred.

Author: MARTIN
Quote: Much the most attractive of the others [umbrella mosses], and the largest, is the FERN-MOSS (H[ypopterigium] filiculaeforme) which selects swampy forest floors or shady stations on the margins of forest streams.

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
Their habitat is the
new house of fern
posts ...

Author: ATKINSON
Quote:
The fern post house
is no longer used as
a dwelling house but
contains D's forge
...

On Tuesday a fire
started in a fern
range, which ran on
to a kauri bush
owned by Mr. R. C.
Smith, one of whose
sons was on
horseback close to
where the fire
started.

With between 500 and
600 armed men in
high spirits,
excellent condition,
and inflamed with
the desire to
revenge the death of
their friends, we
march twenty miles
over hill, gully,
and fern range, burn
some whares, kill an
ancient cripple, and
return declaring
that no enemy is to
be found.

The road lay over a
number of fern
ranges.

His residence is
situated on the
saddle of a high
fern range,
seemingly the least
attractive part of
his property, but as
you draw near you
are at once struck
and surprised with
the vigorous growth
of flowers and
various shrubs,
vegetables, &c ...

Well then you see
the opinion to which
I incline is that
our rat - whether
the true Kiore Maori
or not - is an
indigenous rodent,
the same which
Professor Hutton
calls the Mus
maorium, and which
we may familiarly
name the Fern Rat,
in reference to its
usual habitat.

It appears that the
rat in question is
not the common
Norway rat, but an
indigenous rodent
known as the "fern
rat".

Author: POTTS
Quote:
Among the Maoris, as
an article of food,
fern root held a
most important place
in their social
economy.

When food was
scarce, Maori ate
fern root, which
caused constipation.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
fern stain - sheep
grazing in fern
country in spring or
early summer may
gather up this
powdery material in
the fleece.

Source: A to Z Glossary of Wool Terms
Author: SQUIRE
Quote:
Fern Stain - wool
stained by the
spores of bracken
fern.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Author: FORSTER
Quote: Last Sunday our people observed that the natives took the Stalks of the Ferntrees, broiled the whole & eat the inner-pulp. [ed. fn] Cyathea dealbata Swartz.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote: `... they roast, or rather bake the root and part of the stalk of the large Fern tree, in a great hole dug for that purpose.' [[fn] prob. mamaku, Cyathea medullaris. (Also fern root on same page =bracken.]
Notes: 1777 Feb 25 Anderson Journal in 1967 Cook Journals 3/812

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote:
The fern-tree, that
ornament to the
forest in these
regions, was to be
seen in many places
growing with great
luxuriance.

Author: YATE
Quote:
Another very
peculiar feature in
wood and
forest-scenery of
New Zealand is the
growth of the palm
and the fern-tree,
the latter of which
is a very remarkable
plant.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote:
We passed through
several woods filled
with fern trees and
some very curious
plants - ...

Author: DIEFFENBACH
Quote:
They are
intermingled with
fern-trees,
especially Cyathea
medullaris and
Cyathea dealbata;
while the
cabbage-palm (Areca
sapida) grows in the
deepest recesses.

Author: BRUNNER
Quote:
We tried a species
of fern tree called
kakote, but it is
far from palatable.

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
The luxuriant beauty
of the New Zealand
forests almost
equals that of the
tropics, indeed the
presence of the
graceful fern-trees,
and elegant nikau
palms, gives them
quite a tropical
aspect.
Notes: 1847 Johnson Notes from a Journal in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 121

Quote:
.. clearing away all
the ugly undergrowth
from a number of
beautiful fern trees
...

Author: THOMSON
Quote: The pith of the stem of the fern-tree (Cyathea medullaris) ... [is] eaten.

In the decoration of
the [Otago
Horticultural
Society] show-room,
the graceful young
Red Pine, and the Ti
and Fern Trees,
ranked first among
our native trees.

Well and good, we
plant ourselves not
too much opposite
one another off the
road behind the fern
trees, and wait.
Sometimes ... the outside was formed of hard fibrous slabs cut from the stout red-brown fern-tree, Wekiponga[sic] (Dicksonia australis); ...

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
The palm fern-tree
was there, with its
crown of graceful
bending fronds and
black
feathery-looking
young shoots; ...

Author: HAY
Quote:
There is the
cabbage-tree palm,
with bare shank and
top-knot; the nikau
palm, with weird and
wondrous frondage;
the lancewood, ...;
the fern-tree, ....
There is the
twisting, squirming
rata; the gaunt ...
kahikatea; the
golden kowhai; the
dark velvet-covered
rimu; the feathery
red tawai; the
perfumy mangiao; ...

Author: BROOKES
Quote:
... whitewood, fern
trees, bush karaka
... puketea.

Some people speak
and write of them as
`tree ferns' ...
this is of course
loose and
misleading. There
are fern-trees on my
section up to fifty
feet in height, and
at least one of them
- the wheki variety,
is a hard-bitten
fellow ... The
unobservant are apt
to lump all
fern-trees together,
as pongas, or, in
the vernacular,
`bungers'.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
... the slopes are
black-pencilled with
the stumps of the
wheki, a fern-tree
whose butt is as
hard as ironbark and
almost as
indestructible.
Fern-tree n. a large fern with a stem like a tree trunk; a tree-fern.-fern'-tree gul'ly n. a shady gully with its sides thickly covered with tree-ferns.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
There were no fern
trees in the nearest
bush, so the
construction of the
huts [c1840] was of
a decidedly
wattle-and-daub
nature, but all were
roofed with thatch.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
[The early
runholder's home]
... might be of
stone, clay, brick,
earth, timber,
canvas, ferntrees,
or wattle-and-daub.

Author: DEWAR
Quote:
The principal
building material
used [on the
Southland bush farms
c1900] was
fern-tree, known
locally as bungie,
upright on some
walls, horizontal on
others ...

It was "too late!" -
a phrase which has
been oft and
mournfully repeated
since "the fern was
set aflame" in 1860.

There are about 5
and a half winter
stock units an acre
on the effective
area, 3 and a half
on the total area.
And that doesn't
include
summer-grazed stock
which recently
included 3000 ewes
(for fern-breaking)
and 400 dairy-beef
bulls.

The small cray-fish in myriads bred,/ With sunk fern-bundles lifted from the Lake:/ Next pounded fern-root pounded to a cake,/ ...; and the choicer roots,/ .../ The kumara [u-acute] and taro. [a-acute]

On the 13th of
February Jackson and
I had sent our two
subalterns with 50
men fern-burning on
the Pironghia.

Fern-clad gullies
are the resting
place for all manner
of vehicles, from
war-vintage saloons
to four-wheel drive
landrovers.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote:
I did not dream
then, that I should
spend so many nights
... in the bush or
upon the fern-clad
hills of New
Zealand.

Author: CAMPBELL
Quote:
On that morning the
open country
stretched away in
vast fields of fern,
and Nature reigned
supreme. It is
fern-clad now no
longer, but green
fields gladden the
eye; the white gleam
of the farmer's
homestead dots the
landscape, there are
villas on the
height, and cottages
on the shore.

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
To the right ... lie
wave upon wave of
manuka, gorse, and
fern-clad hills, ...

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
On the Sunday they
set out across the
big scrub and fern
clad towards the
Wakararas.

Author: SCRYMGEOUR
Quote:
Long were the hours
spent in the saddle,
through the
fern-fringed roads,
seeking stock, or
properties for sale,
for the district was
closely settled.

Author: THOMPSON
Quote:
Past fern-girt gully
and gurgling creek,
with a wealth of
bush beside;/

Author: WALLACE
Quote:
In the New Zealand
climate fern-crushed
pasture-land of good
medium quality will
support one to three
sheep per acre.
[Previous paragraph
decribes putting
sheep on burnt-over
fern, to eat new
young shoots.]

Cattle are often
looked upon as more
efficient
fern-crushers than
are sheep on land
suitable for cattle.

Cattle are often
looked upon as more
efficient
fern-crushers than
are sheep on land
suitable for cattle.

.. cattle are
generally regarded
as the more efficent
fern-crushers on
land suitable for
them.

Author: BREMNER
Quote:
By the end of the
1870s the best land
in the central
coastal plains and
hillcountry from
Napier to Takapau
had been freeholded,
pedigree stock were
joining the pioneer
'fern crusher'
flocks ...

Author: WALLACE
Quote:
Fern-crushing. Of
the fern country,
that upon a
limestone formation
is the best and the
least expensive to
break in.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The first care of
the settler was to
increase his area of
grass by the
operation known
through Hawke's Bay
as fern-crushing or
fern-grinding ...

Fern crushing is at
times severe on
stock, and they
should not be left
on too long ...

Author: CUMBERLAND
Quote:
Another really
extensive cultural
practice that
modified the New
Zealand landscape
was 'fern-crushing'
- the replacement at
the cost of
continued effort, of
the natural
Pteridium (bracken
fern) heath with
artificial
grassland.

Author: MCCASKILL
Quote:
Another really
extensive cultural
practice that
modified the New
Zealand landscape
was fern-crushing.

Author: SUTHERLAND & TAYLOR
Quote:
He needed some
cattle for
fern-crushing, but
he thought of
himself as a sheep
farmer.
[fern-grinding]

Author: WALLACE
Quote: Fern crushing. Of the fern country, that upon a limestone formation is the best and the least expensive to break in. Ibid. 245 Cattle [bold] are required for jungle or fern-crushing ...

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The first care of
the settler was to
increase his area of
grass by the
operation known
through Hawke's Bay
as `fern-crushing'
or `fern-grinding,'
- words ominous of
the part played by
the unfortunate
sheep, and which
will be described
later. It is
sufficient now to
state that after
fire had cleared the
tangled bracken
growth, the ground
was surface-sown and
kept clear by
browsing sheep. As
the greatest growth
of fern took place
during late spring,
it was then
impossible to have
too many sheep.
Every squatter in
Hawke's Bay was in
the 'eighties
`fern-grinding,' so
that in those times
sheep could not be
bought at that
season of the year.
The result was that
every sheep likely
to survive the
winter was kept,
however old and
however fleeced. It
was at least a pair
of jaws, a beast
that could bite
bracken.

Author: BELSHAW
Quote:
Hence beef-cattle
are used for
`fern-crushing',
that is, for keeping
in check the
undesirable second
growth of bracken
fern over large
areas of the North
Island hills.

Author: RICKARD
Quote: An operation that seems to have been peculiar to the hill country of Hawke's Bay was the strenuous one known as fern-crushing. [ref. Guthrie-Smith Tutira.]

Author: HUNT
Quote:
But there were no
cattle coming up to
listen. ... They'd
been in there fern
crushing, hundreds
of acres of bracken.
Men'd just walked
off that land in the
slump but those
cattle were breaking
it all in again.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: The Fern-flower or Sundew ( Drosera binata) ... vacated the barren edges on which perforce they had been confined.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The first care of
the settler was to
increase his area of
grass by the
operation known
through Hawke's Bay
as `fern-crushing'
or `fern-grinding,'
- words ominous of
the part played by
the unfortunate
sheep, and which
will be described
later. It is
sufficient now to
state that after
fire had cleared the
tangled bracken
growth, the ground
was surface-sown and
kept clear by
browsing sheep. As
the greatest growth
of fern took place
during late spring,
it was then
impossible to have
too many sheep.
Every squatter in
Hawke's Bay was in
the 'eighties
`fern-grinding,' so
that in those times
sheep could not be
bought at that
season of the year.
The result was that
every sheep likely
to survive the
winter was kept,
however old and
however fleeced. It
was at least a pair
of jaws, a beast
that could bite
bracken.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The first care of
the settler was to
increase his area of
grass by the
operation known
through Hawke's Bay
as fern-crushing or
fern-grinding

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Every squatter in
Hawke's Bay was in
the 'eighties
'fern-grinding';
sheep could not be
bought at that time
of the year.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
The tree-fern, here
called `fern-palm',
abounds in all the
scrubs.

Author: FROUDE
Quote: (And) Rhopalostylis sapida

Author: HUTCHINSON
Quote:
`fern-pilot' or
`fern-herald', as
the catch-fly is
sometimes called.

Author: POTTS
Quote:
It is possible that
there may yet be
heard the thud of
the fern-pounder in
some of the secluded
valleys ...

Made fern-root
cakes, &c.

Sixty Tuhourangi
fern-root grounds
are identified.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
We came to the
conclusion it [the
stone artefact] was
a fern-root pounder.

There were numbers
of wild porkers, all
young and fat
fern-rooters, how
savoury!

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
The energy .. of
certain settlers in
southern Hawke's Bay
was proving that
fern-runs could be
made to pay, at any
rate in good soils
and in dry
districts.

We have a saying on
the East Coast that
it takes three men
to make a fern-run,
and .. there is
scarcely a property
but which has passed
through three hands,
but where the first
two were ruined ..
It is no metaphor to
say the fern hills
of the East Coast
are strewn with
broken hearts.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
We are standing on
the banks of the
Horowhenua Lake ...
a pair of Papango
... are floating on
the placid waters;
... a solitary
Pekapeka is flitting
silently overhead,
chasing ... the
minute insect-life
upon which this bat
subsists; ... and
the melancholy note
of the Fern-Sparrow,
calling to his
fellows among the
rushes, has grown
languid and finally
died away; ...

[Potts gives the
reason for the name
- strangling of
tree-ferns by slow
constriction.]

But at least they
turned into the
comparative safety
of the bush track,
and just as morning
dawned, they reached
the fern-tree whare.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
A man named Adam
Hunter built a
fern-tree whare at
Green Bushes ...

Author: DEWAR
Quote:
[(usual in this
book) =TREE FERN]
... they were to
come to know every
tree ... within a
radius of a mile of
their fern-tree
house there

Author: KEENE
Quote:
We could see that
the ferntree house
was now too small
for our growing
family.

Author: HOLDEN
Quote:
Razorback was still
busily feeding in
the fernbelt.

Fernbirds are still
common on the New
Zealand mainland,
but there they are
secretive - unlike
the confident Snares
birds. They have an
unusual way of
feeding, employing
their tail feathers
as a prop while
using one or other
of their legs to
lift up twigs and
leaves to look for
insects and spiders.

Our utick, or
fern-bird, heard
everywhere in swampy
ground ... has
become very rare.
SPHENAECUS PUNCTATUS, Q. & G. - Fern Bird. ... The peculiar chirp of the fernbird is yet to be heard among the tall fern.

`Fern-bird' is
rather a misnomer
nowadays, for,
whatever the habit
of the utick may
have been, I have
never yet, though
riding over hundreds
of miles of
fern-country ...,
observed the bird in
this kind of
herbage.

Author: BULLER
Quote: [in 1873 English name COMMON UTICK only; changed to FERN-BIRD for 1888] SPHENOEACUS PUNCTATUS. (FERN-BIRD.) ... Maori names. Mata, Matata, Kotata, Nako, and Koroatito. ... It frequents the dense fern (Pteris aquilina) of the open country, ...

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Fernbird. New Zealand birds of the genus Sphenacus. Also called Grass-bird. and New Zealand pipit. There are three species. The Fern Bird Sphenoecus ounctatus, Gray. Chatham Island F.-b.- S. rufescens, Buller. Fulvous F.-b.- S. fulvus, Gray.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: Sphenaeacus punctatus - Fern Bird - Reed Sparrow.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Mata ... Sphenoeacus punctatus, fern-bird.
Bowdleria punctata Quoy & Gaim. Fern-bird. As with so many other species, the diminution in the numbers of the fern-bird is at first sight easily explicable.

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
There were
sandpipers and
waders along the
Molyneux and pukaki
and fern birds were
to be found in the
swamps.

Author: HOWARD
Quote: [Stewart Island birds include] the fern-bird (Bowdleria fulva), the bell-bird (Anthornis melanura), South Island Robin

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
[Mata (fernbird)
extinct: last seen
in the late 1880s]

Author: POWELL
Quote: FERN-BIRD (Bowdleria punctata). A small brownish striped and speckled bird with curious tail feathers, ... This bird has a curious double-note cry which sounds like `U-tick.' It is the Matata of the Maoris.

Author: PASCOE
Quote: [Pascoe's note to Douglas's Birds of South Westland] The Grassbird [The Fernbird, Bowdleria punctata] ...
fernbird n [fern + bird] : a small passerine bird ( Bowdleria punctata) of New Zealand that frequents marshy ground and is becoming rare

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: FERNBIRD Bowdleria punctata Other names: Matata, Tataki Thrush (Foveaux St.).

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: Fernbird - mata, matata, nako, potata, Bowdleria punctata

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: There are, or rather were, six races of fernbird ...: North Island (Bowdleria punctata vealeae), South Island (B. punctata punctata), Stewart Island (stewartiana), Codfish Island, west-nor'-west of Stewart Island (wilsoni), Chatham Island (rufescens- extinct for fifty years), and Snares (caudata). They are flimsy-feathered birds, living inconspicuously in manuka scrub or clumps of bracken ...
fern bird n. N.Z. bird inhabiting fern lands; grass bird of N.Z., the pipit. Maori name is mata, matata, or kotata.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Ma[a]ta[a] ... ma[a]ta[a]ta[a], n. Bowdleria punctata,fern-bird.

a native bird which
lives in raupo
swamps and is
notable for its
fern-like tail
feathers; matata
fernbird n. a New Zealand swamp bird with a fern-like tail.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Fernbird Bowdleria punctata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... North Island Fernbird B.p. vealeae KEMP, 1912. South Island Fernbird B.p. punctata (QUOY & GAIMARD, 1830) ... Codfish Island Fernbird B.p. wilsoni STEAD, 1936. Stewart Island fernbird B.p. stewartiana OLIVER, 1930. Snares fernbird B.p. caudata (BULLER, 1894). EXTINCT Chatham Island Fernbird B.p. rufescens (BULLER, 1869). OTHER NAMES: Swamp thrush, grass bird, matata.

As a result of their
efforts they
[Nukuhou Saltmarch
Care Group] now
regularly record up
to 60 fernbirds in
the monthly surveys.

When [he] was
looking for a
fern-bird whose
notes he had heard..
he saw six ferrets
disappear in a
rabbit hole.

Fern birds for the
wetlands, and
whiteheads,
bellbirds and
parakeets for the
forest are likely to
be the next arrivals
while kereru (wood
pigeons) and tuis
are also sometimes
seen.

Fern birds are to be
found in good
numbers around the
harbour's edge,
along with the New
Zealand pipit.

Author: HOBHOUSE
Quote:
The whole remainder
.. is either forest,
ferndom or sheeprun.

Author: FRAME
Quote:
The roses in the
rose arch and the
ferns in the
fernery.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
... the Procesh Day
lorry decorated with
fernery like our
tanks on a triumphal
procession through
liberated San
Giorgio ...

I can't claim to be
a female pioneer,
from the waybacks,
or a fernfighter
from Te Kuiti, or
the mother of ten,
or anything of that
kind ...

Author: BUTLER
Quote:
It was with the
daughter of this
lady that I went
`ferning'.

Ferns and Ferning
[title of a local
news item]

Author: GORDON
Quote:
The next day was
very fine. Mrs Brown
proposed that they
should go ferning.
...[4] The girls
spent a very happy
day, and got a great
many nice ferns and
some beautiful moss.
Notes: 1898 K. Mansfield (`Enna Blake') The High School Reporter (Wellington Girls' High School) in 1974 Gordon (ed) Undiscovered Country 3-4

Quote:
.. good crops can be
raised from all
kinds of land in New
Zealand; but that
the fern land
requires a good deal
of cleansing, before
it is fit to receive
seed.

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
.. we emerged into a
little bit of open
fern land.

Author: MANTELL
Quote:
Emerged from bush on
undulating fern land
burned about 2
months.
Notes: in Beattie (1947) The Pioneers Explore Otago

Author: RICHMOND
Quote:
Of bush I almost
think we have
enough, but I would
gladly buy fern land
with a proportion of
bush.

Author: PAUL
Quote:
Fern land requires
no previous labour
(except burning off)
to prepare it for
the plough.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
.. the summer fallow
is, however, the
only fallow which
sweetens fern land.

For Sale - 50 acres
of first-class fern
land at Tuakau.

The fern lands of
Auckland cannot be
brought into good
arable condition
without being
stocked for some
years with cattle.

For Sale 496 acres
heavy fern land and
ploughable.

Author: WILSON & FRASER
Quote:
In the early days
the weka or maori
hen was common in
tussock and fern
land ...

There are two main
types of fernlands
in New Zealand -
natural fernland,
that is, land that
carried fern before
the first Europeans
landed in the
country, and
artificially-induced
fernland, or land
which became covered
in fern after the
destruction of the
forest .. Certain
parts of Banks
Peninsula are
natural fernlands
which have been in
fern for a
considerable period.

Author: WASWO
Quote:
Thus while the sites
of most early
mission stations lay
in scrub or
fernland, there was
little difficulty in
keeping cattle or
raising pigs and
goats. [fernland;
fern-land]

Author: GREY
Quote:
The hillside there
was covered with a
wonderful growth of
the tree ferns,
which plant has
given New Zealand
the name Fernland;
...

Bush land is best:
it is all humbug
what is said about
fern land being so
good.

C. a working man on
fern land.

Author: FOX
Quote:
The facilities,
however, which fern
land offers,
compared with bush
or flax land, have
induced a large
proportion of the
settlers to prefer
it for their first
operation.
Notes: 1843 Dec 1 Fox to Wakefield in NZ Company Reports 1844 14/121

Author: ANGAS
Quote: Onwards, through gently undulating fern-land, interspersed with bushes of phormium tenax and an occasional dragon-tree, we again found belts of forest-land.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote: The chief part of the land ... yet cultivated near Nelson is flax or fern land. Ibid. 375 [Cost of clearing land] Fern-land, 10s. to 1l. 10s.; Wood-land, 3l. to 10l. per acre, ...
Notes: 1848 July 29 Colonization Circular No. 8, Fifth Edition (Land and Emigration Commissioners) in 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 258

Quote:
The forest we passed
through was not
continuous ... so
that every two or
three miles we
emerged into a
little bit of open
fern land.

Author: FITTON
Quote:
BUSH LAND AS
COMPARED WITH FERN
[heading] `Almost
all the crops ...
have been taken from
what is called fern
land ... But ... I
know that when I
left New Plymouth
district ... the
bush land crops of
wheat were deemed
inferior ... to
those of open fern
lands; ...

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote: Fresh fern land is at first infertile through what we call `sourness'. ... Grass land is less subject to `sourness'; and Bush land not at all. Ibid. 2/331 [spg caps] Bush land is richer than either Fern or Grass land;

Author: WILLOX
Quote:
The `Bush' or forest
land ... becomes
most speedily
productive, but
`Fern' land, that is
the land covered
with fern and
shrubby plants is
... ultimately the
most profitable.

Author: HOCHSTETTER
Quote: Not a tree interrupted the monotony of the fern-land. Ibid. 319 The road ... leads across open fern-land.

The hills ... are of
much lower
elevation, and there
is a larger extent
of fern-land.

... open fern or
tea-tree land.

Author: FEATON
Quote:
The fore-ground is
open fern land,
partially broken and
intersected by a
fresh-water stream
and one or two
shallow gullies.

Author: LADY MARTIN
Quote:
The grey scoria
houses stood out on
the bleak, high
ground, unsheltered
by a single tree,
and all around was
fern-land.

The search was a
very strenuous
ordeal, for the
party were led
through heavy bush,
tangled scrub,
flooded creeks, and
rough fern land
before they
eventually came on a
lonely and almost
inaccessible spot,
where Tahi Kaka said
the body of Freeman
would be found.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
There is more or
less a fair share of
fern and bracken
land right
throughout New
Zealand ...

Author: WILY & MAUNSELL
Quote:
The fern and manuka
land refused to grow
either corn, grass,
or root crops, and
most of our six
hundred acres
consisted of fern
land.
Notes: 1935 J.W.Stack More Maoriland Adventures in Robert Maunsell (1938) 136

Author: DAWSON
Quote:
Immediately after
the destruction of
the forests fernland
established, but,
with continued
burning, grassland
began to spread ...

Author: FITTON
Quote:
BUSH LAND AS
COMPARED WITH FERN
[heading] `Almost
all the crops ...
have been taken from
what is called fern
land ... But ... I
know that when I
left New Plymouth
district ... the
bush land crops of
wheat were deemed
inferior ... to
those of open fern
lands; ...

Author: RIDGWAY
Quote: [New comers] are puzzled by what is said about fern-lands and bush-lands.
Notes: 1859 Sep 6 J.C. Firth in 1860 Ridgway Voices from Auckland 66-67

Quote:
...we dashed off to
South Africa, and
later to Europe and
the Middle East. We
went variously as
Fernlanders,
Maorilanders and En
Zedders, and the
grim experiences of
1915 added Diggers
and Anzacs to the
list.

Source: Rugby Players Who Have Made NZ Famous
Author: STONE
Quote:
By defeating the
Fernlanders the
Springboks were
justly proud in
having gained for
their country the
Rugby supremacy.

Author: FRASER & GIBBONS
Quote: FERNLEAVES, THE: A familiar term for the New Zealanders. (From the New Zealand badge).

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: [The] following [was] employed by those who served in the [Great] War ... mad money, return fare, it being very generally believed by the New Zealand troops (Fernleaves or, as they preferred to call themselves, Diggers) that every English girl infallibly carried her return fare in case her soldier friend became mad, i.e., acted with excessive freedom of manner;
Notes: 1935 Mitchell and Strong in Partridge Slang Today 285

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Fernleaves. New Zealanders; esp. N.Z. soldiers: military coll: 1915. F. & Gibbons. Ex the badge of the N.Z. soldiers.

Author: BAKER
Quote: New Zealanders were Fernleaves and Kiwis [to Australians].

Author: SOLJAK
Quote:
The kiwi, like the
fernleaf, is now a
New Zealand national
emblem and provided
the name by which
Dominion servicemen
were popularly known
during the war. (The
term `Anzac'
correctly applies to
veterans of World
War I.)
Appropriately
enough, the nickname
`kiwi' has also been
applied to grounded
airmen throughout
the Allied air
forces.

Author: PUGSLEY
Quote: Indeed it was as New Zealanders that other nationalities identified us [in WW1], not as `Otago' or the `Canterbury boys' but as `Fernleaves' or `New Zealanders' and it made sense to do so ourselves. ... [fn] `Fernleaf' and `Fernleaves' - the slang term for New Zealanders. `Kiwi' was not used. According to Brophy and Partridge in The Long Trail, Kiwi meant a ground-duty air force man. A `Kiwi King' was any officer fussy about spit and polish, derived from the brand of Kiwi shoe polish.

Author: McGILL
Quote: Fernleaf New Zealander, from the badge worn by WWI soldiers; replaced by `Kiwi'.

Call them
"Cornstalks" or
"Fernleaves" - all
out for a fight -
But don't call them
Anzacs for that
isn't right.

With these words,
Wiri Fernleaf
executed a few steps
of the Highland
fling on the
duck-walk.

First Fernleaf:... I
had a lot of trouble
getting mine [sc.
riding breeches] off
a dead Ossie on
Gallipoli.

It lay just off the
cross-roads - the
little Fernleaf
Cemetery.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote: `Righto, start up!' Onward, men of the Second New Zealand Expeditionary Force; onward, as our fernleaf badges say, on against the foe; ...

When Miss Jessie
Pope met the men of
the Fernleaf Forces,
their good fortune
was not exclusively
hers.

What strikes me most
about the Fernleaf
crowd is their
beautiful humility
respecting the
merits of their own
country.
A patuaruhe, or fernroot beater, made of maire (Santalum cunninghamii), another strictly Northern Island tree.

This Fernrooter's
off to the front.

Our troops were
actually known as
'the Ferns'. Even at
Gallipoli, they
weren't known as the
Kiwis, but the
Ferns. There is a
military tradition
for the fern.

[Hdg] Fantastic
ferns set for world
thriller.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
They wore what were
known as ferntights,
boots which, instead
of the ordinary
hobnails, has bush
sprigs.

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
A bushman always
wore a special type
of boot known as
`ferntights', named
because the upper
part of the boot was
sewn inside the
lower leather,
preventing sharp
stakes from
penetrating the seam
and tearing the
stitching.
Round-headed
hobnails were
replaced with with
square-headed
`bushman's sprigs'.
... It was essential
... to have a good
firm footing and
`bushman's sprigs'
helped to prevent us
losing our foothold
on a slippery bank.

Calm
Rotoru[u-acute]a's
ferny strand./

The going in most
parts was fairly
difficult, the

undergrowth.

Fescue tussock.

Wintered on rough

When he's got a few

The final death

Two streets away

the classic
galvanised iron and

They held a

lid to shelter
Sidgy's face.

At No 14, a scruffy

hut.

Today there's a
scattering of
weatherboard-and-Fibrolite
