One [photo] is of a
very Kiwi-looking
girl and boy
(clothes,
hairstyles) in front
of a fibrolite bach.

My Piha is focussed
on a humble little
one-room fibrolite
bach with a longdrop
in the bush at the
back.

Morrison ushers us
into primly-mowed
backyards, time-worn

fibrolite baches and
silver service
tea-rooms - the land
that cappucino
culture forgot.

Gordon McLauchlan
has called it the
only fibrolite
literary memorial in
the world: the
humble book-crammed
bach.. where writer
Frank Sargeson held
court for 50 years.

Author: GEE
Quote:

Apple and Pear
Marketing Board.

Bill Schmidt, the

Elvis Presley.

One [photo] is of a

The lushnes of so

Author: IRELAND

That tiny fibrolite

He loved our
fibrolite, our
vertical lawn, our

A terrible crackling

That [the bach]

Forty sheets of grey

Twenty-five lengths

Author: AYSON
Quote:
Boiling down works
had also been
started at Green
Island. Merinos were
boiled down for
their fat and pelts
: and as the hind
legs of merinos
contained no fat
they were given
away. Jock Graham
did a roaring trade
in Dunedin by
purchasing carrots
in the Taieri and
tying three of them
to a hind leg of a
sheep. This was
known as a fiddle
and he would hawk
them through the
streets and dispose
of them for
sixpence.

Car dealers have a
collection of jargon
they use on the
yard, so if you are
thinking of taking
up selling cars as a
career, there are a
few terms you should
know. ... If you
would like a car
with a radio, ask if
it has a `harp' or a
`fiddle.'

[of crosscutters]
... his mate
`fiddled' the
remaining wood -
that is, sawed it
single-handed.

logs using a
singlehanded saw;
syn. BOB.

Fiddleback A rippled
grain pattern which

and gives a piece of

fiddleback, fiddler
beetle variety of

Head', was caught

Author: PICKERING

More palatable are the young fiddleheads of many species, especially the hen and chickens fern, kiokio (Blechnum novae-zealandiae), gully fern (Pneumatopteris pennigera, shining spleenwort (Asplenium oblongifolium) and the shield ferns (Polystichum richardii and P/vestitum).

Other vegetables
already appearing on
restaurant plates
are lightly steamed
fiddle-heads, or
young green shoots
of the hen and
chickens fern
(Asplenium
bulbiferum) and the
native spinach.

Fiddler, Trygonorrhina fasciata.

This is commonly called `fiddling', and a good fiddler can save a lot of waste ...

So I hopped over his

...[p. 212] ...Peter

fiddley ... n. (Sl.)

Author: MALFROY
Quote: OPERATION COSTS. ... MANUFACTURE :- 1. Sawmill - (a.) Fiddling or crosscutting logs at mill ... Ibid. 31 [sawmillers'] It is the usual practice in this country to send logs to the mill in their full length, and have the cross cutting into merchantable length done at the mill skids. This is commonly called `fiddling', and a good fiddler can save a lot of waste ... Ibid. 38 Fiddling .. The operation of crosscutting by one man, usually done at the mill-skids.

When the loco
arrives at the bull
skids, the logs are
hauled off by two
winches, cut to the
required length by
the fiddling saw,
then kicked to the
Pacific bench which
does the "breaking
down".

Quote:
Remember asking a

on the double for

Lifestyle farmers

Author: McLINTOCK

The field mouse of
England is a vole,
not a true mouse,
but here the common
house mouse is
called a field mouse
when it occurs out
of doors. So also
any rat occurring in
streams is called a
water rat but the
English water rat is
a vole, not a true
rat.

field tile n. N.Z.
an earthenware drain
used in farm
drainage.

Mr. Field (Otaki)
asked the Minister
of Railways, Whether
the practice of
taking off at
Paekakariki the only
comfortable
first-class carriage
attached to the
train known as
"Field's express"
leaving Thorndon at
5.55 p.m. .. may be
discontinued.

With his father, a
civil engineer, he
[William Hughes
Field] made the
original exploration
of "Field's Track"
between Wanganui and
the Karioi plains.

Long after those of us who knew him personally have passed away, [his name] will be known to a much wider section of the public - to travellers between Palmerston North and the Capital city -because of "Field's Express." Ibid 87 I can recall the fight he put up for the train we now refer to as "Field's Express."

To Mr. Field was due
an improvement of
the railway service
between Palmerston
North and
Wellington, "Field's
Express" being named
after him.

Author: HOY
Quote:
The former service
comprises a Friday
night train to
Palmerston North,
stopping at most
stations including
those within the
suburban area. The
latter is a morning
and evening return
train from
Wellington on
Sunday. These three
trains are all that
is left of a
twice-daily service
which served the
district from 1923
to 1958, and which
was known as the
Field's Express
after the Member of
Parliament for Otaki
(Mr. Field) who
campaigned for their
introduction.

Author: HOY
Quote:
W.H. Field, M.P.
Field's Express may
have been named for
him; his brother who
served before him as
M.P. for Otaki,
referred to him as
Willie.

There were only six

THE FIELDAYS might
seem an odd choice
of venue for sales
staff from an
ivestment fund, but
on reflection it is
appropriate.

Fieldays, held
yearly at Mystery
Creek near Hamilton,
is New Zealand's

the latest in
agricultural
products and
services and
bringing buyers and
sellers together to
create an
agricultural
hypermarket.

Home of the National
Horticultural
Fieldays
Notes: also seen in television advertising for this event

The unashamed
purpose for being at

Hard Sell - this
year over 500
companies exhibited
at the Fieldays. An
estimated $20
million is spent in

and accommodation
during Fieldays
week.

Sales at this year's

Fieldays topped a

Fieldays general

said the figure was
$16.1 million or
33.5% higher than
the previous year.

I would like to
congratulate
Fieldays for
choosing Landcare as
the theme for 2002.

One of the
earlybirds.. has

Fieldays since
1986... At the
Fieldays, interest
has been steady from

year a boom in the
diary industry meant
farmers came to town
to spend and there

Fieldays is also
attracting interest
from overseas.

Though there is no

[i.e. bookmakers]
from adopting such
pointing tactics,
the clubs could
easily put a stop to
it by refusing to

when they apply the

Wellington's medical

was nicknamed
slapcheeks because

been slapped around

be called fifth

FIFTHS Monies paid
by the Forest
service to County
Councils for the
express purpose of
maintaining roads on
which round or sawn
timber is hauled.
The amount is
generally one fifth
of the royalty value
of the timber.

Quote: Even Shirty Williams the 'Fifty-oner forgot his ulcers and managed a smile. Ibid. 70 `It wasn't a strike [in 1951 in the waterfront] then?' I asked. `No. She was a lock-out, Henry. We had a disagreement with the bosses and told 'em only work a forty-hour week till she was settled. The bosses said: `Right ho, go on penalty the whole perishing lot or you - and stay on penalty.' `Then the 'Fifty-oners moved in and took our jobs. Rotten cow.'

`I got six figs for
that load of

Americanism that had

substandard tobacco
supplied by the
companies. Nobody
spoke of a packet of
tobacco - it was
always a fig.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: ...the natives came running, and exclaimed, Ka puta te taua, that is, the fight is in sight, or those for that purpose. Ibid. 205 Went to Kororarika to see the Chiefs about the fight. ... [ed fn] `The fight' is a translation of taua much used by the missionaries and early settlers. Both the Maori word and the translation mean a `war party' and are used whether the `fight' is a mere local skirmish or a full-scale tribal war.

[=taua[????]] this

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: Fam. Plectognathi. - The Pakirikiri, (balistes,) file fish, is distinguished by two strong spines at the commencement of the dorsal fin, in shape like the letter V, both fronting the head, and standing out from the fin, these are elevated at pleasure, some fish have only one. The Pakirikiri is abundant in the Bay of Islands.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: File Fish Name given in New Zealand to the Monacanthus rudis, Richards, family Sclerodermi; in New South Wales to species of the genus Balistes. The first of the spines of the dorsal fin is roughened in front like a file. Balistes maculatus is the `Spotted File-fish' of Sydney. It is closely allied to the genus Monacanthus, called Leather-jacket (q.v.), which is much more numerously represented in Australasia.
Cantherines scaber (Forster). Leather-jacket (trigger-fish, file-fish).

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: ROUGH LEATHER JACKET, TRIGGER-FISH or FILE-FISH (KOKIRI) Parika scaber (Bloch and Schneider) ... This interesting fish has a number of other vernacular names, such as File-fish, and all with a bearing on its construction. The name Leather-Jacket is due to the fancied resemblance to a North American lumber jacket, not unlike the dark brown coloured jumpers used by hikers. The word rough is attached to the name Leather Jacket by fishermen, because the scales are furnished with sharp points which make the skin so rough that one's fingers cannot be rubbed freely in a direction from tail to head without losing part of one's skin, hence the name File-fish.

Author: DOOGUE & MORELAND
Quote: ROUGH LEATHERJACKET ... Other names: Novodon convexirostris; triggerfish and filefish are used, but should rightly be given to a family of tropical fishes of similar appearance to our leatherjackets; kokiri (Maori).
file fish n. New Zealand fish, like the leather-jacket.

Author: MORELAND
Quote: LEATHERJACKET [Navodon scaber] ... The names filefish and triggerfish are sometimes used, but more properly belong to a related group of tropical fishes. The Maori name kokiri is still in use.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: LEATHERJACKET (a) Scientific name: Navodon scaber. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Creamfish (fillets); Leatherjacket. (c) Other common names: Triggerfish; Filefish. (d) Principal localities where taken: Auckland, Tauranga, Tasman Bay.

Author: WILSON
Quote: FILE-FISH: see Leatherjacket

A few, like species of the filmy fern Trichomanes, consist of branching filaments and more closely resemble a fuzz of green algae than a fern gametophyte.

Only the alpine shield fern (Polystichum cystostegia), bladder fern (Cystopteris tasmanica), mountain kiokio (Blechnum montanum), thousand-leaved fern (Hypolepis millefolium), finger ferns (Grammitis poeppigiana and G. givenii), one filmy fern (Hymenophyllum villosum) and two clubmosses (Huperzia australiana and Lycopodium fastigiatum) are found primarily in this habitat

With the true whales

it has the following

Whalers often speak

it had the following

RORQUALUS (Sp.,) Trigger-fin, Razor-back, Sulphur- bottom (to be distinguished from the Finner, which is properly the B. Marginata .)

The blue whale ( Balaenoptera musculus ) is the first of the four species or rorquals, or finners, to be mentioned. It is the largest species of whale, and, indeed, of all animals, living and extinct. ... The common finner ( Balaenoptera physalis ) may be thus defined: Dorsal fin triangular, low, at commencement of last fourth of body; ...

Author: MONRO
Quote: The animal [sc. finback whale] has been named by Cuvier the Rorqualus Australis, or in English, the Rorqual of the Southern Seas. It is very little known to zoologists; and it is only within a few years that its existence has been ascertained by the scientific. The Rorqual of the Northern Seas, it will be recollected, is the largest creature in existence, attaining sometimes to a length of 120 feet, with a circumference of 40.
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 248

Quote: The blue whale ( Balaenoptera musculus ) is the first of the four species or rorquals, or finners, to be mentioned. It is the largest species of whale, and, indeed, of all animals, living and extinct.

Quote: Rorqual species - A furrowed whale with rows of long corrugations or folds in the skin of its throat and chest.

Finger ferns (species of Grammitis, hanging spleenwort, sickle spleenwort (Asplenium polyodon), lance fern (Anarthropteris lanceolata) and fork ferns (species of Tmesipteris) are also common on tree-fern trunks or hanging from the branches of forest trees.
Asexual reproduction is not confined to the sporophyte generation. Gemmae are also formed on the gametophytes of several ferns (Grammitis species) or some filmy ferns (Trichomanes species).

Only the alpine shield fern (Polystichum cystostegia), bladder fern (Cystopteris tasmanica), mountain kiokio (Blechnum montanum), thousand-leaved fern (Hypolepis millefolium), finger ferns (Grammitis poeppigiana and G. givenii), one filmy fern (Hymenophyllum villosum) and two clubmosses (Huperzia australiana and Lycopodium fastigiatum) are found primarily in this habitat

Author: CROOKES

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Knucklebones (K-34)
was played in both
Europe and
Polynesia,
independently at
first. In the
nineteenth century
distinct European
[177] and Maori
versions were known.
More recently, the
two types have
merged, and today
the Maori children,
who are mainly
responsible for
perpetuating the
game in New Zealand,
include in their
games movements
borrowed from the
European tradition.
... In most of the
provinces the game
was known as
Knucklebones, and it
is widely reported
as having been
played by New
Zealand children of
European origin
until about 1900.
Occasionally it was
known as Chucks,
Chuckstones,
Chuckystones,
Fingerstones,
Hucklebones, Jacks,
Jackstones,
Knuckles, or
Knucklestones.
Children still
played it here and
there throughout the
country in 1949, but
they knew little
about it until
plastic knuckles
were imported in
1954 in large
quantities and
revived the game.

I find that the
drowned trees had
probably come from
what the
Fiordlanders call a
tree avalanche.
Because Fiordland
was so thoroughly
gouged by glaciers,
there is virtually
no topsoil on the
steeper valley
sides. Even the
fully-grown forest
has only the
precarious hold of a
woven skin of roots
that stretch over
rock. This net has a
weak grip and if one
section tears free
it can peel the
forest from the
cliff-faces in great
strips. The fall of
just one tree can
trigger a tree
avalanche.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Fire in the fern for
trouble or
smouldering
discontent. The
expression to spread
like fire in the
fern, used of a
rumour and even of
an epidemic, is
useful as well as
alliterative.
Dealing with the
Maori Wars in the
Sydney Telegraph as
recently as
February, 1940, a
writer says: `The
fire in the fern has
now gone out.
Justice is being
done to the Maori',
which reveals that
in Australia the
phrase is linked
with New Zealand.

Quote:

smouldering

generally applied to
the Maori wars and
their aftermath

fire-in-the-fern n.
Maori wars, put down
in one place, only
to break out in
another; any
smouldering
discontent,
particularly
industrial.

The Maori had a
phrase to describe
the kind of guerilla
war they practised
so successfully
against the British
and colonist armies
here last century,
talking of "a fire
in the fern".

When the "fire in

Constabulary was
quartered in
Hamilton.

Author: ANGAS
Quote:
[South Island Kiwi]
Like many of the New
Zealand birds the
apteryx is nocturnal
in its habits,
dwelling beneath
extensive beds of
fern, where it
conceals itself
during the day. The
largest species, the
`fireman' of the
whalers, is from the
Middle Island, and
is considerably
larger than the
other two.

Most of the birds,
including kiwis, are
recognisable from
the descriptions [of
the Foveaux Strait
sealers], except one
- a large bird they
called the
`Fireman', because
it made a noise like
the wooden rattles
which firemen of
those days carried
to give the alarm.

Alvin's letter to Chaff (Alvin being the Massey student who wrote "firetrucks are cool"), was not as harmless as it appeared. "Your 'happy' letter writer Alvin was not referring to the big red firetrucks one sees driving round town," she wrote. "Firetrucking", male student style, is the practice.. of getting so hideously mullocked that control of the bladder is lost. A wet patch on the front and legs of the trousers ensues. This is the signal that a firetruck has occurred."
fire ... fire'-weed n. several plants that spring up after forest has been burnt off.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL

Fireweed: Celmisia spectabilis. One of the few plants which shepherds can always identify. Sometimes called fire weed, as it flourishes after burns.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: FLEABANE (Erigeron canadensis), also called Canadian fleabane, woolly cobbler's peg and, mistakenly, fire weed, is abundant throughout the North Island, and is found in waste ground and dry pastures.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: WILLOW WEED (Epilobium sp[p].). - This is also called herb willow, swamp willow, and by confusion redshank and fireweed. It is a native that occasionally grows as a weed in or near ditches. The name is sometimes given to redshank [59], and it is true that both polygonum and epilobium grow in damp places, have willow-like leaves and are about 2 feet high.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: Another fire weed that thrived prodigiously on newly-burnt land was mouse-ear chickweed (Cerastium glomeratum).
Australian fireweed [s] Erechtites atkinsoniae F.v. Muell.

Author: TAYLOR

Quote:

Author: BRUNO
Quote:
Certain near-sober
First Echelon
wife-beaters and
debt-dodgers.

But the most common
name for the first
group of New Zealand
soldiers to see
active service in
the Middle East
during the Second
World War is the
First Echelon ...
Soon after New
Zealand declared war
on Germany on
September 3, 1939, a
call went out for
volunteers for a
special force
comprising a wide
range of army units.
The use of the
military term
`Echelon' in the
sense of first,
second or third
echelon has puzzled
many people. It
refers to the
position of an army
in the form of steps
or parallel lines,
each line being a
little to the left
or right of the
preceding one.
However, the name
was given because
the main groups of
New Zealanders sent
overseas in previous
wars had been called
contingents.

Author: Ihimaera
Quote:
On 29 November 1940,
we were ordered to
the Middle East to
join the First
Echelon.

Quote: For impatient young men, anxious to be `in the first of the rush', and for those weakened by privation, every West Coast river was a likely grave. Ibid. 528 `THE FIRST OF THE RUSH': the phrase is self-explanatory. Some deference was due to those `in the first of the rush'.

[heading] The First
of Waimea and
Kumara.

The last remarks
contained in the
report with regard
to the want of easy
access to the back
country, and the
consequent unfair
pressure of the
difficulties upon
the first settler
who endeavours to
open up the country,
are perfectly just,
and the remedy
proposed is
certainly a
practicable one; the
only difficulty is
the providing of
funds, but the work
ought to be done.

Mr. Duke entered the
Wararapa [sic] last
week with about
forty head of
cattle. Mr. Duke is
the first settler in
that fine district.

Wednesday last being
the 22nd Anniversary
of the arrival of
the first settlers
in Port Nicholson,
was observed as a
general holiday; and
the Government
Offices, Banks and
other places of
business were
closed.

The honourable
member for Wairarapa
(Mr Bunny) had
stated that the
reason Wellington
had not advanced as
rapidly as the other
Provinces was
because there were
too many educated
men among its early
settlers, and that
these men either
could not or would
not work. Now he (Mr
Buckland) had
resided in
Wellington for some
months immediately
after the arrival of
its first settlers,
and his impression
was that there was a
willingness and
desire to work among
all classes .

LAKES WANAKA AND
HAWEA .. The first
settler who made his
habited [sic] in
this terra incognita
was the late Mr
Henry Norman, who
came, here as the
manager of a station
for a Wellington
firm of squatters in

Now that there is a
town of 1000 or more
inhabitants within a
few miles of the
Knapdale homestead,
a railway within
three or four miles,
and good roads all
round the estate, it
is not easy to
imagine the
difficulties and
dangers that its
first settler had to
undergo - no
neighbour for miles;
no practising doctor
for 100 miles, no
help or comfort in
any way whatever.

Then came the first
settlers, men of
energy and strong of
heart, who rushed
their way through
many difficulties.

In the first shear
ewes the best lines
sold at $25-$28.

The best of the
first-shear ewes
sold at $24-$28.
[first shear]

[marble] terms from

[sic, ?funking],

Quote:
Action terms which
refer to the
shooting of the
marbles are: Knuckle
down Stiff, Knee
High, Funks [Flunks
sic] or Funnicks,
Slips, Firsts and
Lasts and Forces.
... The term
`Knuckle down Stiff'
(Taranaki [18]80,
Gisborne [18]85,
Waitara [18]95) is
mentioned by [Lady
A.B. Gomme Vo. 1,
p.113]. ... As
Taranaki [18]80
says, `The term was
called out in order
to prevent too easy
a success against a
marble near the
ring'. It was less
advantageous to fire
with the hand on the
ground than with the
hand elevated,
perhaps at `Knee
High'.

Like guarding the
fisc, resource
management is a
proper activity for
government.

"Fiscal bikies" was
what former prime
minister David Lange
called them when the
vice-chancellors
cornered him in the
1980s complaining
that they could not
increase enrolments
while also accepting
reduced budgets.

Such is the
opposition to the
proposals, some
believe the issue
could be more heated
than the "fiscal
envelope" hui of the
mid-1990s, the last
time Maori and the
Crown met head on...
The fiscal envelope
was the term given
to the then-National
Government's plan to
limit Treaty
settlements. It was
eventually dumped.

To Smith it was
simply a classic
piece of radical
publicity seeking,
designed to focus
debate on the
government's
now-famous "fiscal
envelope". which
would settle all
Treaty claims for $1
billion in 10 years.
The fiscal envelope is like Selwyn Toogood's old quiz show, except it's called 'Money and the Bag.'

Maori expectations
of big financial
settlements soon
rose so rapidly that
Jim Bolger's
ministry introduced
the "fiscal
envelope", limiting
them to $1 billion.

The Maori leaders at
those huis in the
early 1990s conveyed
to Parliament such
strong messages as
their opposition to
the billion-dollar
fiscal envelope.

Cabinet papers
obtained by The
Evening Post confirm
that settlement
payments are going
to blow out well
beyond the $1
billion cap - the
so-called fiscal
envelope - that the
former National
Government imposed
in 1994.

Moutoa might still
never have happened
without the
galvanising spark of
the fiscal envelope.

The Fiscal Envelope,
what a lot of hooey!

Bluntly, the fiscal
envelope is a power
struggle over who
will control New
Zealkand's
resources.

Officially, the
fiscal envelope -
that sought to place
a billion-dollar cap
on Treaty
settlements - is
dead.... Yet the
rest of the
agreement suggests
that, although the
dread words "fiscal
envelope" may no
longer be utttered
in decent company,
the underlying
process is really
still alive and
kicking.

Author: BELL
Quote:
If the fishing is to
be carried on by a
shore party, the try
pots and huts are
erected on the beach
... The boats are
sent out at daylight
every morning, and
when ... they kill a
fish it is towed
ashore and flinched
and boiled upon the
beach.
Notes: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 9

Author: POLACK
Quote:
Tales of which [the
whale] is the hero
are ...
significantly termed
`fish stories.'

Source: Narrative of a Residence in  Various Parts of NZ
Author: HEAPHY
Quote:
While [the whalers']
boats would be off
the heads of the
harbour,

there.

strong as to draw in
the `fish' as they

Author: MOORE
Quote:
[Caption] The
fish-and-chip
brigade at the wake
after David Lange's
abortive leadership
challenge.

The final defeat of
the "fish and chip
brigade" has the
potential to unlock
a huge chunk of the
electorate
previously hostile
to the Moore-led
Labour Party.

The plotters,
including Mr Lange,
became known as the
"fish and chip
brigade" - a
newspaper photo
after the failed
putsch having shown
them eating a meal
of fish and chips.

I also believe that
the fish-and-chip
brigade were being
groomed, flattered
and cooerced by big
business entities,
from here and the
US, who saw
opportunities and
took advantage.

Mr Prebble is the
last parliamentary
survivor of the
so-called fish and
chip brigade, named
after a 1980
newspaper photo in
which, oddly, Mr
Prebble himself did
not appear. It
instad showed then
Labour MPs David
Lange, Mike Moore,
Roger Douglas and
Michael Bassett
eating fish and
chips at Parliament.

Mr Prebble's name
has for years been
associated with the
so-called fish and
chip brigade - the
group of young
Labour idealists who
plotted to overthrow
party leader Bill
Rowling and later
formed the backbone
of the Lange
Cabinet.

So the last of the
fish and chip
brigade is about to
take his salt and
vinegar and go.

The shop achieved a
name for being the
haunt of the "fish
and chip brigade",
the Labour plotters
of Roger Douglas,
Mike Moore, Michael
Bassett and David
Lange.

Ironically, those
[he] saw as Mr
Lange's "enemies"
were not the foes on
the Opposition
benches, but
erstwhile friends
and colleagues:
Roger Douglas and
Richard Prebble;
stalwarts of the
fish and chip
brigade that
engineered Mr
Lange's rise to the
leadership of Labour
inside five years of
his arrival in
Parliament.

This is the place
David Lange, Mike
Moore, Richard
Prebble and Roger
Douglas made famous
when the fish and
chip brigade, as
they were called,
could still sit
around a Cabinet or
dining table without
gagging.

He was an outrider
with the
"fish'n'chip gang",
the coterie around
Roger Douglas and
Richard Prebble.

History tells us
that Labour people
never eat
fish'n'chips
together during a
time of low-polling
without some
ulterior motive.
Other terms for places and procedures include.. work parade which refers to the ordered positions in which inmates line up before starting work in the morning.

The example of ships
fishing on this
coast proves there
is no material
difference in time.
Notes: 1802 May 21 Lieut.-Gov. King Queries to Whalers in 1908 McNab Hist Records 1/234

Author: McNAB
Quote:

Europeans call the
[Horoeka] the

Author: ANGAS
Quote: The Aralia crassifolia or fish bone tree is a curious object in the New Zealand woods. It runs up with a slender stem to thirty feet, having tufts of leaves thrown out near the top, which are about a foot in length and an inch in breadth, of a thick, coriaceous texture, irregularly jagged at the edges and abrupt at the end.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
Mr. T. Hunt, who has
lived on Pitt Island
for more than thirty

states that the
Zosterops (to which

Mr. R.W. Kerr.. knew

Chathams, where they

It is the `Fish-guts
plant' of the

[Chenopodium detestans]

(The fish-heads at
New Zealand Table
Tennis would later
ban track pants from
comptition, which
made a lot of sense
for games played in
cold stadiums at
nine in the morning
in mid-winter.)

I don't want to be

but it's a message
to the fish heads
[officials] that sit
in the offices and
make all the rules
up - they better
clean up their act
because the game of
rugby needs a clean
image.

It was one long
apology to the
fish-heads and then,
almost as an
afterthought, to the
players and the
public.

Author: R.GILBERD
Quote:
I have heard
`fish-head' used
only in the Army and
on Public Works. It
refers to those
several steps above
the speaker in rank.
... the glazed eye.
One's immediate
superior may be
quite intelligent
and not a bad fellow
but, everyone knows,
the man above him is
always a damn fool.

There was also
little interaction
last year between
the All Blacks and
the Rugby Union -
fish heads - as the
players
disparagingly call
them.

"You can't even do a
fish hook, now!"...
A fish hook? "Finger
in his mouth,
ripping at the
cheek."

[Hdg] First-home
fishhooks seen.
There are fishhooks
in Government ideas
about helping low
income families into
their first homes,
say emergency
accomodation
workers.

The answer seems
obvious but there
were fish-hooks. At
the time, Japan had
so many of these
late-model used cars
that they were an
embarrassment.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
fish hooks
difficulties; eg
`Any fish hooks in
the report?'

[Hdg] Fishhooks in
radio waves. The
government's
decision to allocate
a quarter of the
hi-tech radio
spectrum to a
pan-Maori trust is
full of fishhooks.

Similarly, if
employers choose to
regard every
conceivable
fish-hook in the new
law with paranoid
timidity, the
chances of
industrial harmony
are very slim
indeed.

And I'm not saying
that because I
have.. worked as a
fish-kicker in white
overalls unloading
the fishing boats at
the docks.

Hunterville
`fish-ohs' have been
notified that owing
to the oppressive
labor[sic] laws the
price of fish has
been raised-round
fish fish a farthing
per pound, and flat
fish a half-penny.

This most recent
experiment in
overfishing, called
a "fishdown" in the
trade, removed 110
tonnes of probably
ancient paua over
two years along this
formerly virgin
coast.

The following
fishers are in
Cloudy Bay:- The
Dragon, full;
Courier, 300 barrels
William Stoveld, 300
barrels of black
oil, and 400 of
sperm; ... Mossman's
shore whaling gangs
have secured 170
barrels.
Notes: 1831 July 27 Letter from Cloudy Bay in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 14

Quote:
North facing to
capture the all day
sun, this is an
ideal location for
the keen fisherfolk
as the property has
riparian rights, its
own boatshed and
ramp.

The net ... was
lying along the
starboard rail, with
the exception of the
`cod', or purse,
which was suspended
from a gaff. This is
facetiously termed
the `fisherman's
flag' or colours.

The black whale

John Jones, of

Zealand oil trade.
Most of the

thereabouts are

and he is the
principal purchaser

oil caught along the

...when you get a

Quote: The Tauwharenikau block purchase as well as Tuhitarata, was completed with the aid of a provision peculiar to the Wairarapa, the requirement that five per cent of the subsequent return from land sales should be paid back to the Maori vendors.Ibid. 204 More culpable was the with-holding of moneys from the five per cents... Some members of Government expected that the mill would be erected from the 'five per cents' the proceeds from sales in certain designated blocks, for which.. the construction of flour mills was an explicit objective.

References made in
the claim still
considered valid
were guarantees and

Ngati Kahungungu
under what was known

Cent" clauses and

Author: SLATTER
Quote: This land where Rugby is a religion and a race track a shrine and the five to six rush Communal Living. Ibid. 90 The bar is crowded for the five to six rush is in full swing.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: CATCHFLY (silene [gallica]). Varieties of this species have been named S.anglica and S.quinquevulnera. [1967 quinquevulnera] Commons names are spotted catchfly, flycatcher, sticky weed, and five wounds. It is common in cultivated land and waste places such as gravelly river-beds throughout both islands. ... The flowers are white or often dark red, or sometimes white with a blood red blotch on each petal so that this variety is called quinque vulnera, `five wounds'.

Quote:
`Instant sheds,

New Zealand has..

The backs, as played

Full-back.. the
Five-eighth, who

Author: QUINN
Quote:
Five-eighths. A
positional term used
almost exclusively
in New Zealand;
other countries used
'stand-off',
'fly-half', or
'outside half'. It
originated with the
1903 New Zealand
captain, Jimmy
Duncan.

Kiernan.. was weak
at five-eighths.

There was nothing
startling about the
play of the
five-eighths, but
Church was on the
slow side as half.

Author: ELLISON
Quote:
A five-eighths can
be a frightful
nuisance to the
opposite side by
constantly changing
his game.

Author: BARR
Quote: The TEAMS. Britain. - Full back ...; three-quarters - Gibbs, Ponty Jones, Chapman; half backs, Davey and W. Major; ... Otago. - Full back ...; three-quarters - Dwyer, Bennet, O'Sullivan; five-eighths, McLeod and Dansey; half back, Eckhold; Ibid. 165 The two half back system, which was afterwards to develop into the now well-known five-eighths, prevailed very largely about 1880 ...

[It is stated that
in 1889 Alhambra
came from Dunedin to
play Merivale and
played only one
half-back instead of
two. The man who
would have been the
second half-back
`stood between [the
half-back] and the
three-quarters
line.' The Club had
no name for the new
position, and some
discussion took
place about it. The
argument was ended
when a Merivale
player said that if
the new position was
between half and
three-quarters, he
must be
five-eighths. The
name was adopted.]

Author: SLATTER
Quote: see WIPER KICK Ibid. 172 Woodened out the five-eighths with a straight arm tackle.

five-eighth n.
Austral. & N.Z. a
rugby player
positioned between
the half-backs and
three-quarters.

Source: Rugby Players Who Have Made NZ Famous
Author: STONE
Quote:
James Duncan, of
Otago,.. instituted

system in New
Zealand.

Author: PALENSKI
Quote:
The pivot for most
of Alhambra's
attacks [sc. in a
game in Dunedin
between Kaikorai and
Alhambra in 1890]
was the extra player
between the halfback
and the
three-quarter line.
After the game
players from both
sides sat around
discussing tactics
and a Merivale back,
one F. Childs, is
credited with coming
up with the new
name, five-eighths.
A blacksmith, Childs
obviously thought
logically. If the
player was not a
half and was not a
threequarter, he
said, he was between
the two and
therefore must be a
five-eighth.

One of our
well-known members
Fred Childs gave the
player between the
halfback and
three-quarter back
the name of
five-eighth which
has been adopted
throughout New
Zealand ever since.
Notes: Fred Childs, blacksmith of Makikihi, b. about 1865. No other information

Author: HENDRY
Quote:
He wasn't a half and

so someone said he

be how this position

five-eighths Phelan,

Quote:

[Caption] Five
finger, ngaio,
cabbage trees,
wineberry and
pittosporums were
among the species
planted.

And seeds from five
finger and seven
finger plants
(plants with leaves
that have fivce or
seven lobes), have
high levels of oleic
acid which is also
an important
component of high
temperature cooking
oils such as
sunflower oil.
Even some of the rarest of the rare [plants] are coming back such as raukawa Raukaua edgerlyi, a relation of five finger.

Less exciting were
frequent sightings
of ghostly trunks of
Five Finger, puriri
and pohutukawa,
naked of their
leaves, showing
where possums had
been partying.

Source: Tararua : the Story of a Mountain Range

Frequently the

profitable to run a
limited number of
cattle among the
sheep. They clean up
this rough 'flag',
break through bushy
and rushy obstacles
and thus purify the
pasture for the
sheep.

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: FLANNEL LEAF (Verbascum thapsus) is commonly called mullein in England, and is frequently so called here as well. Its commonest local name is probably tobacco plant, or native tobacco, a name for which there is no justification in either appearance or use. Velvet mullein, woolly mullein, golden rod, and Aaron's rod are other appellations, but flannel leaf, one of the common sheep-station names is both descriptive and distinctive. The plant is found in dry soil and river beds ... in both islands.

VERBASCUM THAPSUS, a

has many popular
names. In New
Zealand it is called
native tobacco,
velvet, flannel leaf

Author: MARTIN
Quote: A little lower down where the seaweeds are permanently submerged we have such plants as the GRAPELET, the WIRE- WEED, and OX-TONGUE; the FLAP-JACK and GIRDLE WEEDS. In rather deeper water ... we have the (Lessonia) and the OARWEED, the GRAPEWEED, and numerous representatives of the red algae. Ibid./ Flora 14 The commonest of the four species is (C[arpophyllum] maschalocarpum) which has been designated by the apt and appropriate name of FLAP-JACK from the habit of the plant in swaying first in one direction and then the other as the water enters or recedes from the surge channels between tidal rocks.

Author: HARGREAVES

The [Governor

Debentures,
popularly known as
`government rags',
were given various
nicknames such as
assignats,
`shinplasters', and
`flash notes'. All
these terms had
reference to
worthless paper
money, some of which
had been issued in
the past. Assignats
was the name given
to large amounts of
paper money issued
in France during the
French Revolution,
but which
depreciated to such
as extent to be
almost worthless.
`Shinplasters'--sometimes
written
`skinplasters'--had
its origin in North
America, and again
referred to
depreciated paper
money, while `flash
notes' was a popular
term in use for any
counterfeit money or
worthless forged
paper money.

The two main varieties of packs are the frame pack and the frameless pack, sometimes called a flat pack. The frameless pack of course receives that name only on formal occasions, being more familiarly known by that elegant term, kidney-rotter, or less frequently as kidney-buster, kidney-crusher, kidney-sweater or kidney-rider.

Bert said he was
flat tack serving
beer and she'd
better return as
soon as she could.

Author: SHADBOLT
Quote:
A gang ... threw a
bottle at the hotrod
so we screwed flat
tap into town to
round up the boys.

Author: SLATTER
Quote:
I work flat to the
boards, never even
cough till ten,
slogging me guts out
to buy luxuries for
the wife and she
goes butchers
because me home-brew
stained her posh
water set.
see Adam's Ale

Author: MILLS
Quote:
At a shed of some
sixteen stands
shearing 38,000
sheep, a long spell
of fine weather had
kept everyone 'flat
to the boards.'

When Sir Edmund
Hillary reached the
top of Mt Everest,
it's a wonder he
didn't find a bunch
of Ministry of
Commerce staff up
there enjoying an
flat white.

Flat white: this
term has two
meanings in New
Zealand. Sometimes
it means a caffe
latte served in a
cup rather than a
bowl or glass, and
sometimes it is a
latte made with
two-thirds coffee to
one-third milk.

A flat white is my
choice.

When I walked into
the Espresso
Republic at eleven
in the morning,
there was a throng
of people chugging
down lattes, flat
whites and
espressos.

Author: Ihimaera
Quote:
'And I'll have -' 'A
flat white?' I
laughed. 'Yes,' she
nodded. 'A dead
Pakeha.'

Even before they
start on their flat
whites in an
Auckland
coffee-shrine, Burte
whips out his mobile
phone to confirm a
flight to
Wellington.

He [Don Brash]
intoned, and so
lost, his main
points in his
trademark flat-flute
voice, without
variations in timing
and phrasing.

Author: DRUMMOND & HUTTON
Quote:
The warehou,
tarakihi, and gurnet
are common in the
north, and the moki,
butterfish, and
frost fish in the
south, while the
kahawai, hapuku (the
groper of Dunedin),
blue cod,
barracouta, the
little sea mullet,
sometimes called the
herring, and the
flat fish are found
all round the coast.
-

...practically no
trawling has been
done at the
Chathams, so our
knowledge of the
flat-fishes is
rather meagre.

flat fish: edible
fish.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: NEW ZEALAND LEMON SOLE Peltotretis flavilatus Waite. The Lemon Sole, like the Common Sole, Flounder, Brill and Turbot is a bottom-dwelling fish with both eyes on the upper surface of the body, known as the right side. This fish and the others mentioned are known to fishermen, auctioneers, retailers and the public generally as Flatfish. Skate and Electric-ray are also Flatfish, the upper and lower surfaces being the back and belly.

Author: WILSON
Quote:
FLATFISH ...
Inhabitants of sandy
or muddy, shallow
flats the flatfish
are also
occasionally taken
in deep water. This
is specially so of
the fairly rare
Turbot which grows
to a considerable
size and inhabits
the deeper, southern
waters.

I've always called
them `flatfish.' But
I saw a big poster
about NZ fish which
declared they were
called sole and
never mentioned
flatfish at all.

flathead ... 2 N.Z.

ugliness.

.. two `flat-heads'
they `lob.'

The factors which
have exerted the
greatest influence
on the position of
the ore-shoots are
(a) intersections -
namely `flatheads',
carbonaceous seams,
faults,
cross-courses,
dykes; (b) the

country rock; (c)
depth.

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: Notothenia coriiceps Rich. Flat-head, or Maori Chief
flathead n. common Australian edible fish, with flattened heads and bodies. See Maori-chief.
flathead n. common Australian edible fish with flattened head and body.
Kathetostoma giganteum Haast. Anderton records one specimen of this fish - the `flathead' - as taken about eight miles from Taiaroa Head ...

KATHETOSTOMA GIGANTEUM Haast. Flathead. Common, North Auckland Peninsula; but seldom utilized as a food fish. Occasionally seen in Christchurch markets. Distribution: New Zealand coasts (rarer in the extreme south).
Notes: Phillipps Notes on the Edible Fishes

Quote: Kathetostoma giganteum Haast. Flathead (Chinaman).

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Flathead Kathetostoma giganteum Haast
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 409

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: FLATHEAD Kathetostoma giganteum Haast ... Other names for the Flathead are Chinaman and Frenchman, but where these names originated and for what reason I do not know with certainty. One theory is that when Chinamen hawked fish about Dunedin they kept Flatheads for their own consumption, as they preferred them to all other fish.

Author: PARROTT
Quote: THE FLATHEAD Kathetostoma giganteum Haast. Ibid.169 Flathead Kathetostoma giganteum Puffer-fish

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: Family URANISCOPIDAE. The flathead, Kathetostoma giganteum ..., is usually found on its own, often burrowing in the sea bed with just the eyes and mouth showing. It shares this way of lifeq (and its wide heavy heady, flattened on top, eyes staring upwards) with the stargazers and catfish. Some fishermen call it chinaman.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: MONKFISH (a) Scientific name: (i) Geniagnus monopterygius (ii) Kathetostoma giganteum. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.

Author: WILSON
Quote: FLATHEAD No relation to the ubiquitous Australian flathead who comes in several forms, most of which belong to the family Platycephalus. The New Zealand flathead is a gruesome, seldom-seen fellow called Kathetostoma giganteum.

The hoki are sent
down first and are
by far the major
species caught in
this area designated
G in New Zealand's
exclusive economic
zone. But there are
also ling and school
shark, headed and
gutted before they
are boxed, squid and
silver dory, fat
blue nose and silver
warehou, hake and
sharp-toothed
southern kingfish,
ugly green monkfish
and slimy flathead,
electric skates and
others with saw
toothed snouts.

Author: PAUL
Quote: Monkfish Kathetostoma giganteum ... Also occurs in southern Australia. Known by a number of local names: giant stargazer, flathead, bulldog, boof, etc. The name monkfish is well established for this species in New Zealand, whereas overseas it is used for similarly shaped but unrelated anglerfishes.

Author: MORELAND
Quote: SPOTTED STARGAZER [Geniagnus monopterygius] ... Other names include monkfish, catfish, dogfish, and flathead.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: MONKFISH (a) Scientific name: (i) Geniagnus monopterygius (ii) Kathetostoma giganteum. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (both) Whitefish. (c) Other common names: (both) Monkfish, Monks, Stargazer, Flathead (also applied at times to export gurnard); Churchills, Toebiters, Bulldogs, Spotted Stargazer, Maori Chief (Dunedin); Muddies. (d) Principal localities where taken: Napier, Cook Strait, Nelson, Banks Peninsula, Bluff-Stewart Island. ... Monkfish is a general term for species of the Families Uranoscopidae and Leptoscopidiae.

Author: SORENSON
Quote: GURNARD (a) Scientific name: Cheilodonichthyes kumu. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: N.Z. Latchett, N.Z. Latchett Fillets; Gurnard. (c) Other common names: Flathead, Shoal or Latchett or N.Z. F.F. for the prepared state of frozen fillets for export.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Flathead ... name given to several Australian marine fishes, Platycephalus fuscus, Cuv. and Val., and other species of Platycephalus, family Cottida. The Red Flathead is P. bassensis, Cuv. and Val., and the Rock F. is P. lavig?stus, Cuv. and Val. see also Tupong and Maori-chief.]

In Wellington
extensive sheep
farming swept up the
east coast, first on
the bracken-covered
hills and tussock
and scrub flats, and
later on the bush
clearings.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
Slowly the flats
assumed a grey tinge
as 10,000 ewes
emerged from the
tussocks and strings
of sheep joined the
mob from the hills
...

I found a few flats
up the river but
they were too small
and too high up, to
be worth my while to
take.

Source: Big Country of the North Island
Author: NEWTON
Quote:
The coastal flats of
Homewood and the
adjoining properties
are great fattening
country, producing
big drafts of fat
stock.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
With the emphasis on
the flats,
Makarora's whole
management was
turned round. It had
been a traditional,
extensively run
property, but as the
flats were fenced
and grassed, it
became intensive.

A well-balanced unit
comprising both
river flats and easy
terraces.

Prime finishing land
with cropping flats.

The land area is
made up of 50ha of
strong fertile
flats. [on the
flats]

Author: McARA
Quote:
Flatsheet: A steel
plate, usually four
feet square and up
to three-eighths of
an inch thick, used
on underground rail
junctions instead of
points and on the
floor of the brace
and shaft chambers
to enable the
handling and turning
of ore-trucks. A
considerable amount
of skill and
strength was
required to handle
the loaded trucks,
which weighed 25
cwt, on these
flatsheets. The
trucks were built
with two-thirds of
the weight on the
front axle to enable
a man to lift the
rear-end while
turning the truck.

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
The long head is
unusual in the sense
that the dogs can
either run up the
creek, or up the
guts but have a
difficult piece of
ground to cover to
clear the sheep
cleanly, and not
flatten their head.

Several pens of big
bullocks were
yarded, but most of
them had not the age
or were not forward
enough for the
flattening paddock,
and prices offered
did not approach
vendors' reserves.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
For a time Bede went
out of her way to
pass a swimming-bath
... where real boys
splashed and yelled
... She listened to
their commonplace
talk. `Gee, that was
a flatter.' ...
`You're going off
the ten-footer? Come
and see, old Jenks
thinks he can
dive..'

This must benefit
all flatters.

With its predecessor, Food for Flatters, one always imagined some provincial hearty (Kevin? Graham?) dashing in from rugby practice to see what might be lashed up from a pound of mince and a tin of something.

Some of it seems to
come from the
collective
unconscious of a
thousand Wellington
flatters.

`Feeding the
`flatter' or the
`roomer.'

At first glance,
thy're a more
sophisticated Food
for Flatters.

Varsity is drawing
to a close and New
Zealand Post wants
student flatters to
redirect their mail
when they move back
home.

Every Tuesday at
7.30pm her flatties
- who include a
policeman, a manager
and a
telecommunications
worker - scramble
for a seat to
witness a group of
Aussie sheilas claw
their way to the
top.

The flatties were
surprised to see me
home so early,
expecting me to be
out all night as I
had been a lot.

He knows the gig, he
explains, quickly
shooting off a story
about Dylan Tait
interviewing his
then-flattie
musician Nathan
Haines in New York.

A bisexual flatmate
joins the cast of
This Life.. But not
without dissension
in the flatties'
ranks

...now that their
mates and most of
Wellington's
students have seen
it, will the
well-worn themes of
nightmare flatties
pull the punters?

Their presence
provoked more humour
than concern among
the flatties.

Clearly, you had to be there, but in lieu of such a privilege, the documentary had most of the old flatties on to reminisce about their "conceptual" freedom flat. ... All the ex-flatties remember it almost reverently, and frankly they all still look like characters out of The Young Ones.

The three current
"flatties" seem to
get on peacefully
enough.

You don't want to
get your flatties
offside.

Police believe
thieves who stole a
car which got a
flattie, pinched
another car rather
than change a tyre.

Taking a stroll with
your baby takes on
new dimensions these
days, especially as
you get a flattie in
the urban
wilderness.

[Hdg] Flattie ends
chase... Soon after,
however, the case
was closed because
the car, stolen from
Feilding, had a flat
tyre.

"Lady", he said,
"did you know you
had a flattie on
your rear wheel?"

However, he said
dealing with
flatties was easier
- if you had no
replacement tube you
could stuff grass
inside the tyre and
continue driving.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
Returning, I collect
a flattie, rain
begins, drenched I
reach work, ...

Author: McCAULEY
Quote:
His own bike has a
flattie. Maureen
bought a new inner
tube at Parenga, but
though she's tried
and Hennie's tried
there seems to be no
way of easing the
wretched tyre off
the rim.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
flattie a punctured
tyre; eg `She's
given the old dunga
too hard a time on
the corners, she got
a flattie on the
back left and
flapped to a stop.'

Don't race round in
a `flattie' if you
haven't finished
your letter at
10.30, looking for
candles.

A hard-working
boatman who goes
fishing in a flattie
and one or two net
fishermen are
pestered with
requests for fish.

You have to get
aboard the launch by
means of a "flatty"
and that flatty has
to do a bit of
surf-riding.

Source: Holiday Trip to the Catlins District, A

I were blown out to

Author: MAY
Quote:
I have just finished
an article ...
referring to flat
bottomed boats
(Flatties) used at
Lake Ellesmere and
Taumutu. In the
early 1930s my
Father bought a
flattie which was
used to go across to
the Opihi mouth for
whitebaiting season
and also for eeling
and floundering.

The latest class,
the Takapuna, 12 ft
6 in flatties, are
very handy little
craft, and ideal for
racing or knocking
about the sheltered
bays and beaches of
Takapuna.

I never went
flatting, which
wasn't the done
thing in my time.

First time flatting
is where the stories
were for me.

Anyone who has ever
flatted, is
flatting, or is
thinking of flatting
with other people,
should see this
play.

If you were flatting
with several other
people, and one lost
his job, and you all
chipped in to give
him some money to
support him, well
you'd all expect him
to contribute to the
household in some
other way, wouldn't
you?

At least there is no
threat of being
turfed out at the
whim of a landlord
as happened to me a
number of times
during my flatting
days.

Flatting brings you
closer to the lies,
loves and
idiosyncrasies of
complete strangers
than you would
otherwise choose to
get.

The Government has abandoned its plans for a flatulence tax in the face of fierce farmer opposition and international derision... "Animal fart tax puts wind up New Zealand farmers," the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation said on its website. "Farmers raise stink over New Zealand fart tax," said The Guardian newspaper in Britain.

It's been a
wonderfully retro
experience watching
the farmers get
aerated about the
government's new
flatulence tax.

So when the
government proposed
a "flatulence tax"
on farmers - to make
them pay for the
methane emissions
produced by their
livestock - every
fart joke in
Christendom was
wheeled out and
dusted off.

Mr Barton is not alone in his opposition to the Government's "flatulence tax". "Tell Helen she can stick her latest tax dream up her very own windtunnel," remarks a Rural News correspondent from Oamaru... The flatulence tax will see farmers charged about 9c a year for each mature sheep and from 54-72c a year for each mature beef or dairy animal...

His lusty blowing on
the conch shell
sounds a perfect
target for
flatulence tax.

Two of New Zealand's
best flatwater
canoeists have head
to Australia... The
challenger for
flatwater canoeing
was to provide funds
to send paddlers to
world events.

Author: WILSON
Quote: Hypochoeris radicata CATSEAR ... Flatweed

Quote:
[In Dusky Bay] it
will generally be
necessary to secure
to the trees also,
to prevent being
drifted off from the

half fill their

kete (flax basket)

Author: SANSOM
Quote:
The fresh fish were
spread out on the

Author: COWAN
Quote:
These Ngati-Mutunga
... made up small
casks of powder in
flax-basket pikaus
or back-loads, and
transported them
through all the
forests and ranges

... there are four
distinct sections
... most easily
brought under
cultivation. The
open grass land,
that in which fern
and tutu easily
grow, the flax
bottoms, and the
reclaimable swamp
land.

Should the weather
permit, by the tall
flax-bush the candle
is lit.

With the best will
in the world it is
hard to find
anything to praise
about flax bushes.

It is a perfect sea
of brown grass-tree
tops, only relieved
by the occasional
green of a flax bush
or ti-ti growing
along the sides of
the canals, where
the ground has some
consistence.
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 246

to pass the night

Author: LADY CAMPBELL

and then a stiff,

successsive taps of
his paw.

Author: MEREDITH

And the louder

Author: PINFOLD
Quote:
Good business was

Zealand hemp, the

family and is
popularly termed
`flax'.

Flax: Phormium Tenax. `The poor man's friend.' This plant, shaped like a giant tussock, was one of the most useful things that grew. The leaves or `blades' were ready-made straps and ropes for almost any purpose. The bush makes an excellent dog-kennel, and many a man has made a comfortable camp under one on a rough night. It is handy to tie a horse to and very good shelter for shorn sheep. The leaves are easily skinned; and the fibre was used for making crackers for stock and bullock whips. The individual plants are called flax bushes and the dried reed stalks (which Maoris and children tied into bundles to make rafts) are called flax-sticks, koradi ss. o[r] kraddy ss., I suppose a corrupted Maori word. On native country flax is always a sign of good land. ([1857 Paul Letters from Canterbury], p.96; [1898 Morris Austral-English])

New Zealand hemp, or
`flax' as it is
termed locally, is
one of the so-called
`hard' or leaf
fibres, as
contrasted with the
`soft' fibres from
the bast of stems.
flax: plant with large strong leaves used for rope making.

Author: DAWSON
Quote: The term `flax' for the genus Phormium, although firmly established, is yet another inappropriate common name as Phormium and true linen flax (Linum) have in common only the possession of useful fibres. Mountain flax is Phormium cookianum and its tufts of narrow, leathery leaves may be conspicuous in poorly drained places in tussock herbfield and shrubland.

Mr. Simmonds suggests that the marsh-tit would help in the eradication of the flax-grub. But ... the caterpillar of Persectania steropastis (the species which does most of the damage in the South) hides during the day in the sheaths at the bases of the leaves, where no bird could capture it. I believe that the larva of the Xanthorhoe praefectata, the northern flax-moth, also conceals itself during the day.
[caption] Graph illustrating the ...life-cycle of the New Zealand flax-moth (Orthoclydon praefectata).

At the point where
the high [Nelson]
bluffs cease, a very
irregular bank of
boulder-stones
detaches itself from
the main land, and,
at the distance of
about half a mile,
runs parallel with
it for eight or nine
miles, nearly to the
bottom of the bay.
The space between
this boulder-bank
and the main land
... is filled by a
flax swamp ...

Author: CARBERRY
Quote:
The Battle of
Rangariri (no date)
... they drove the
Maoris like sheep
before them over a
deep Gully at the
bottom of which lies
an extensive Flax
swamp, and the
slaughter of the
Evening was sharp
...

If the weather has
been very dry ... we
attempt to burn a
great flax swamp.

Author: LINDSAY
Quote:
Hence, next to bush
and swamp-land
proper (on alluvial
clays), Flax-land is
regarded as the most
desirable for
agricultural
purposes.
`Flax-swamps' are
frequently as common
as `Tussock-swamps,'
though their soil is
far from being so
wet or watery. Like
the
`Tussock-swamps,'
they are frequently
very `tussocky' -
causing walking
thereon to be
extremely ...
fatiguing.

The Korari is the
name of the flower
stalk, often, but
wrongly, used as the
name of the plant.
The edible root is
the Aruhe. The word
`Muka' is commonly
applied to the
dressed fibre; it is
the correct name for
the inner leaves.
Cleared bush-land is
suitable for the
cultivation of the
flax plant, and even
swamp-land is
improved by
drainage. In the
various flax swamps
near nelson ...the
finest plants grow
upon the soil that
has been thrown out
of the ditch ...

Author: BAINES
Quote:
After tramping many
miles over steep
fern ranges, through
flax swamps, and
tangled forest ...

Author: BATEMAN
Quote:
The tussock land
abounds in the
Middle Island,
although the richest
land was originally
what are termed
`flax swamps.'

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
There was evil in
the wild, sensuous
smell of flax-swamp
that rose to
windward . ..
Notes: 1902 Lancaster Our Lady of the Plains in 1987 Happy Endings 101

Author: MANSFIELD
Quote:
Then the rain fell
heavily drearily -
on to the river and
the flax swamp -

Author: GORST
Quote:
After dinner we had
to cross a
flax-swamp.

... whereas in New
Zealand the flax
swamps could be
easily converted
into dairying-land.
Mr. Oliver caught a clear view of Porzanoidea plumbea, the swamp-rail, in a flax swamp near the sea-coast.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote: [OEDS]

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
He ... would stop
... to listen to the
blue-feathered
scarlet-legged
pukeka calling in a
warm flax-swamp ...

Author: STUDHOLME
Quote:
In some of the heavy
flax swamps near the
sea there were quite
a number of really
wild cattle ...

The first arrivals
were linen workers
from Glasgow and
Paisley who had
heard about the vast
flax swamps of New
Zealand, and arrived
here with all their
linen-making
machinery only to
find that the flax
was "Maori flax" and
not suitable for
making fine linen.

Author: Lakeman
Quote:
.. all this at a
place nine miles
from the town, and
on a spot that six
years ago was a flax
swamp.

Author: BARKER
Quote:
A view of downs
rolling into a
narrow gully, the
flax swamp of which
formed a natural
boundary.

Author: PASCOE
Quote:
On 22 February
[1891] Douglas took
two weeks' supplies
up the valley,
through flax swamps
and lawyer tangles.

Author: HUNT
Quote:
In this way Foxton
was able to retain
its identity as a
"flax town".

Author: BRUNNER
Quote:
I had often looked
forward with dread
to the time when my
shoes would be worn
out, ... but now I
can trudge along ...
with a pair of
native sandals,
called by the
natives pairairai,
made of the leaves
of flax, or, what is
more durable, the
leaves of the ti or
flax tree.

Author: BATISTICH
Quote:
Taddi was a good
bush carpenter; he
soon knocked up a
rough cottage for
the men to live in,
better than the flax
whare they agreed.

Author: BARR
Quote:
A Maori basketful
[of flour] strapped
with flaxes across
his shoulder.

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
fn Flax-blades: The
plant known as NZ
Flax has long
ensiform [check]
leaves commonly
called blades.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Flax-blade, ... the
leaf of the New
Zealand Flax (q.v.).

Author: BAUCKE
Quote:
... he would lave
any head with
fermented
herb-waters, and
bandage it with
split flax blades,
according to an
ancestral recipe,
...

Author: LANCASTER
Quote:
... he came pushing
through the tall
flax-blades and
black koradi-sticks
and found her
sitting demure in
her print gown ...

Author: DOMETT
Quote: With flax blades binding to a tree./ The Maid ..Ibid. 1883 1/127 With flax-blades binding to a tree/ The Maid who strove her limbs to free./

Author: COWAN
Quote:
Half wading, half
swimming, he went
with the current,
keeping close under
the flax-bordered
bank.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
... the Ranger
officers ...
explored the [Maori
defensive] works
before which they
had crouched in the
flax-clump.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
... Thomas cut scrub
and levelled as best
he could the
flax-covered ground
on which the dray
had been left.

Author: MIDDLETON
Quote:
(Day by Itself) It
seemed impossible
that this ...
estuary, with its
toe toe and
flax-covered banks,
was only
half-an-hour's fast
drive from the city.

A gang of
flax-cutters ... in
Foxton. We finished
the block of flax we
were cutting in.

I have about 100
acres of land in
flax, and have
always allowed the
flax-cutters to cut
it as they pleased,
but have recently
been informed that
if cut down into the
butt of the leaf
which contains the
gum the growth is
thrown back about
fifteen months.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
The duff boiled for
three hours, and the
rattle of tin plates
was a newly invented
song of the
flax-cutters.

Author: FINLAYSON
Quote:
flax: New Zealand
flax, phormium
tenax, a plant that
grows in clumps of
tall sword-like
leaves with strong
fibres. Strips of
the leaves are woven
to make the matting
used in village
churches and
meeting-houses. The
fibre had commercial
use, and until the
depression flax
mills and
flax-cutters' camps,
temporary rough
quarters for
harvesters, would be
found near swamps
where the flax grew.

Author: HYDE
Quote:
Then he struck the
rhythm of
flax-cutting, and
could do the job on
his head.

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
A man told us he was
not there but down
in the swamp
supervising
flaxcutting.

Other crafts and
trades scheduled
were, coopers,
flax-dressers,
gardeners, millers,
...
Notes: 1843 June 21 Census of New Plymouth in 1940 Establishment of New Plymouth 222

Quote:
The blacksmith, the
builder, ... the
flax-dresser, and
the farmer were soon
busy ...

However, one man
names Williams, an
expert flax-dresser,
took the
perseverance
prospecting; he was
rewarded by finding
flax ...

A process of
flax-dressing which
will reduce the cost
of production; ...

But the Daedalus [in
17??] succeeded in
taking two Maoris on
board, a warrior and
a tohunga [to teach
flax-dressing] -
rather unfortunate
choices when it is
considered that
flax-dresssing was
neither toa nor
tohunga work but
wahine work.

As a result of their
investigations, the
Committee urged that
[154] flax-owners
should see that the
flax is cut in such
a manner as to leave
the heart of the
flax-fans
uninjured...

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote: [We] undertook to risk the reptile [sc. taniwha] if the Maoris would make us two `eel-bobs.' These are made by stringing worms on flax-fibre, which is attached in a loose lump by a cord to the end of a stick. Ibid. 44 The Maoris had our `bobs' ready, ...Presently an old chap named Paitai got very excited because a large eel was `stripping his bob.' The fibre was not strong enough to lift the large eel out of the water.

Author: HAY
Quote:
In the commercial
world New Zealand
flax-fibre was
highly esteemed at
one time, but has
fallen out of
favour.

Author: BULLER
Quote: When the korari-flower (Phormium tenax) is in season, the Kakas repair in flocks to the flax-fields to feast on the flower-honey; ...

Author: BULLER
Quote:
... in December and
January [Tuis] leave
the forest and
repair to the
flax-fields to feast
on the korari honey.

I have little doubt
that ... all these
flax flats might be
made available; ...
Notes: 1840 Oct Report M.D.Martin from River Thames in GBPP House of Commons 1841 (No.311) 119

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
On the way back ...
we found poor old
Paitai stuck in one
of those
`underground creeks'
peculiar to the
flax-flats of New
Zealand where the
banks are kept from
erosion by the
numerous roots.

Some of the flowers
here are both useful
and ornamental,
particularly the
flax-flower, which
abounds in a clear
liquid honey; ...
The Bell-birds are
very fond of these
flowers, ...

Author: DOMETT
Quote:
... Little isles/
Where still the
clinging flax-flower
smiles.

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Flax-flower, ... the
flower of the New
Zealand flax (q.v.).

Author: GOWANS
Quote:
Her dirty fingers
poked into the
embers her flax
flowers, dead grass
and dung, which she
called her `yellow
pine' or `buffalo
chips' or the
melodic-sounding
`Kaladdies'.

Author: FULLER
Quote:
Bundles of kiekie
and dried
flax-flower stems
were also used to
carry fire.

Hopes of flax-fur
money-spinner [hg]
Mr Howard said a
trust, Te Rito
Kaitiaki, has been
formed with Maori
interests with the
aim to set up a
flax-fur industry,
with chemical
by-products.

Author: BENNETT
Quote:
The first was
swimming, which was
learnt in our
flax-girt creek
meandering through
its deep pools and
rapid shallows.

[Hdg] The Flax-Grub.
Undoubtedly the most
serious injury to
flax swamps at the
present day is
caused by the larvae
of a native moth
called by millers
the 'flax-grub.'

... the marsh tit of Europe would doubtless help considerably in the control of the flax-grub which is at present causing heavy losses to the country. Ibid. 1/320 Mr. Simmonds suggests that the marsh-tit would help in the eradication of the flax-grub. But ... the caterpillar of Persectania steropastis (the species which does most of the damage in the South) hides during the day in the sheaths at the bases of the leaves, where no bird could capture it. I believe that the larva of the Xanthorhoe praefectata, the northern flax-moth, also conceals itself during the day.

... the dry conditions and accumulation of dead leaves are favourable as well to the flax-grub. Ibid..283 Kirk, T.W. and Cockayne, A.H. The Pests and diseases of NZ Phormium. NZ Dept Ag Ann Report 1909 pp286-289 Ibid. Cockayne, A.H.: The Flax-grub. N.Z. Jour. Agric., x, pp. 1-7 (1915).

Author: GILLESPIE
Quote: The ones attracting most attention were the owlet moths, the caterpillars of which destroyed the first pastures and cereal and root crops. There were also porina moths (Oxycanus spp.) whose caterpillars also destroyed pastures; the bag moth (Oeceticus omnivorus) which left cigar-shaped cocoons hanging from shrubs and tree [sic]; and the ghost-like white moth ... of the flax grub (Orthoclydon praefectata) which eats longitudinal slits on the surface of [flax] leaves ...

Author: RAIMONDO
Quote:
One man stood in the
middle of the
[flax]bush and cut
the blades in one
stroke, using a
sharp curved knife
called a `flaxhook'.

Author: POLACK
Quote:
and a flax-house at
[186] Uwoua, eighty
feet long by
twenty-four broad
and forty feet high
to the ridge-pole,
was built by a chief
and a large company
of natives for a
small keg of powder
25lbs. in weight.
The house was
extremely
water-tight and
warm, and several
streams and marshes
had been denuded of
their rushes (raupo)
to cover the roof
and sides; ...
<i>Ibid. 1/210-211
The largest public
works undertaken are
those of
flax-houses, some of
which are above one
hundred [211] feet
in length, thirty
feet in width, and
forty feet in
height. These are
built less for
ornament than being
durable and
water-tight, as any
rain pouring on the
flax would discolour
and finally rot it.

Author: HEAPHY
Quote:
The native ...

Notes: 1846 Heaphy Expedition South-West Nelson in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 197

Quote:
These tubes are thus

mussel-shell, ...

The Maoris ... made
up ... three
pikaws[sic] or
bundles of about
35lb each which they

flax leaf which

... that was one
swag, and a very
unwieldy one it was,

Author: PYKE
Quote:
At first he cut a
quantity of the

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH

This was twisted

The huts were all

Quote:
Zephyrs stirred the

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
~ the blade of the

Quite accidentally

... the steam was

Some of the Maoris

flax-like growth of

astelia, in the

Author: PYKE
Quote:
Loosing the
flax-line, he made a

the locality.

Author: COWAN
Quote:
The end was fastened
with a flax-line
carried across the
track so laid that
any suspecting
invader coming along
the track ... would
release the trap ...

Author: BAKER
Quote:
Flax mats softened
an already well-worn
floor as they padded

Without an export an
import trade, the
New Zealanders might
not have to go back
to "the pipi and
flax mat" standard,
but out standard of
living and comfort
would be
considerably
lowered.

Author: MALCOLM
Quote:
The women spent the
morning making flax
mates as plates for
the guests.

Author: POWER
Quote: In the interior of the Pa the Wahines[e-acute], or matrons, are busy weaving flax-mats, cleaning potatoes or fish, or engaged in the superintendence of a Maori oven, or a huge gipsy-looking cauldron, called a `go-ashore', and can only afford to greet the visitor with a whining `tena koe pakeha', sighing as though they were very much to be pitied. Ibid. 172 ... the women were cooking, gossiping, or making flax-mats; ..

Whares with bullet
proof flax mats, for
roofs, were built
all along inside the
rifle pits, ...

Author: GORST
Quote:
... the service was
European fashion. We
sat at a table with
a white cloth, forks
and spoons. I felt a
lingering longing
for the old
hospitality of
former days, when
the company sat on
the ground, upon
clean flax mats
spread over the
floor, when each
guest had a separate
portion handed to
him by a Maori girl
in a little green
flax kit, woven for
the occasion,
potatoes and meat
and vegetable marrow
together, to which
he had to help
himself with his
fingers.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
Besides the whare
(houses), there were
whata (futtahs)
standing there when
I was a boy. They
stood on two posts,
and each post had a
niche cut round it
to stop the rats
from getting up to
the food stored on
them. There was no
roof on them, the
food being covered
with flax mats.

Author: JOHNSTONE
Quote:
The Maori cooks then
place flax-matting
upon the hot stones.

Quote:
Sheep-raising,
flax-milling ... and

the main industries.

As a result of their
investigations, the
Committee urged that
[154] flax-owners
should see that the
flax is cut in such

the heart of the

Author: J.R. FORSTER
Quote:
... two Nets made of

Author: G. FORSTER
Quote: Here [at Dusky Bay] we found a double canoe hauled upon the shore ... The canoe ... consisted of two troughs or boats joined together with sticks, tied across the gunwales with strings of the New Zeeland flax-plant. Ibid. 1/202 ... the New Zeeland flax-plant (phormium), [grew] round some old abandoned huts of the natives.

The flax-plant of

very great quantity
of it.
Notes: 1791 Jan 10 Lieut.-Governor Phillip King Description Norfolk Isd in 1908 McNAB Hist Records 1/120

Author: ELLIS
Quote: The native flax-plant, phormium tenax, ... is by no means like the flax or hemp plants of England, but resembles, in its appearance and manner of growth, the flag or iris.

Author: NICHOLAS
Quote:
The plant which grew
in greatest
profusion, ... was
the flax-plant, ...

Author: McCRAE
Quote: The hill was covered completely with the flax plant which is called Corade[acute] Mauvre, and which grew in great luxuriance. [Andersen fn.: ... korari is usually the tall flower-stalk of harakeke ..., but in the North sometimes used to designate the plant itself. Here McCrae uses the word maori in its original sense signifying `normal, usual, ordinary'.

Quote:
The harbour here is

rocks ... much

Source: Early Journals of Henry Williams, The

Author: POLACK
Quote:

Quote:

Quote: ... the indigenous flax-plant and ... the Cabbage-tree or Ti-palm. [fn] Dracaena Australis. Ibid. 149 [The kiekie] has a bunch of leaves, growing from the root like those of the flax-plant, but seldom exceeding two feet in length.

Author: SHORTLAND
Quote: Our natives soon constructed [a mokihi] ... from the dry stalks of the flax plant (phormium tenax), a material light as cork, ...

Quote: (And) [Phormium tenax ]

Muka of the natives,
as the dressed fibre

He described briefly

[Hawaiian]

Author: FITTON
Quote:
Although New Zealand

Author: COWAN
Quote: Boiled flax-root water poured on the wounds, and also dock-root (runa), well scraped and boiled, were our favourite remedies for gunshot and bayonet wounds. IBid. 2/396 Te Kaka was suffering agony from his shattered jaw; he had contrived to pound up some flax-root, and make a dressing of it, which he had tied under his terrible wound.

Author: BAINES
Quote:
When I had four made
I fixed one to the
top of a korari or
flax-stalk, ...

Source: Contributions to the Early History of New Zealand
Author: HOCKEN
Quote:
... their sole
shelter [was] a

carried up country,
stuck on the end of

Author: KNIGHT
Quote:
.. suddenly into his
mind popped the soft
translucent jelly

Tumoti had gone to

Got some dead flax
sticks to boil a

Author: HAAST

the river fell, and

Quote: FLESHFISH Dermatopsis macrodon ... The fleshfish is a small cod-like fish ... They have been found in New Zealand and southern Australia around rock reefs at low tide level and in shallow coastal waters.

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
fleshfish 861

The process of
fleshing is usually
carried out by
machines operating a
right-and-left
spiral
knife-cylinder ...
flesh side to the
knife cylinder. A
process similar to
fleshing is also
carried out in order
to remove as much as
possible of the hair
root-sheaths and fat
glands upon the
grain side of the
pelt. This process
is known as
`scudding', the
skins being fed into
the machine, grain
side to the knife
cylinder.

Here the hide is
fleshed or flayed by
hand to remove any
surplus fat and meat
left on in
butchering ... These
fleshings are sent
to the tallow
department ...
(And) 2. fleshy-leaved lobelia, Lobelia Roughii.
Notes: COCKAYNE Botanical Survey Waipoua Kauri Forest

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: Lobelia Roughii

Contrary to what the
name suggested,
"flex beds" were not
a new tool for
physiotherapists,
but the "converse to
resource beds". Eh?
That is beds
occasionally
"flexed" into use,
versus those always
available for use.

Why hasn't a
generator/retailer
introduced such a
flex-price option
already?

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
No doubt you
frequently will
meet, A Chinaman
going down the
street, With slang
expressions then to
greet This cove to
yield you joy. Say
to him, `How are
you, old flick?'

That doesn't mean
that you flick
Changing Rooms, for
example, because
there is an audience
for programmes like
that.

Author: Owen Marshall
Quote:
'They'll get a
three-bedroom, brick
place in one of the
hill suburbs, and
flick friends like
us.'

Author: SLATTER
Quote: Plenty of times they flicked me with wet towels in the changing shed at the baths ...] Ibid. 189 `Another one won't hurt,' I say, but he doesn't take the hint. `When we get there perhaps,' he says. `Come on boy. Flick your wick. Can't waste it'. He pours me another.

I have also had a
report of `creases'
and what to me were
two novelties,
`flicks' and
`skinch'.

Author: SWAN
Quote:
Light, wire mesh
goggles, 'flies
eyes,' prevent one's
eyes being gouged.

Following are other
local money-names: -
1 pound note -
flimsy, rag or
carpet ...

The pound note of
pre-decimal days was
varously [sic] known
as a quid, nicker,
smacker, flimsy,
rag, and carpet. The
latter term was
apparently peculiar
to New Zealand and
Australia.

Author: GRADY
Quote:
[glossary] Flense -
To strip the blubber
off a whale. Flinch
means the same
thing. Flinch - Same
as flense.

Author: BELL
Quote:
If the fishing is to
be carried on by a
shore party, the try
pots and huts are
erected on the beach
... The boats are
sent out at daylight
every morning, and
when ... they kill a
fish it is towed
ashore and flinched

Notes: 1831 Nov Bell Letter in 1913 McNab Old Whaling Days 9

Quote: flindersia n [NL, fr. Matthew Flinders + NL -ia] 1 cap : a small genus of pinnate-leaved Australasian trees (family Meliaceae) having white flowers followed by woody capsular fruits and yielding strong hardwood lumber, often with an excellent figure, that is used in cabinetmaking and construction - see FLINDOSA 2 -s : any tree of the genus Flindersia

I want to go back to
Europe to see my
fling. I met him in
Melbourne and we had
a fling for four
days.

This country is
traversed by
"flinties" (small
veins of cherty
quartz).

At the intersections
of cross-veins,
flinties, and
`flatheads', the
mingling of waters
that have come from
different Sources
... has resulted in
precipitation of the
gold and its
associated minerals
... [173] ... In the
lower levels the
patches of highly
auriferous ore
generally occurred
at the intersectons
of `flinties' with
the veins ...

The nearest parallel
to the `flinties' or
`indicator' veins so
common at Thames is
seen in the Tairua
Broken Hills Mine.
Here a small flinty
leader ...
intersected certain
of the reefs ...
[82] ... The richer
material occurred
... also ... where
`cross-heads' or
`flinties' joined
the main reef.

Q. If you ordered a
"flip" in a South
Island takeaway bar,
what would you get?
A. A potato fritter.
Notes: This was a question on 27 Dec., answer given on 28 Dec. p. 14

Quote:
One way in which it
[the development
programme] will do
this is to 'hump and
hollow' some of the
pakihi soils and to
'flip' pasture. The
plan at this stage
is to turn all those
properties that are
able to be flipped
or humped and
hollowed into
dairying.

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Spotted Shag Stictocarbo punctatus(SPARRMAN, 1786) ... Spotted Shag S. p. punctatus (SPARRMAN, 1786). Blue Shag S.p. steadi (OLIVER, 1930). ... OTHER NAMES: Parekareka, ocean shag, crested shag, flip-flap, blue shag.

The spotted shag, or
flip-flap, well
known to our shore
folk, is stated by
ornithologists to be
peculiar to New
Zealand; its active
movements enliven
many a bluff
headland or rocky
inlet of our island
coast line... In
calm autumn days
often have we
watched the still
waters of our
shallow bays flash
with the swift
motion of the
flip-flap.

Author: AYSON
Quote:
Thomas tried his
hand at baking
flippers, with
flour, water and a
little salt for the
ingredients, and
treacle or sugar to
sweeten the taste
after the cooking
was complete.

Author: FOSTON
Quote:
He has now become a
crack hand at making
`doe-boys' and
`Flipperjacks.'

I have recently done
a small amount of
work with
Agriculture NZ and
some of the dairy
farmers in the Cape
Foulwind area
looking at the
changes in soils
from flipping.
Notes: pc with Dr Craig Ross, Landcare Research:

Quote:
The most innovative
soil improvement
technique to be used
in the conversions
will be pasture
flipping - a
practice pioneered
at Cape Foulwind to
bring free-draining
soils to the surface
and turn sour
wetland into lush
pasture .. A group
of Cape Foulwind
dairy farmers,
together with
Agriculture New
Zealand consultant
Richard Reynolds,
and Landcare
Research Scientist
Dr Craig Ross, are
evaluating flipping
or breaking up the
pakihi iron pan to
bring free-draining
soil to the top. The
technique was
developed by a local
farmer, the late
Fred King, and his
son Alex, and costs
between $2500 and
$5000 a hectare.

Author: KEITH
Quote:
Flies could be kept
at bay with Flit in
a patent, pump
action spray.

[Advt] Flit is sure
death to insects
because it is a
combination of
potent killing
agents which cannot
be excelled... Flit
spray will not stain
and is harmless to
humans.

Author: MASON
Quote:
ANA. What's that in
her hand? Looks like
- Yeh! a flit-gun.
PERA. Flit-gun? Sure
does look like a
flit-gun!

Author: CARR
Quote:
Old fashioned
`Breast' benches
(where flitches from

are still used in
many mills.

As the first slice,
known as a flitch,

the off-bearer holds

the pony bench
conveyor chains.

Author: MARRIOTT
Quote:
Face cuts, by the
way, are the first
boards to come off
