[Les Cleveland]
FLITCHING: a method
of draining blood
from slaughtered
cattle after they
have been PITHED.
The animals become
unconscious after

severed.

Float: Loose pieces
of quartz shed from
a reef outcrop by
weathering and found
some distance away.

Quote:
Well, everything was
going well till ...
spun two coins very

means land them
without spinning
them more than
twice.

Author: KEITH
Quote:
One suburban sound
of the 1940s, now
completely vanished
from New Zealand
streets, was that of
food vendors: the
rabbito and the
whitebait seller and
the clip-clopping
hooves of the
milko's horse-drawn
float - as the milk
waggon was called.

float ... 15.
Austral. & N.Z. a
vehicle for
transporting horses.

... `ducks'

Hotel' need no

Quote:

Ex: v to float up to

Quote:
float up casual
approach, unexpected
arrival or

He hadn't won a
match since May
2003. What a

Author: WASHBOURN
Quote:
.. the gold ...
[was] so much of a
gold-leaf character
... I have
frequently seen
large specks
floating in and out
of the dish when
panning out there,
and these in digging
terms are
`floaters.'

The loose auriferous
rubble and
`floaters' of rich
stone mined on the
Lord Brassey claim
were part of this
great mass of
slumped material.

Such occurrences,
however, are but
analogous to the
`hard bars' or
`floaters' of the
Thames mines, and to
the cores of fairly
fresh andesite and
dacite found inset
in masses of highly
altered rock.

... But classroom
construction hasn't
kept pace, so the
teachers become
`floaters' or
teachers without
classrooms.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
floater a pie
floating in gravy
served up
traditionally by
piecarts and
cafeterias along
with peas and lumpy
mashed potato. NZA.
- a turd that will
not flush away.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
As a tree was
falling away from
the others these
'floaters' would be
released to drop
down on top of you.
We never spoke to
each other when
working, only to
warn of floaters or
any other danger.

"Your "Currantly
Bran" is marvellous
for me - I'm now
producing the most
regular Fluffy
Floaters!"... In
case you haven't
cottoned on, "Fluffy
Floaters" are linked
to bran consumption
in - to put it
delicately - a
"cause and effect"
manner.

Then there are the
little things that
annoy some cleaners
but amuse others:
used condoms under
the bed, "floaters"
in the toilet that
refuse to flush,
arriving early to
find the householder
or their teenager in
the bedroom with a
lover.
Initially there were problems mooring the floating crane Hikinui because a pile snapped when the crane strained against it.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And)

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
In some areas cattle
will be carried as a
floating grazing
unit or
'set-stocked' to
deal with surplus
growth.

Floating line: Also
'Shooting Head' and
'Slow Sink'. A
strong cored line
that the tippet
attaches to; most
fishermen have all
three on separate
spools in their kit.

Author: NOLAN
Quote:
Floatstone: loose
quartz in a river
bed, usually remote
from its parent
lode.

Author: McLEAN

Some driftwood is
found on the banks
of the Awatere,
sufficient to keep
some of the Stations

confident of the

When two or three
adjoining runs are
in one man's holding
he must have as many
flocks as
establishments as
runs to fulfil the
exact letter of the
regulations ...

Author: BARKER
Quote:
It is impossible to
estimate our loss
until the grand
muster at shearing,
but we may set it
down at half our
flock ...

... after we drafted
out some fine
wethers ... I
counted the whole
flock, 1649.

Author: TINNE
Quote:
It is customary to
invite all the
neighbours to your
`muster,' as they
can then pick out
their missing sheep
which have strayed
from the adjoining
runs. As they
complete each flock,
it is turned over to
a shepherd, who
would drive it off
with the aid of his
dogs to a beat,
possibly ten or
twenty miles distant
...

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south
Author: KENNAWAY
Quote:
It needs incessant
care to prevent
stragglers breaking
away from the head
and sides of the
mob, and the rear of
the flock, made up
of the weaker sheep,
requires an equally
constant lookout.
The horses are led
or ridden, as the
ground allows; ...
but in driving
through unknown
country, the halts
are made very much
where the explorers
find themselves at
sundown.

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
[cp mob] A little
further up the
[East] coast the
Maoris have a flock
of very `scabby'
sheep, which roam
over a large area of
land. These sheep
are all long-tailed,
and have never been
marked, except on
their ears.

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
When the flock is
small this is all
the wool classing
that is necessary.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
Instead, therefore,
of collecting the
sheep from every
part of the run and
counting them in the
yards, we took
delivery `off the
books' - that is, we
accepted the flock
on the previous
shearing and lambing
tally.

Flock: (1) The whole
of the sheep on a
farm or station; (2)
the whole of the
ewes or wethers on a
station are
sometimes spoken of
as the ewe or wether
flock. A number of
sheep running
together are a mob
(q.v.). `Such a
large flock as this
- about 50,000.'

Author: BARKER
Quote: 3. Adjectival use. - Ordinary as opposed to stud sheep, which are registered and kept for breeding rams and show sheep. (C.) Ibid. 33 Such a large flock as this - about 50,000.

Quote:
My flock was the dry
flock wethers. One
day I got notice to
... put my flock of
3,000 sheep away
back on the hill
country of
`Lochindorb', near
the head of the
Owaka river. It was
very much infested
with wild dogs and
wild pigs, ... but
it was very good
sheep country.

Author: SCOTTER
Quote:
He founded a flock
of Border Leicesters
from which [his
sons] ... bought two
rams and six ewes
and developed a
flock at `Rocklea',

Zealand.

Its purpose is to
divide a mixed flock
... into any
required number of
smaller mobs, ...

Quote:
Flock. The sheep on
a run.

Quote:
NEW ZEALAND. -
Scoured fleece, 1s.
8-1/2d. ...; average
flocks, 1s. 5d. ...;
pieces and locks,
1s. 1d. ...
unwashed, 10-1/2d.
...

Ordinary as opposed
to stud sheep, which

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
flock: of breeding
sheep other than
stud animals.

After weaning the
flock ewes are
mob-stocked through
to crutching and
eye-clipping in
April.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
Ivan blade-shore the
whole wether flock.

Author: GUTHRIE-SMITH
Quote:
.. the hogget flock
of 6000 or 7000 was
autumned and
wintered on
self-sown
un-topdressed
suckling.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Flock: the total of
an owner's sheep. It
may also mean the
total of his sheep
of any particular
breed or any kind.
eg Corriedale--,
ewe--, or wether
flock. Townspeople
may incorrectly term
a mob they see being
driven along the
road as a 'flock.'

To presume laying
down rules for
wool-washing, which
every flock-owner,
overseer or manager
imagines that he
understands better
than all the world
...

As cotted or matted
wool is a loss to
the flock-owner, the
cause of this
condition of the
fleece is often
discussed.

Author: COLONEL W. WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The vicinity of
snowy eminences is
highly estimated by
flock-owners,
particularly where
the downs are
round-topped, ... so
that the gradual
tricklings from the
melting snows go to
nourish the roots of
grasses.
Notes: 1844 Aug 31 COLONEL W. WAKEFIELD Letter in 1898 Hocken Contributions 268

Quote:
[Notice] TO THE
FLOCKOWNERS AND
OTHER INHABITANTS OF
CANTERBURY ...

NOTICE TO
FLOCKOWNERS

Of the several
native grasses ...,
several are
considered by the
flockowners, to
possess high
nutritive powers.

The quantity [711]
of lamb's wool
produced by one
flock owner is
usually too small to
warrant its being
classed into many
lines.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
When I first read
this inscription [in
the Memorial Church,
Cave], the word
`sheep-men' made me
involuntarily
flinch. Years later,
when I had forgotten
it, I suddenly met
it again, and again
I recoiled. So
aghast was I that I
spent weeks
collecting every old
term for
`runholders' I
could, and I found
thirteen, viz.,
`flock owners,'
`flock masters,'
`pastoralists,' `run
holders,' `run
owners,' `sheep
owners,' `sheep
holders,' `sheep
masters,'
`squatters,'
`station holders,'
`station owners,'
`stock holders,[sic]
and `stock owners.'
The word `sheepmen'
is a modern
Americanism, and
using this
anachronism mars a
splendid memorial.
... [12] Of all the
thirteen terms found
in old documents,
the word `runholder'
was the most used,
and it is the word
that I think should
be substituted.

Author: SHARPE
Quote:
A hill-country
flockowner keeps all
his ewe lambs,
turning a percentage
of
eighteen-month-old
ewes - two-tooths,
as they are called -
into his main flock
every year ...

If the flockmaster
decide [sic] to
shear his sheep in
the grease, like
care ought to be
taken to separate
carefully the locks
and oieces from the
fleeces ...

Author: HOBHOUSE
Quote:
The most advanced
flockmasters are now
enclosing on a much
greater scale to
retain large 'mobs'
of sheep when
mustered.

The waste lands were
sold by the
Government - of
sheep - to the
flockmasters about
them.

Will you kindly
inform me what is
used most by
experienced
flockmasters as a
lick for sheep?

Author: HARTLEY
Quote:
Flockmasters shudder
to watch the
uneducated efforts
of a young dog
endeavouring to work
sheep in a 200 acre
paddock of today.

There is an
abundance of water,
enabling the
flock-master to wash
his wool thoroughly;
...
Notes: 1844 Monro to Nelson Examiner in Hocken Contributions 260 (Griffiths Collection) 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey

Quote:
... not only our

concerned.

dog (Canis

unknown. For some

was the terror of

But the bulk of the
wild dogs were not
domestic animals
gone wild, but the
true old Maori wild
dog. I know that
this statement will
be questioned by
many who have never
believed that there
were genuine
old-identity wild
dogs in New Zealand
before Europeans ...

Mr Maxwell: Here is

Flog: steal or
misappropriate Flog
off: sell usually in
an unconventional
manner

Flood Gate: Used

falls with the water

[I learned how] to

All the skills of

flood gate: Device

Author: BALFOUR

To Hampden to see

Author: RIDDOLLS

Where a fence line

Source: High Times in the High Country

[flood-gate]

Author: BARKER

After this repast

finished, ... I did
not like either its

... but I was

two I found it quite

with Mr L- round the
`floor.'

Then some accursed
shearer yells "Floor
Boy!"

In these bigger
sheds would be a
dozen shearers, an
expert classer who,
besides classing all
the wool, manages
the internal running
of the shed, two
floor boys, and men

Author: HAY
Quote:
We see this liquid
[sc. puddled ore]
sent over `beds',
and `floors', and
`ladders', and
`blanketings', and
washed again and
again.

Young petrolheads
drop the suspension,
put valves in the
brake system so that
they do bigger
"smoke-outs"
(spinning the back
wheels while the car
is stationary), and
they bolt seats
directly on to the
floor pan.

The big
1100-square-metre
floor plate had also
attracted the
company and was
unusual for
Wellington where
most floor plates
were between 600 sq
m and 800 sq m...

KPMG wanted 8000sq m
of lettable floor
space with 1600sq m
floor plates (over

by most standards
for central business

In my own field of
office buildings,
for no apparent

became floor plates.

The TTP site was
"the only area on
the fringe of the
city where you could
build large 2000sq m
floor plates",
Catley said.

This arrangement was
devised in the early
1950s to provide a
floor price for

fluctuations for the
commodity whose
price was set mainly
on the auction
floor.

Source: Avondale College Slang Words in Use

Author: BENNETT
HYDE

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

(Queen Charlotte
Sound) We observ'd
already that the
principal fish
caught by the seyne
were Mullets [ed. fn
Aldrichetta
forsteri.] and
Elephant fish [ed.
fn Callarhyncus
milli.] & a few
soles [ed. fn
Peltorhamphus
novaeseelandiae.]
and flounders,
[ed.fn Rhombosalea
spp.] but those
which the Indians
mostly supply'd us
with are a sort of
sea Bream of a
silver colour with a
black spot on the
neck, [ed. fn
Tarakihi, ...] ...
Notes: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/807

Author: SPEIGHT
Quote: The four species of Rhombosolea are distinguished by form and colour. The best known is the Sand flounder, or simply Flounder, (R. plebeia) (Plate II. fig. 2) wider across than the other, while the Greenback (R. tapirina) with white undersurface, the Yellowbelly (R. leporina) and the Black flounder (R. retiaria) have their distinguishing colours recorded in their common names.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 201

Quote: FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii) Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: (i) Flounder (ii) Freshwater Flounder (iii) Flounder (iv) Yellowbelly Flounder. (c) Other common names: (i) Square, Dab, Plaice, Diamond or Diamond-back, Tin-plate, Three Corners. (ii) Blacks, Black Flounder (iii) Greenback [25 `Not common but occasionally taken in southern waters.'] (iv) Yellow Flounder.

Most women in those

Much labelling is done on the grounds of ethnic identity, so terms such as flour bin (a Pakeha), Bruce (an Asian - from Bruce Lee) and T.H. Lowry (a Maori) are in use.

Author: MAY
Quote:
The mercury plates
were seldom perfect:
the finest gold was
lost by flotation
while with cemented
gold a thin coating
of iron oxide
(`rusty gold') often
prevented
amalgamation. The
mercury itself
became `sick' or
`floured'; both
sodium and nitric
acid were employed
to improve its
amalgamating
qualities.

Author: MAY
Quote:
FLOURED MERCURY:
mercury that has
lost its
amalgamating
properties because
of impurities in the
ore or the wash. The
mercury is then
`sick'.

While on an official
visit to the Thames
Goldfield I
...[observed] the
... effect of
Cyanide of
Potassium, in
preventing the
flouring of mercury
used in working the
blanketings. These
blanketings I found
have ... a decidedly
acid reaction, due
... to the presence
of ferric and
ferrous salts ...,
and it is to the
former ... that what
is commonly known as
[335] `flouring,' is
mainly due, in the
process cited above;
such ferric salts
being able to either
oxidize or
chloridize the
surface of any
mercury ..., thus
enfilming it with a
compound, which
being practically
insoluble in water
... prevents that
metallic contact
taking place between
detached mercurial
globules, which is
necessary to
amalgamation.

an ineffective dog -

Our object was to
make a `flume', or
aqueduct, which
should carry the
water of the creek

allow us to work in
the bed of it below.

A good breakfast,

sometimes as high as
1000 feet up, we see
numerous races or
flumes as they are
called used by
diggers to take
water to sluice the
gold out of the
stuff the gold is
found in.
Notes: 1873 Jan 30 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 158

water for dozens and
dozens of miles.

Author: BLYTH
Quote:

companies, working

FLUMES: the more

consisting of

wooden boxes; most
commonly applied to
wooden boxes used
for conveying water
to the claim.

Several of these

water-races over

There were two large
arch-supported
flumes across the
Ohinemuri River
carrying the 12 ft
by 4 ft low-pressure
race.

The stream at the

[175] through the

... bringing water
to bear on the
[drifts] by a system
of `fluming.'

... bringing water

"flumonia".

I find that all
inhabitants of the
country through
which the Main Trunk
line runs earnestly
believe the flumonia
was brought per the
train.

If flumonia must
come back - and most
people seem to
expect it - they
will want to know
how to cope with the
terror... Eating
onions all day keeps
the 'flumonia' quite
away."

During the horrible
flumonia epidemic of
a year ago..
Stanbrook "held the
fort".

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Some of the typical
terms used in
marbles referred to
the act of shooting
and the movement of
the marbles. Those
related to ways of
shooting marbles
were cribbing,
firsts, fudging,
funks, funnicks,
funnigans, flunks,
forces, knee-high,
knuckle-down-stiff,
knuckles, and lasts.
Terms connected with
the movement of the
marbles were:
cannons, clears,
dead-stick,
double-hits, fires,
funs, gees,
haystacks, in smug,
keeps, kills,
kisses, lay-ups,
manyes, ones, pink,
ringer, rolls, scat,
screws, skinned,
skun, spiders,
sported-off, stays,
stops, tracks,
throughs.

[He] marked a route
on a map, gave me a
fluoro vest and a
hard hat and sent me
up to an area where
a mechanical
harvester was
working.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
The Otakaramu run
was very bad for
tutu and care had to
be taken not to
flurry the sheep.

Author: GRADY
Quote:
Flurry, death flurry
- A whale's dying
convulsions in the
sea, after the whale
has been harpooned
or bombed.

Author: WAKEFIELD
Quote:
The N. and N.E.
winds, which draw up
the harbour [at Port
Ashley :
?Lyttelton], are
seldom either
violent or enduring;
from the appearance
of the hills, I
supposed it subject
to flurries in N.W.
and S.W. gales; ...
the former wind
draws up Port
Cooper, ... and the
latter draws down
...
Notes: 1842 Capt. Smith's report (p292) in 1848 Wakefield Handbook for NZ 328

Quote:
flush vt. fatten
(ewes) before mating
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]

Author: ANTHONY
Quote:
The flush of the
season was over,
most of the cropping
was done, and I
decided to do some
stumping.

Author: COLIN GORDON
Quote:
This is a seasonal
job and gives rise
to phrases like:
`Chaps winter at a
certain job (e.g.
shearing) in the
off-season, and come
back regularly. The
season is divided
into the flush when
lambs are coming in
(two flushes
`grass-fed' and
`rape-fed'). After
the first flush of
lambs, a lot of
sheep come in,
wo-olly iwis [wou
li: |i:wi:z] as they
are called. they are
tougher than lambs
and the tally is
therefore less - 80
instead of 100 say;
and they are often
called grannies or
grandmother lambs.

The November "flush"
has failed to
materialise at the
Te Kuiti cream
dumps.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
The case is recalled
of a flock of two
hundred ewes, caught
in the first flush
of lambing by an
overnight storm,
which lost
twenty-four lambs.

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
At the flush of
lambing, and
particularly when
the the weather is
unkind, they
[temporary houses]
are indispensable
...

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
My next job was to
attend a `ram fair'
and buy some rams
...These were put in
the best paddock to
`flush them up'
before putting them
out with the ewes,
...

Flushing: Extra
feeding before
joining to help
stimulate ovulation
in the ewe and hence
produce more lambs.

Author: DU FAUR
Quote:
Availability of
flushing feed should
also be considered
when determining
mating time. On farm
where flushing feed
can be reliably
provided, mating can
be earlier ...

Author: STEVENS
Quote:
Use of the crop in
this way enables
weaned lambs to be
finished and
provides flushing
feed for the ewe
flock.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: Flutemouth Fistularia petimba Lacepede
Notes: 1955 Whitley Namelist in 1956 Graham NZ Fishes 403

Author: AYLING
Quote: FLUTEMOUTH Fistularia commersonii (Fistularia petimba) ... The flutemouth is a distinctive, very elongate fish ... In front of the large eye the long tubular snout makes up a quarter of the total length of the fish. At the tip of this snout is a small mouth ... [?omit: specimens stragglers to NZ]

Author: PAUL et al.
Quote:
[index to common
names 283-293]
flutemouth 1102
FLUTEMOUTHS 1102-3

An old hand won't
write, and if a new
one does he gets
rubbed in for
fluting.

Summer days were
spent on
flutter-boards and
hastily constructed
wooden
"belly-boards".

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Fluttering shearwater Puffinus gavia (FORSTER, 1844) ... OTHER NAMES: Pakaha, Forster's shearwater.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Pakaha, n. Puffinis gavia, rain-bird. = hakoakoa.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: hakoakoa ... Puffinis gavia gavia, fluttering shearwater.

Author: FALLA et al.
Quote: FLUTTERING SHEARWATER Puffinus gavia Maori name: Pakaha

Source: Annotated Checklist of Birds of NZ
Quote: 63. Puffinis gavia gavia (Forster, 1844) Fluttering Shearwater (Pakaha) Breeding on many offshore islands from Three Kings to Cook Strait ...

Author: WILSON
Quote:
.. (the fluttering
shearwater puffinus
gavia is the mutton
bird of the South
Island), ...

I was ascending
slowly from a deep
dive near Mayor
Island when young
fluttering
shearwaters swam
down towards me at a
depth of 10 m.

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Hakoakoa ...1. Shearwater, Puffinis gavia, and other spp.

Fluttering
shearwaters are the
third seabird
species being
tricked by DOC and
FOMI into believing
Mana Island is home.

"The hunters are
making good use of
huts ... it is
advisable to take a
tent or a fly as a
precaution."

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
The fire, which must
have otherwise been
extinguished by the
rain, was protected
by a small fly of
palm leaves, which
the natives had
given to Clifford
for that purpose.

It was only needful
to sling our tent
and fly over the
poles ... and give
it a good sweep out
with a bush broom,
to render it fit for
occupation.

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
... sod walls with
flies of gunny-bags
sewn together.

Author: JONES
Quote:
[?b ?c] ... on the
saddle I had a fly -
that is, a calico
sheet with poles

Author: VON HAAST
Quote:
Instead of a strong
tent with a fly (a
waterproof sheet to
go horizontally over
the top of the
tent), Haast had
been sent a tent
without fly, ...
soon almost torn to
pieces by the wind.

Author: LYON
Quote:
... not far away was
a saw pit built of
logs and with a fly
- a large square of
stout calico - where
[they] ... on wet
days were cutting
the timber.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
However, although
there was a swag
skins of hanging in
a galley fly and the
hut was well stocked
with tucker, ...

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
[?a ?b] The light
oiled japara used
for parkas and
fishing coats makes
up into a light tent
which can be used
without a fly.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMPSON
Quote:
We used the canvas
canoe to bring
ashore ... a skin
fly [? a.] which we
pitched to store dry
wood for firing ...
[178] The fly tent
we used as sleeping
quarters and the
skin fly as a
cooking galley.

Author: NOLAN
Quote:
When it can be
carried, and
certainly for a base
camp, a fly, long
enough to provide a
porch, makes camping
much more
comfortable.

Author: McCASKILL
Quote:
As the tents were of
canvas, flies were
not used but in wet
weather there was
always someone
careless enough to
brush the roof and
start a leak going.

The tent has been
purchased in Spain
and doesn't have a
fly. Apparently, it
does not rain in
Spain.

Charles Lush, of Parnell, Auckland, on January 22, 1864, wrote in his diary about his activities that day, including, "... I also bought two penny worth of fly kooks for Martin." Alison Drummond, the editor of the Waikato Journals of Vicesimus Lush (Pegasus Press, 1982) in which this entry is printed, identifies "fly kooks" as "cookies, know to generations of children as 'squashed fly biscuits'"

Author: CARR
Quote:
When the flax
arrives at the mill
it is weighed and
credited to the
cutter. The `bench
loader' then takes
two or three bundles
and puts them in a
barrel (heavy end
down). He then takes
the longest leaves
and places them on a
bench convenient to
the `feeder'.
...[44] The `feeder'
takes each blade
separately and
places the butt end
into the `stripper'
which takes the
green outer covering
off. ... The fibre
as it leaves the
stripper is caught
by the `fly boy',
who collects enough
to make into a hank,
which he places
convenient for the
`shaker'. The
latter, with a
motion like cracking
a whip, gets rid of
as much rubbish as
possible, after
which he places the
hank handy for the
`washer'. This man
places the fibre in
a vat, through which
... clean water is
running.

Many fought ;long
and hard to become
mebers ikf Fly Buys
which, besides
rewarding customers
for their loyalty,
gives businesses
access to
forward-looking
customer behaviour
trends and
information... Fly
Buys set about
trying to understand
groups of people in
different life
stages, with
different needs and
characteristics -
and then targeting
each group through
mass marketing.

The upshot of all
this was the cheese
and crackers in
place of what would
have been finely cut
cucumber sandwiches,
flies' cemeteries
(fruit pies) and
perhaps even
chocolate cake.

The topic that
brought this
unexpected attention
was the origin of
the name of the
dried-fruit-filled-shortcake
known as fly
cemeteries.

Fly cemeteries were
known to the father
of Pontius Pilate in
Perthshire,
Scotland.

I was born and bred
in south-east
London... From as
far back as I can
remember, about
1935-36, "fly
cemetery" was our
invariable
expression for a
garibaldi biscuit.

I remember my mother
telling me she used
to walk to her
primary school in
Pamerston with her
best friend
Elizabeth. She would
send Elizabeth into
the cake shop and
wait with a
delicious sense of
anticipation and a
great deal of
surprise that she
could persuade such
a naturally good
child to ask for a
fly cemetery... My
mother was born in
1910, so these
events would date to
the early 1920s...

Fly cemeteries: It's
not a name used in
cookbooks. There
it's always called
fruit squares. How
boring, compared to
fly cemeteries, a
name that is
original to New
Zealand.

...I, too, can
remember hearing
about fly cemeteries
over 50 years ago. I
was living with my
family in Wellington
when my father
mentioned that he'd
had a fly cemetery
for afternoon tea...
So maybe it was
Eccles cakes in
Manchester and fruit
squares in
Wellington that were
given this
affectionate
nickname. .

Author: VIRTUE
Quote:
She had baked some
fly cemeteries.

Where did Lois
Daish.. get the idea
that "fly
cemeteries" was a
phrase original to
New Zealand? My
family was using
this term in
relation to eccles
cakes over 50 years
ago, as I grew up in
Manchester.

We watched the cakes
being iced or filled
with cream and if we
were lucky we were
allowed to choose a
cake - my favourite
was a "fly
cemetery", filled
with fruit and
enclosed in flaky
pastry.

Door, fly-proof-
Partially or wholly
fitted with a
perforated fabric
for the admission of
air and the
exclusion of flying
insects.

Come on, me lucky
lads, you pick 'em
an' I'll pay 'em.
Hop right in,
diggers, and have a
fly with the old
man.

Author: SYDER & HODGETTS
Quote: `We were just raw recruits, absolutely inexperienced. .in 4;We often said we would like the experience of a big Construction site. So anyway we gave it a fly.'..Ibid. 407 To attempt the project, not being entirely sure of success. .in 4;`I probably won't last any longer than anyone else, but the pay's good. I'll give it a fly.'

`Come on me lucky
lads, you pick 'em.
Hop in, digs, and
have a fly with the
old man. Come on,
thick and heavy, for
I'm here today and
gone tomorrow.'

Source: Account of Settlement of New Plymouth, An
Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
Sheep are never
attacked by the
`fly'

Author: MACDONALD
Quote:
BLOWFLY. -
Cleanliness by way
of proper dipping,
crutching, etc.,
assists towards
suppression of the
fly.

Author: PERRY
Quote:
Sheep that are left
uncrutched and dirty
are pre-disposed to
attacks of fly, as
are those which have
been cut about at
shearing time.

The shaft is covered
with a canvas fly.

Author: PAYTON
Quote:
We pitched our tent
in their corn
paddock, while the
Maoris slept near us
under a fly.

We used to sleep out
under the "fly" and
under the stars.

Author: WILLIAM MARTIN
Quote:
[=fly-tent] Simon
gave me two old
pieces of Callico
with which I tried
to make a fly to
sleep in going over
the Mountains

Source: Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies
Author: MEREDITH
Quote:
... I selected a
tent-fly (a
twelve-foot square
sheet of calico),
rolled it up, threw
it over my shoulder,
and proceeded to a
bare glade on the
Kohiwai flat. This
flat is heavily
covered with flax
and toi-toi bushes.

Author: BATHGATE
Quote:
... diggers' tents
by twos or threes
... most of them
being surrounded by
a wall built of sods
or turf, and
protected by a
weather-stained and
patched `fly'.

Author: DOUGLAS
Quote:
[?b] Load consists
of two Batwing Tents
and two flys [sic].
Notes: 1891 Jan 29 Douglas Letter to Roberts in 1957 Pascoe Mr Explorer Douglas 118

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER
Quote:
.. survey parties
can have their loads
packed on horseback,
and carry tent and
fly, with a second
smaller fly to pitch
at the end of the
tent to shelter the
fire ...[51] We
therefore pitch an
ordinary 6 ft. by 8
ft. canvas tent, on
a ridge pole, with
an 8 ft. by 10 ft.
fly six inches above
it ...

Author: SATCHELL
Quote:
The tent, with its
fly to protect the
roof from the direct
beams of the sun,
was soon in
evidence, ...

The languid few who
congregate in the
gloom have to
indulge in the
fascinating pastime
of "fly monte" as a
means of keeping
boredom at bay.

At the time McColl
was perfectly sober,
but he told witness
that he had a `fly
round the clock' the
night before, which
witness understood
to mean a bad night.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
We decided to pack
enough tinned stores
and, with a small
fly-tent, go up the
valley ... [179] Had
we stayed in the fly
tent we would have
had a fairly
uncomfortable night,
as we had not
collected any fern
for bedding.

Author: THATCHER
Quote:
When they know
you're fly-blown/
You're then left
alone.
Notes: also in 1967 Bailey and Roth Shanties 52

Quote:
(quoting Thatcher)
When they're cleaned
you out in the
Bazaar,/ Quite
negligent of you
they are;/ When they
know you're
fly-blown./ You're
then left alone.

Author: PRESHAW
Quote: fly blown

Author: D'AVIGDOR
Quote:
His position [after
he sc. a digger has
cut out his cheque
on drink] is then
described by the
very graphic
adjective fly-blown.

Author: FOSTON
Quote:
[The men] usually
returned to the
works fly-blown
[after boozing their
cheques].

Source: First White Boy Born in Otago
Author: BEATTIE
Quote:
It appeared that
from October to
Christmas he had
made [pounds]2000
and he was now
engaged in `blowing
it in'. He was
reeling down the
street ...and when
he saw me he called
out, `Hey, Tom, I'm
flyblown just now
but come with me in
a day or two and I
will make your
fortune for you.'
[171] ... You ask
what the term
`flyblown' meant. It
was a word used in
those days [c1860s]
and meant a man had
no money, but once I
saw a man really
flyblown.

Author: BAKER
Quote:
[As in Australia] a
person is flyblown
when he is
penniless.

flyblown adj.
penniless.

fly-blown ... NZ &
Austral. sl. broke.

In some sheds the
managers insist on
the cuts made in
shearing being
tarred, to prevent
them being fly-blown

Author: MALCOLM
Quote:
A sheep became fly
blown.

All fly-blown sheep
are culled...

WANTED a man to Feed
and attend to
stripper, none but
an experienced hand
need apply. Also
Washer, Catcher, and
Flyboy for the
Paparata Hemp Mill.

An experienced
catcher and flyboy
is wanted.

WANTED, Waitress
15s; Housemaid,
private; Scutchers,
Fly-boy; Kitchenman
15s ...

WANTED, Fly-Boy for
flaxmill.

Author: Carr
Quote:
The fibre as it
leaves the stripper
is caught by the fly
boy who collects
enough to make into
a hank, which he
places convenient
for the 'shaker'.

At the end of the
second day, I'm
bluffed on the tops
and have to set up a
fly-camp surrounded
by an arena of
windthrow-covered
ridges, cliffs and
waterfalls.

Author: WILMOT
Quote: Mantle and Dan stayed in the fly camp - the rest of us came back ... the men from the fly camp came down for tucker and stayed till 6 when they returned with swags. Ibid. 155 We shifted our camp today, and pushed on past our flycamp.
Notes: 1897 Wilmot's Journal in 1950 Reed and Reed Farthest West 138-139

Author: ORBELL
Quote:
Fly Camp or Bivvy.
This is the camp
that needs to be of
super-light
equipment to go on
your back to the
high tops.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote: But he was a solid mate, though one felt a mite uncomfortable when, even in the most far-flung fly-camp, he would produce the Bible each evening and read a verse. Ibid. 45 After dividing the skins we returned to the fly-camp.

Author: HALL-JONES
Quote:
As the rain
continued, they
collected the rest
of their provisions
and packed them out
to the various fly
camps.

Author: TOMLINSON
Quote:
Charlie spent a lot
of time looking for
Moonlight's fly camp
[126] and claim, but
so far as I know no
one found much gold
there.

Source: You'll Learn No Harm from the Hills
Author: MCCONOCHIE
Quote:
... I was to look up
the Styx River over
the Browning Pass to
assess that area for
a fly camp.

Author: WILMOT
Quote:
Mantle and Dan
stayed in the fly
camp - the rest of
us came back..the
men from the fly
camp came down for
tucker and stayed
till 6 when they
returned with swags.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
We had very few
spells in the
three-hour trip and
were about all-in by
the time we reached
the fly-camp.

Author: PORTER
Quote:
Glad they were of
the warmth instead
of freezing slowly
in a fly-camp in the
hills, and we were
glad to have their
company and their
willing help.

Author: FARMER
Quote:
The professional's
fly camp wasn't
luxurious but it was
efficient.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote:
Both of us had been
out fly-camping and
were returning to
our base.

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
Not long after that
we decided to
flycamp in an
adjoining valley.

Author: ADDENBROOKE
Quote:
During the little
fine weather we had,
we fly-camped,
seeing many Wapiti,
but few trophy
heads.

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
.. we decided to
descend to the
comfort of Kiwi Flat
Hut until the
weather was more
conducive to
fly-camping in the
tops.

Source: Along the Track: a collection of NZ hunting yarns
Author: AXBEY
Quote:
This went on for a
month or so, until
one day we returned
from fly camping to
find the owner in
residence ...

Author: FARMER
Quote:
The only time the
pack was light was
when you were off
fly-camping ...

Author: CURTIS
Quote:
That night around
the campfire the
head field officer
selected half the
intake to go
fly-camping next day
up the Dillon Creek.

Author: SUTHERLAND
Quote:
Fly-camping was
essential to be able
to cover such a wide
area of mountainous
country that we were
responsible for.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote: The other four shooters were out on the job for a few more days fly-camping, so the two of us had the first night in the never-nevers to ourselves, ... Ibid. [89] Once when out fly-camping, we [were] ... stranded several days without much in the way of food.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
... I set off early
one morning with the
intention of fly
camping and doing a
few days' hunting
along the tops.

Source: From the Top of a Hill
Author: GASCOIGNE
Quote:
He could help us -
we got all that
footrotting to get
through - he could
fly-crutch the ewes
too.

Fly-crutch the ewes
and three weeks
before they join the
rams flush them for
six weeks on the
best feed available.

MDC have also had to
stop vehicular
access to the
Waingawa River at
the closest point to
Masterton because of
fly-dumping of
rubbish.

Author: WHYTE
Quote:
a fly-flicker - a
slack, casual and
unimpressive dog.

a lazy dog: a
fly-flicker.

It was time to take
the maggot taxis up
to the marrowbone
country with the
shandygaff,
fly-flicker, powder
puff,
thistle-peeper, the
wool classer and the
gravel-scraper.

Here was a rather
sad fly-happy case.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote:
He went for a
fly-round over to
Sydney.

Source: Resolution Journal of J.R. Forster, The
Quote: In the morning ... I went ... to the Indian Cove, & shot there two new Kingfishers [[ed. fn] Now the new Zealand Kingfisher ...], some new yellow headed Flycatchers [[ed. fn] Now the Yellowhead Mohoua ochrocephala (Gmelin, 1789).], a fine large green and brown Pigeon [[ed. fn] Now the New Zealand pigeon ...] ... a small Perrokeet, green with a red forehead ... [ed. fn] Now the Red-crowned Parakeet ...

Author: SAMUEL STEPHENS
Quote:
The active little
flycatchers ... with
their pretty fan
like tails.

Author: ANGAS
Quote:
Among the smaller
varieties [of
birds], I observed
the white-headed
manakin, a black and
yellow fly-catcher,
and an extremely
diminutive wren.

Piwakawaka an
elegant little
flycatcher

Source: Account of Settlement of New Plymouth, An
Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
The Tirakara is an
elegant little
flycatcher.

Author: HURSTHOUSE
Quote:
... and the
kingfisher, the
chiming bell-bird,
black robin,
flycatcher, ... are
common round every
homestead.

RHIPIDURA FLABELLIFERA, Gml. Piwakawaka. Fan-tail. The pied Flycatcher seems to prefer proximity to water in selecting its nesting- place ... RHIPIDURA FULIGINOSA, Sparrm. Tiwaikawaka. Black Fan-tail. The Black Fan-tail Flycatcher breeds under conditions so very similar to those of the preceding species, that one description will serve for both. Ibid. 48 ... the Fly-catchers, pied and black, flit around ...
RHIPIDURA Flycatchers.

Author: HAY
Quote: The Waka-waka (Rhipidura flabellifera) is the robin of our Brighter Britain. It is a fantail, or flycatcher.

Author: BULLER
Quote:
... to say nothing
of Korimako and
Pitoitoi ..., we
never saw or heard
the notes of either
the Piopio, the
Tieke, or the Hihi,
all of which birds
were at one time
more numerous even
than the Huia. The
Zosterops was
everywhere abundant,
also the Grey
Warbler and
Rifleman, and ... we
found the Tomtit
comparatively
plentiful; the
Parakeet chased its
mate through the
tree-tops with sharp
cries of
`twenty-eight'; ...
and among the tangle
of the underwood the
ever-present
Flycatcher displayed
its pretty fan-like
tail.

Author: KELLY

All our species [of Drosera] catch and digest insects, and in fact are known in some districts by the name of `Fly-catchers'. Ibid. 325 (Petrie) Insects are so frequently caught in the glandular hairs of [Drosera spp] leaves that these herbs are known among the observant Southland settlers as `fly-catchers'. [also 1881 ibid 13/261 (Thomson)]

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: CATCHFLY (Silene [gallica]). Varieties of this species have been named S.anglica and S. quinque vulnera. [1967 quinquevulnera] Common names are spotted catchfly, flycatcher, sticky weed, and five wounds. It is common in cultivated land and waste places such as gravelly river-beds throughout both islands. ... The flowers are white or often dark red, or sometimes white with a blood red blotch on each petal so that this variety is called quinque vulnera, `five wounds'.

Source: Report on Geol. of SW Nelson

Author: POLACK
Quote: The mango or shark (Squalus); pilot-fish (Scomber ductor); flying-fish (Exocoetus volitans); hammer-headed shark (Squalus zygoena); frequent the coast, expecially the River Thames, in vast shoals, and are preserved by the natives as winter food.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Among the piscivorous tribes, are those well known in Europe under the appellations of snapper, tench, haddocks, pollock, salmon, gurnets, john dory, hakes, bream, sword-fish, elephant-fish, diodons, pipe-fish, cod, parrot-fish, flounders, skate, cat and dog-fish, sting-rays, eels. - Among the larger tribes that sport in shoals in the vicinity of the shore, are, sperm-whales, called para[as-acute] paraua[a3-acute] (physeter macrocephalus); black whale, mungu nui (black physeter); right whale, tohora (balaena mysticetus); finback, (balaena physalis); sun-fish (diodon mola); large-lipped whale (balaena mysticetus); large-lipped whale (balaena musculus); hump-back (balaena gibbosa); shark, mango (squalus); hammer-head (zygaena); pilots, (scomber); flying-fish (exocaetus volitans); and an infinity of others, besides a great variety of testaceous and crustaceous fishes that almost cover the rocks under water, such as clams, muscles, oysters, crays, cuttles, limpets, wilks, gigantic muscles, a foot in length, cockles, sea-ears, sea-eggs, star-fish, mutton-fish, &c.; from the latter the pearl is procured which they insert in the eyes of their carved images and boxes.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Gurnet ... [Gurnard cross-referenced to Gurnet] The species of Trigla found in British waters, called Gurnards are of the family of Cottidae. The word Gurnet is an obsolete or provincial form of Gurnard, revived in Australia, and applied to the fish Centropogon scorpaenoides, Guich., family Scorpaenidae. The original word Gurnard is retained in New Zealand, and applied to the new species Trigla kumu (kumu being the Maori name), family Cottidae. The Flying Gurnet is Trigla polyommata, Richards., found on all the Australian coasts from New South Wales to Western Australia, family Cottidae. It is a distinct species, not included in the British species. They have large pectoral fins, but are not known to possess the power of supporting themselves in the air like the `flying fish' which belong to other genera. Sir Fredk. McCoy says that Sebastes Percoides, Richards., is called Gurnet, or Garnet-perch, by the fishermen and dealers, as well as the more common Neosebastes scorpaenoides, Guich., and Scorpaena panda, Richards.] Ibid. 384 Red Gurnet-Perch, n. name given in Victoria to the fish Sebastes percoides, Richards., family Scorpeaenidae. It is also called Poddy; Red Gurnard, or Gurnet; and in New Zealand, Pohuikaroa. See Perch and Gurnet.]

I've dined out on

fob Samoan; street

A white boy and a

Tip-Top becomes

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
In the nineteenth
century the ring
game seems to have
been the most
popular marble game.
(In more recent
years marble games
with holes have had
the greater role.)
There was Big Ring,
in which a circle a
yard or more in
diameter was drawn
on the ground; there
was the mullibar
variation, in which
an outsize taw was
catapulted amongst
the marbles in this
circle. There were
Little Ring, Liney,
Follows, Follow the
Taw, Holey, and
then, on a less
important scale,
Butcher's Board, in
which the marbles
were bowled through
the holes in a
board, Eye-Drop,
Knock-Backs,
Leggings-Out (or
Leggin's-Out),
Span-'Em, and
Backits. The last
was more usually a
girls' game.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Action terms which
refer to the
shooting of the
marbles are: Knuckle
down Stiff, Knee
High, Funks [Flunks
sic] or Funnicks,
Slips, Firsts and
Lasts and Forces.
... The term
`Knuckle down Stiff'
(Taranaki [18]80,
Gisborne [18]85,
Waitara [18]95) is
mentioned by [Lady
A.B. Gomme Vo. 1,
p.113]. ... As
Taranaki [18]80
says, `The term was
called out in order
to prevent too easy
a success against a
marble near the
ring'. It was less
advantageous to fire
with the hand on the
ground than with the
hand elevated,
perhaps at `Knee
High'.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote: Some of the typical terms used in marbles referred to the act of shooting and the movement of the marbles. Those related to ways of shooting marbles were cribbing, firsts, fudging, funks, funnicks, funnigans, flunks, forces, knee-high, knuckle-down-stiff, knuckles, and lasts. Terms connected with the movement of the marbles were: cannons, clears, dead-stick, double-hits, fires, funs, gees, haystacks, in smug, keeps, kills, kisses, lay-ups, manyes, ones, pink, ringer, rolls, scat, screws, skinned, skun, spiders, sported-off, stays, stops, tracks, throughs. Ibid. 269 [marble term] Here are some [marble] terms from Taranaki around 1880-1890: firsts, lay-up, stakes, tips, sticking-taw, nothings, anythings, fade-it, knuckledown stiff, dubs, finking [sic, ?funking], sips, spanning, placing; and from Dunedin School in 1949: knee high, manyies, tracks, screws, nuts, sleets, kills, forces, dig, dubs, cheats.

On Forest Culture

Forest is, of
course, still in
use, but it does not
come as naturally to
the tongue as bush,
and there are no
words derived from
it in this part of
the world. It is
stiffer, more
formal, more
technical. We may
speak of kauri
forest or beech
forest, but we get
lost in the bush,
fight bush fires,
and climb above the
bushline. The kauri
forest, like the
mixed podocarp
forest, the
sub-tropical rain
forest, ... and
such-like are terms
that come from the
botanist and
forester, not from
the layman - or from
the bushman.

Forestry about a job
tomorrow.

Author: MAF
Quote:
Forestry Grazing:
forestry management
regime with the
objective of
producing a pruned
resource with
incidental grazing
encouraged. Unlike
agroforestry, the
forestry crop has
priority.
Notes: Economic Evaluation of Agroforestry in Otago

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
I would.. gaze at
the light beaming
from a hilltop
behind our house -
the light of the
watchman at the
Forestry lookout,
sixteen hundred or
more feet up on the
skyline.

Author: HENDERSON
Quote:
After a cup of tea
came the first part
of our work:
reporting to the
District Forestry
Office the weather
conditions.

Author: COCKAYNE

Myosotis antarctica Ibid. Myosotis spathulata
We found a few interesting plants [at the Snares]. ... a Ligusticum is found on the cliffs, and near it the pretty forget-me-not (Myosotis capitata) ...

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: FORGET-ME-NOT (Myosotis spp.). - [six] species of this genus have been introduced, and are found chiefly in wet places, though some occur in cultivated fields, and LM. arvensis (scorpion grass) is found in dry pastures and waste places in Wellington province.

A third [new plant]
is a white flowered
forget-me-not,
Myosotis amabilis.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And) Myosotis saxatilis

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And) Myosotis albida

Presently we may emerge from the forest upon some moor-like tableland in the heart of the ranges, where we again meet with a characteristic flora composed largely of heath-like Gaultherias, white gentians, blue ground-lilies, yellow forget-me-nots [fn Myosotis australis.], native daisies [fn Brachycome Sinclairii.], creeping veronicas, and white-flowered Pimeleas, with magnificent clumps of the larger Spaniard.

Author: COCKAYNE
Quote: (And) Myosotis australis

The forgotten
legion,the
thirty-niners, the
four-figure man ...
all sound like
mysterious titles
[an article on First
Echelon].

Finger ferns (species of Grammitis, hanging spleenwort, sickle spleenwort (Asplenium polyodon), lance fern (Anarthropteris lanceolata) and fork ferns (species of Tmesipteris) are also common on tree-fern trunks or hanging from the branches of forest trees.
The fork fern Psilotum nudum.. can be found around steam vents or along thermally heated stream banks in places such as Orakei Korako and Waimangu.

Forkhoist
operator/general
hand .. We are
currently looking
for an experienced
forkhoist operator
who is physically
fit,enjoys working
as part of a team
and have [sic] the
energy to meet
deadlines.

Items include:
Carrot topper,
pallet wrapper, BT
Ride on Forklifts x
2, Bingham Dicer,
Farm trailers x 2,
Tractor Fork Hoist,
ford 6640 .. We are
looking for
Experienced [sic]
and qualified fork
hoist operators to
join our team.

A current fork hoist
certificate is
essential.

This is a postition
of responsibility
and will involve
computer work,
forkhoist operation
and general duties.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
Yet on his own, in a
small fork sledge,
he was the easiest
of horses to handle.
I once took a keg of
beer on a fork
sledge pulled by a
draught horse.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
I was given a cheque
for GBP70. The
forkies got GBP70
too.

Author: ANDERSON
Quote:
Baggies to one
wheel, forkies to
the other and the
walloper hand out
the spikes.

Riding on the hay
sweep behind the
horses was another
favourite thrill for
me; and watching the
men operating the
forklift with a
rope, lifting huge
bundles of hay onto
the top of the
stack.

Source: Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland
Author: HAAST
Quote:
Mr. Greenlaw was in
charge of the road
party, which ... had
been sent up to form
a bridle-path over
the Pass, ...

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
`There is an
unformed cross-road
or street at the
back of the township
which leads on to
our road ... The
timber is cleared
off the centre, but
it is not formed.'

A track has to be
formed over which
logs can be jacked
or dragged.

Author: NEWBOLD
Quote:
FORM (n) 1. Criminal
record. 2.
Reputation, style.
Derived from `form'
as used in
horseracing.

[The mine] contains
a number of blocks
which vary in width,
and are generally
short. They wedge
out very quickly,
passing into mullock
or `formation'.

Source: In the Shadow of the Bush
Author: BELL
Quote:
Roads, as the term
is generally
understood, were for
a time unknown. At
first, a pathway
through the bush or
along the felled
road line, diving
... into a deep
gulley, or skirting
a slippery sideling,
and barely passable
for a horse; then a
formed clay track,
...

Author: BULLER
Quote: PUFFINUS {GAVIA. (FORSTER'S SHEARWATER.) ... Native name.- Pakahaa: `Rainbird' of the colonists. ... {237} They fly low but swiftly, and utter a note resembling the native name by which the bird is called, but somewhat prolonged, as paka-ha-a - paka-ha-a.}
FORSTER'S SHEARWATER, or PAKAKA Puffinus gavia).

Source: Reader's Digest Book of NZ Birds
Quote: Fluttering shearwater Puffinus gavia (FORSTER, 1844) ... OTHER NAMES: Pakaha, Forster's shearwater.
(And)

Author: THOMSON
Quote:
two `dens' or
`forts' were formed.

`Come on I'll beat
y'all to the fort,'
shouts a
ginger-headed boy
... And what a fort
it was! ... Hollowed
out of the sandy
bank by the creek
...

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Many pack games
involve forts - the
defence of forts and
the attacking of
forts. These forts
may be much in the
nature of `cosy
nooks'. They may
also be a home away
from home - to be
defended to the last
ditch - the symbol
of the new
independence.

fortified pa Maori
hist. hill with
trenches and
palisades
Notes: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]

Author: BLAKISTON
Quote:
After several days
spent in cruising
around, searching
for Chatham Island a
Maori look-out
spotted, dead ahead,
a rocky island known
as `the forty
fours'. [1896]

Author: McINTOSH
Quote:
Though his
assertions may be
discounted the
spirit of Saunders's
utterances may be
taken as a
reflection of the
attitude of the
popular party. In
commenting on the
fact that the power
acquired by `the
Original Resident
Land Purchasers'
Association' was
retained long after
the Company had
ceased to exist,
Saunders states `It
became a leading and
bitter opponent, a
dangerous and
mischievous class
combination,
facetiously called
`The Nelson Supper
Party' and more
viciously called
also `The Forty
Thieves'. This party
was very ably led by
Dr., afterwards Sir
David, Monro, and
retained all
political power in
their own hands
until some time
after the
introduction of
representative
government into this
country.

Author: ROLLESTON
Quote:
The notoriety of the
defendants [at the
1873 Native Lands
Alienation
Commission] gave
rise to their being
called, variously,
the twelve apostles
(actually only seven
were involved in the
ownership of twelve
shares) or the forty
thieves.

Source: Nelson Examiner and New Zealand Chronicle
Quote:
In the outset of the
Company's
colonisation scheme,
there were certain
individuals who, by
their
disinterestedness in
forwarding the
establishment of the
Company's first and
principal
settlement, obtained
the sobriquet of the
Forty Thieves ; and
it appears that some
individuals forming
a portion of the
Company's second
Colony were anxious
to rival the
above-named
gentlemen in a
similar line of
conduct. The one set
proposed, that no
individual holding
less than five
original land-orders
in the settlement,
should be eligible
to a seat in their
self- elected
Council for the
republican
settlement of
Britannia, well
knowing at the time
that none but
themselves were
qualified under such
[a regulation,
seeing that they
were the holders of
ten gratuitous
landorders from the
Company. The Nelson
resident original
landpurchasers, on
the other hand,
propose to exclude
all persons who are
not, like
themselves, resident
original purchasers,
but who still
originally emigrated
here, and have
become holders of
land by purchase
from them and the
absentee land
proprietors, and
have embarked their
labour and capital
for various
purposes, thereby
promoting the
welfare of the
settlement, from any
right to runs for
cattle and sheep
upon the waste
lands.

Author: WASWO
Quote:
The crowning
disappointment for
many settlers in New
Zealand was the
discovery that the
forty-acre farms
allotted to them
were, when cleared
and grassed,
hopelessly
inadequate to
support a family.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
As one of the
forty-acre farmers
said in the House of
Representatives
thirty years later,
he came out because
he wanted 'a bit of
land of his own'.

Author: SINCLAIR
Quote:
In the
eighteen-sixties the
Auckland Provincial
Council, for
instance, promised
each immigrant a
`free farm' of forty
acres ... As one of
the `forty acre
farmers' said in the
House of
Representatives
thirty years later,
he came out because
he wanted `a bit of
land of his own'.

Author: RIDGWAY
Quote:
Will Forty-acre men
ruin the country?

Author: MAY
Quote:
We were lately on
the sections of two
`forty-acre men.'

Author: SILK
Quote:
There they received
their two forty-acre
sections, of which
there was not one
square yard of
arable land.

Author: SILK
Quote:
She arrived here
with five little
children and was
given a forty-acre
section on the west
side of Puhoi.

Author: MILLER
Quote:
Edie had 200 acres
adjoining this block
and he and a number
of others were keen
to get this
forty-acre section.

I am no friend to
the special
settlement system,
not being able to
see much good that
has come of it, that
is to say, beyond
what would have come
of the forty-acre
system alone.

Author: KEENE
Quote:
During the 1850s
large areas of Crown
Land were made
available under the
40-acre system,
which entitled an
adult immigrant on
payment of his own
fare from Britain,
to a grant of 40
acres, plus 40 for
his wife, and 20 for
each member of his
family aged between
five and 18 years.
Under the 40-acre
system the immigrant
gave an undertaking
to remain in the
province and not
sell his land for a
period of five
years, after which
time he would be
given the freehold
title of the land.

In New Zealand the
forty-acre system
has been adopted - a
system which has
proved most
injurious to the
country ...

Source: May's Guide to Farming in NZ
Author: MAY
Quote:
The country was a
dog-hole .. the
forty-acre system a
most villainous
take-in.

Source: Brave Days: Pioneer Women of New Zealand
Author: BARRER
Quote:
"The Britain of the
South" with its
vaunted climate and
scenery attracted
them, and especially
the forty-acre
system ..
Disillusionment
awaited them.

Author: MAY
Quote:
.. the country was a
dog-hole ... the
forty-acre system a
most villainous
take-in.

Author: WOOD
Quote:
I [the Otago
Goldfields
Commissioner] cannot
describe how welcome
that `clay' [pipe]
was to me, ... with
Dub. [Dublin, an
Irish miner],
Mexican and Pat, for
my companions; the
others having
gathered round the
rough table to enjoy
the Irish game of
`Forty-fives'.

Author: PFAFF
Quote:
Consequently larger
numbers grouped
themselves outside
[the Reefton
Courthouse], where
they passed the time
in playing cards -
the favourite game
in those days
[c.late 1860s] being
`forty-fives'.

A background of the
haze engendered by
tobacco and coal [in
Buller pubs] is
cards. As staple as
beer is, more so is
the game of
`forty-fives',
impossible of
definition, where
the five of the
trump suit beats all
other cards and the
table gets a
thumping. It
accumulates all the
good-natured
interest and noise
of which pubs are
capable.

In smoky little back
parlours [in
Westport] friendly
little groups meet
to play
`forty-fives' with
uproarious oaths and
much heavy thumping
of the table. For
[100] the
uninitiated it may
be stated that in
this game the
five-fingers (the
five of the trump
suit) beats all
other cards. The
trump suit order is
five, jack, ace,
king queen - all
other suits begin
with the king.
Non-trump suits win
high in red; low in
black. Obviously the
ace of diamonds is
the lowest card in
the pack unless
diamonds are trumps,
in which case it is
the fourth best. The
word `obviously' in
the preceding
sentence is a little
optimistic - as the
ace of hearts (the
Maggy) is always the
third best trump. It
is credibly reported
(a) that the game is
of Irish origin (b)
that there are no
written rules (c)
that the game can
only be learned by
playing it, and (d)
it is as
characteristic of
Westport as
whitebait or coal.

Author: PEARSON
Quote:
[Gloss] Forty-fives:
A peculiar card game
played on the West
Coast, imported
originally from
Ireland.

Author: CRUMPTON
Quote:
The game played was
called Forty-fives,
and he could make
neither head nor
tail of the method
of play. There was
no money on the
table, but a record
of games played and
won was made on a
cribbage board by
shifting a match
about in the holes.
At the conclusion of
each game and [sic]
a score of
forty-five was
reached, the losers
shouted drinks for
the other players,
and the cards were
shuffled round
again. ... The
fourth man stood up
and excitedly
thumped the table
with the five of
hearts. `I've been
waiting for that,
twenty-five - one -
five, now lead and
keep leading.' Play
and conversation
went on in a similar
strain. Dave
endeavoured explain
the rudiments of the
game. `The sequence
of the game is
highest in red cards
and lowest in black.
The highest card in
the pack is the five
of whatever suit
turns up, then comes
the Jack, and the
ace of hearts is
always the third
highest trump in the
pack. But you'll
never learn the game
looking on, it's too
hard to follow. They
play four legs to a
game which is called
a `horse.' Jim's
playing a hundred
pounds a game,
twenty pounds a leg,
and twenty pounds at
the completion of
the game. Then they
start again.'

Author: BATTYE & EAKIN
Quote:
45's an Irish card
game, scored on a
cribbage board,
still popular on the
West Coast.

Author: McGILL
Quote:
Old Calamity was an
early one-man band
of fiddle, horn,
cymbals and
kettledrums.
Gambling was poker
of 45s, a diggers'
card game from
California involving
legs, queer suits
and Maggie, cries of
`Get Jinx!' and `Go
for the Doctor!'

Above the stage / in
the Buffs hung a
wicked pair of
horns; all the
Druids/ did was play
Forty-Fives and
Euchre.

I dimly remember as
a youngster in the
days when the
Forty-Mile Bush was
still standing, such
a drink as 'matai
beer'...

There is plenty of
good land in the
Forty-Mile Bush. The
bush settlers would
be only too glad to
avail themselves..

Author: WILSON
Quote:
We did not stay long
.. returning by what
is called, surely in
irony, the
'Forty-Mile' Bush
...
Notes: in Wilson (1894) In the Land of the Tui

Author: ANZAC
Quote:
Shebangs [in Cairo]
where they sell you
whisky that takes
the lining of your
throat down with it
... a soothing
liquid that licks
`forty-rod',
`chained lightning'
or `Cape Smoke' to
the back of
creation; the kind
of lush that gives
you a sixty-horse
dose of the jim-jams
while you wa

100 2-tooth ewes
from up-river, 40
18-month steers, off
rough country, 300
forward bush
wethers.

Indications,
however, are that as
a finisher for
forward stores,
lucerne is slower
than good rape.

The lambs are sold
as fat and forward.

Forward conditioned
cows and heifers
were in demand.

Forward-conditioned
two-tooths off the
shears have reached
63/4.

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I
Author: TAIT
Quote:
Mr Hull had
purchased 230 acres
of sandhill country
on the coast west of
Waiuku, where
forward conditioned
cattle are 'run off'
during the wettest
part of the winter.

Forward conditioned
18 month heifers,
some of which had
failed to sell in
the prime pens, made
$400-$430.
[forward-conditioned]

Source: Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I
Author: TAIT
Quote:
The farming practice
has been to forward
good drafts of fat
and forward wether
lambs and attractive
lines of two-tooth
ewes and five-year
ewes.

Author: GORDON
Quote:
One [method of doing
business] which I
knew about, but
which had virtually
ceased when I went
on the road, was the
common practise
[sic] of 'forward
selling.'

Indications,
however, are that as
a finisher for
forward stores,
lucerne is slower
than good rape.

Good forward stores
$35 - $40.

Author: STACEY
Quote:
They were a good
line of well-woolled
forward stores.

They [store cattle]
can range from big,
fat animals ready to
kill, 'forward
stores' that will be
ready in a few weeks
if feed is good, to
walking toast racks.

Author: DU FAUR
Quote:
Losses can be
markedly reduced by
ensuring that the
ewes are held at
'forward-store'
condition up till
about four to five
weeks from lambing.

Author: DU FAUR
Quote:
The aim is to
equalise the
condition of the
ewes to a little
better than
'forward-store'
level.

The forwarding yards
or pens, which are
considerably smaller
and consequently are
useful for dealing
with small mobs of
sheep, as well as
their function of
leading up to The
crush or forcing
pen(s): These are
usually one or two
long, small pens,
frequently tapering
at one end, and
holding about 50
sheep. They in turn
communicate by a
two-way gate with
the mouth of the
Drafting race: This
race is long and
narrow just wide
enough for the sheep
to pass through in
single file. Its
purpose is to divide
a mixed flock ...
into any required
number of smaller
mobs, and for this
purpose the race is
fitted at its exit
with one or more
drafting gates,
which guide the
sheep into several

Author: BOWEN
Quote:
Receiving yards.
These must have the
capacity to take
incoming mobs. They
communicate with the
forwarding yards, or
diamond pens, which
are much smaller,
and lead up to the
crush pens or
forcing pens.

Author: PYKE
Quote:
Do you think I can
go fossicking in
patience here, while
you are running down
the game?

~ v.i. to dig out
crevices with a pick
and knife; to work
over waste heaps and
abandoned claims in
the hope of finding
gold; to search
about or rummage for
profit.-foss'icker
n. [E. dial.]

v.int. to propect
for gold, especially
in abandoned claims
and diggings; whence
fossicker. fossicker
n. searcher for gold
or other minerals.

fossick To dig or
search for gold,
especially on
abandoned claims or
`tailings'; also to
hunt about or
rummage for
anything.

Author: MASTERS
Quote:
..., and that was
the last trace found
of those
prospectors, and
probable reason for
the creek where they
had camped and
fossicked, [sic]
becoming known as
Gold Creek.

fossick vb. Austral.
& N.Z. 1. (intr.) to
search for gold or
precious stones in
abandoned workings,
rivers, etc. 2. to
rummage or search
for (something): to
fossick around for.
[C19: Austral.,
prob. < E dialect
fussock to bustle
about, < E FUSS] -
fossicker n.
Notes: [1986 NZPOD 297; cf. 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 195]

Source: History of the Early Gold Discoveries  in Otago
Author: PYKE
Quote:
Peters had persuaded
a man named Jenkins
to accompany him in
his gold-hunting
expeditions, and for
some time Jenkins
`fossicked' about
the Woolshed, whilst
Peters went further
ahead.

Author: WHITWORTH
Quote:
We caught some fish,
and also fossicked
out some potatoes.
Notes: [1866 ? Diary Williamson] 1870 Whitworth Martin's Bay Settlement 23

Author: FERGUSON
Quote:
All your grub you
[sc. a horse] had to
fossick/ Upon the
dry and stringy
tussock.

... a medium-sized
footprint ... shows
where a striped rail
has been fossicking
for tit-bits.

Author: G.M.WILSON
Quote:
We ... fossick out
our heavy luggage
which we left in
charge of John to
bring on.
Notes: 1873 Feb 6 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 170

Author: WILLIAMSON
Quote:
We caught some fish,
and also fossicked
out some potatoes.
Notes: 1866 Williamson Diary in Whitworth Martins Bay Settlement (1870) 23

Author: MORRIS
Quote:
Fossick... intrans.
to dig, but with
special meanings.
Derived, like fosse,
a ditch, and fossil,
through French from
Lat. fossus, perfect
part. of fodere, to
dig. Fossicking as
pres. part., or as
verbal noun, is
commoner than the 3
other parts of the
verb. ... (1) To
pick out gold.
-->1952. W. H. Hall,
`Practical
Experiences at the
Diggings in
Victoria,' p. 16 :
-->(2) To dig for
gold on abandoned
claims or in
waste-heaps.
-->1865. F.H. Nixon,
`Peter Perfume,' p.
59: -->(3) To search
for gold generally,
even by stealing.
-->1861. T.
McCombie,
`Australian
Sketches,' p. 60:
-->(4) To search
about for anything,
to rummage. -->1870.
S. Lemaitre, `Songs
of Goldfilds,' p.
14:] -->A. v.t.
-->1a. (goldminers')
(i) to search out
and find (alluvial
gold) small amounts
of gold

see citation
FOSSICKING ppl aj

I've got a great
geologist to look/
About for gold .../
And he's been
fossicking in every
nook,/ But Nothing
found ...
Notes: 1862 Oct 22 Lyttelton Times in 1948 Von Haast Julius Von Haast 259

Quote:
Another man, in a
few hours, fossicked
with his knife 10ozs
[of gold]

Author: GRACE
Quote:
I shouldn't have
left till I'd
fossicked that
gorge.

...I am quite sure
that there is still
gold and silver up
there in 'them thar
hills!' and no doubt
modern machinery
will be fossicking
around in the not
too distant future.

Men from New
Zealand, who got a
precarious living by
fossicking about the
islands, got into
all sorts of
trouble.

Author: DAVIES
Quote:
"I'm getting tired
of fossicking about
here," said Jack
next morning.

She fossicked out
two gin bottles,
took them down to
her bowser
attendant, and had
them filled.

Author: BAUGHAN
Quote:
Close we'd cling
about him, an'
fossick in his coat
- / Lollies for the
kiddies," always
came in / Father's
coat. [Note: Fossick
: Australasian for
"hunt about"].

Author: DUNCAN
Quote:
I was [sent] to
bring the old horse
up ... We fossacked
our way through that
grim collection of
rocks, known to us
by the name of the
Devil's lumber box.

Author: HARPER
Quote:
One of [the dog's]
accomplishments was
to `fossick' a route

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Ages of sheep.
Although there are
many variations, the
following names are
usually used: A
sheep is a lamb
until weaned. After
weaning a lamb is
called a hogget
until shorn. A male
lamb is a ram lamb
until castrated,
then a wether. A
female lamb is a ewe
lamb. After
shearing, a ewe or
ram lamb is usually
called a shorn
hogget until cutting
the first two teeth.
It is then called a
two-tooth. Some use
the term two-tooth
as soon as the lamb
is shorn. Next year
the sheep is a
four-tooth, then a
six-tooth and then
an eight-tooth or
full-mouthed sheep.
It is full-mouthed
as long as the teeth
remain perfect but
then becomes
broken-mouthed and
gummy.

The sheep forwarded
to the laboratory
were one "two-tooth"
and one
"four-tooth."

The sheep were two,
four, and six-tooth
ewes.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
A ewe that goes to
the ram as a
four-tooth is
exactly three years
old when it has its
first lamb.

The evidence for the
defence is that a
four-tooth ewe
ceases to be a
four-tooth as soon
as the fifth tooth,
or the fifth and
sixth tooth, appear
through the gums...
The witnesses for
the plaintiff... are
unanimous in their
opinion that a ewe
two and a-half years
old is still a
four-tooth ewe,
although the fifth
and sixth teeth have
appeared... I have
accordingly to
settle the matter as
follows - a ewe is
correctly defined as
a four-tooth until
the fifth and sixth
tooth reach
maturity.

Fertiliser,
four-wheelers and
scanning have
revolutionised sheep
and beef farming.
Four-wheelers have
killed rural
communities. I'd
need twice the staff
if we had to use
horses.

We hope to finish in
a fourteenight then
the great muster
begins.

The two main varieties of packs are the frame pack and the frameless pack, sometimes called a flat pack. The frameless pack of course receives that name only on formal occasions, being more familiarly known by that elegant term, kidney-rotter, or less frequently as kidney-buster, kidney-crusher, kidney-sweater or kidney-rider.

At the end of the

out' and this was

of this form of
sport were simple.
Each player has to
have three
threepenny pieces
and on the first
round all put in one
threepence. An
ordinary poker hand
was then dealt and
cards were bought as
required. There was
no betting as all
hands were tabled
face up and the man
with the worst hand
was `frozen out'.
All he had to do
however, was to put
in his second
threepence and he
was in again. After
losing three
threepences,
however, he was
frozen out for good.
This went on until
only two players
remained and on the
final game the
winner took the
whole kitty!

In 1932, wages were cut, and the freezing workers struck throughout the country. The butchers didn't believe that they could be replaced, but when the works reopened it was found that the companies had installed the American chain system, with each worker responsible for only one aspect of the process. The butchers were replaced by the unemployed, who initially made a terrible mess of the carcasses. But in time they became competent process workers, as opposed to the tradesmen who had preceded them. Ibid. 86. The freezing workers sent in a short line-out to meet them: Kennedy and Scott from the New Zealand union, Evans from Auckland and Douglas and Knox from the FOL.

Author: MORRIESON

This was freezing
workers' slang for

Author: LELAND

Freezing Works. This
is the place where
New Zealand's major
exports are

on the hoof to
fastidiously
prepared sides or

overseas
consumption.

factory where

slaughtered and
their carcasses

freezing works n.
Austral. & N.Z. a
slaughterhouse at
which animal
carcasses are frozen

Author: LELAND
Quote:
...like every other
industry in the
country the freezing
works have been hit
by 'restructuring'
which means that
fewer works, and
workers, are doing
what used to be done
by many more firms
and workers.

Our factories are no
longer "freezing
works" that simply
slaughter anbimals
and freeze down the

or carcasses.

[Sir Howard
Morrison] went to a

Whakatu Freezing
Works.

[Advt]. Formerly a

The big railway

and most of its

H L & R M were
greatly interested
with the boys at the
freezing works
wharf.

I would arrive on
the bus in the dark,
with the freezing
works looming out of

Victorian prison.

The establishment of
the Auckland
Freezing Works.. is
now accomplished.

The power could not
be switched off on
account of the
freezing works
supply.

His one ...
companion was a
freezing-works chain
slaughter-man (with
appropriate gestures
he explained his job
as a
brisket-puncher) ...
Notes: 19? Sargeson `A Final Cure' in 1975 NZ Short Stories III 4

killing sheets.

.. the slaughtering

It is abundant in scattered localities in both islands, sometimes forming dense masses. It is an annual or biennial, grows up to 6 ft. in height, and has large leaves without wings.

[Hebe sp.]]] found near all the Beeches, Sow thistles, Virgins Bower, Vanelloe, French willow, [ed. fn 1 `French willow' was one of the popular English names for the willow-herb, Epilobium sp. There are many species in New Zealand, most of them native and very widespread.] Euphorbia, [ed. fn 2 Euphorbia glauca.] and Cranes bill ...

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: FLATHEAD Kathetostoma giganteum Haast ... Other names for the Flathead are Chinaman and Frenchman, but where these names originated and for what reason I do not know with certainty. One theory is that when Chinamen hawked fish about Dunedin they kept Flatheads for their own consumption, as they preferred them to all other fish.

Author: WILSON
Quote: FRENCHMAN: see Flathead Ibid. 100 [The Flathead, Kathetostoma sp. is sometimes called Frenchman or Chinaman (presumably because these fishermen sold them in the early Otago days). The Latin translation of the name means roughly `large, perpendicular mouth.' Also known as Spotted Stargazer. Ibid. 100 FRENCHMAN Another name for Flathead. Also known as Chinaman. The latter name apparently derives from the fact that Chinese fish merchants in Dunedin in the early days always kept these fish for their own consumption. Nowadays these fish are more accurately termed Spotted Stargazer.

Quote: FLOUNDER (four species) (a) Scientific name: (i) Rhombosolea plebeia (ii) Rhombosolea retiaria (iii) Rhombosolea tapirina (iv) Rhombosolea leporina. Quote:
The Maoris started

bayonets. Hence the

Butchers' by `Lord
Haw Haw.'

`Freyberg's Circus'
(as the troops often
called it) was
maintained as much
by rank-and-file
laughter, horseplay,
mischief, and the
assertive,
rumbunctious,
enterprising spirits
of autonomous man as
it was by any
subservience to
conventional
military
organisation or to
aspirations of
professionalism.

Rather than
"Freyberg's Circus"
(the troops'
self-derisive term),
I felt that here, in
this well produced
and illustrated
book, was a
thoughtful
indication of a
substantial stratum
of RSA officials and
their outlook.

Author: BULLER
Quote: PHALACROCORAX MELANOLEUCUS. (FRILLED SHAG.) Phalacrocorax melanolencus, Vieill.

There are thirteen species [of shag] in New Zealand Phalacrocorax novae-hollandiae (Black shag), P. melanoleucus (Frilled Shag), P. brevirostris (White-throated Shag), P. varius Pied shag, and P. punctatus (Spotted Shag), which I have often found in the inland bays, rivers, and lakes. The frilled shag is, owing to its cautious habits, called the `duckscarer' by the sportsmen living in the above - mentioned sound [Kenepuru].

In 1854 a further

The front Lawn is

Kiwi; it speaks
volumes about our
culture"... In New
Zealand the front
lawn has always been
an upwardly mowable
status symbol.. but
mostly.. front lawns
are there to keep
people away.

Author: EVANS
Quote:
Immediately north of

fault-involved older
quartz drifts, ...

surface ... This
layer is locally
known as the `back
lead'. On or near it
a shaft was sunk ...
but was not utilised
for driving-out. ...
Somewhere about 1880
... others drove an
inclined drift from
point to the
southward of the
back lead for a
distance of 254 feet
... Then they drove
horizontally for a
short distance and
intersected an
auriferous ... layer
of quartz wash,
about 10 feet wide,
known as the `front
lead'. [fn quotes
OED on drift as an
excavated passage]
Notes: 1914 P.G. Morgan report Geological Survey Branch 147 in 1962 Evans Waikaka Saga 4

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Para, n. lepidopus caudatus; frost-fish.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: ~ name given in Australia and New Zealand to the European Scabbard-fish, Lepidopus caudatus, White. The name is said to be derived from the circumstance that the fish is found alive on New Zealand sea-beaches on frosty nights. It is called the Scabbard-fish in Europe, because it is like the shining white metal sheath of a long sword. Lepidopus belongs to the family Trichiurida; it reaches a length of five or six feet, but is so thin that it hardly weighs as many pounds. It is considered a delicacy in New Zealand.

Author: BULLER
Quote: ` The frost-fish ... the most delicately flavoured of all New Zealand fishes, is an inhabitant of deep water, and on frosty sights, owing probably to its air-bladders becoming choked, it is cast up be the surf on the ocean-beach.' Author: SPEIGHT et al.
Quote: The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito (Sarda chiliensis) and the large-scaled Tunny (Gasterochisma melampus) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (Thyrsites atun), the King Barracouta, Jordanidia solandrii (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (Lepidopus caudatus) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained.
Notes: 1927 Archey `Native Fishes of Canterbury' in Speight et al. Natural History of Canterbury 199

Author: NATUSCH
Quote: Family TRICHIURIDAE. The frost fishes (Lepidopus ...) are unrelated to the ribbonfish ... which they superficially resemble. They have no scales. The `silver' which rubs off like aluminium paint is the substance guanin, which gives many fishes their silvery sheen. Nobody can explain Lepidopuss habit of putting itself ashore on cold spring and winter evenings.
frost fish n. long, very thin edible Australian and N.Z. fish, the European scabbard fish. Maori name Para.

Author: WILSON
Quote: FROSTFISH Lepidopus caudatus: The Maori name Para means `to spring' or `to leap' and refers to the last moments of the average specimen when it seems tp leave its own element to spring to its death. Lepidopus means `small scales' and caudatus refers to the small tail. It is sometimes called the `Suicide-fish.'

Author: AYLONG
Quote: FROSTFISH Lepidopus caudatus ... Frostfish have a scaleless body and are a uniform bright silver colour. They spend the cold winter months in deep offshore water beyond the edge of the continental shelf and apparently come to the surface on clear still nights when the moon is full; although it maybe that they are on the surface at other times but are not seen because of the dull rough conditions. ... They are occasionally found stranded on beaches.

narcissistic fruit
loop who couldn't
maintain a
relationship with
anything other than
a mirror for five
minutes and who has
sex with strangers
at the carwash.

Author: Philippa Swan
Quote:
'Becky, don't you
ever worry about the
sort of people
attracted to a life
coach?'
'Fruitloops?'

...as a reporter
who's sat through
lots of council
meetings, it's safe
to say that, on some
committees of some
councils, I've never
seen as many
fruitloops in one
room as I have since
visiting my
grandmother in the
psycho-geriatric
ward of a mental
hospital.

Many readers will
presume [she] is a
total fruit loop;
others might wonder
if she was hit by
lightning during the
storm.

I'm told that
someone who would be
seen in politically
correct circles as
perspicacity-challenged
is immediately
identifiable by his
peers if he is
described as a
fruitloop. The last
time I rubbed
shoulders with
fruitloops they were
repulsively sticky
little things, in
bright colours. When
poured on to a plate
they became a cereal
breakfast fit to
brighten the morning
of any jaded five-
year-old.

The earlier settlers
on Sunday Island
found a large
fruit-pigeon very
abundant on their
first arrival ...

I was amused to hear
in the radio
lunch-time Country
Session a reference
to `fruit-salad
breed' as a possible
cause of the
undesirable
hairiness in slipe
wool. I wonder is
this another New
Zealand-ism for the
appendix to the
Dictionary? [not
Griffiths
handwriting]

GABA member Malezone
presented a stunning
line-up of models
for their range of
swimwear and
underwear at our
November Fruits in
Suits.

Author: FERGUSON

And he in less than

such a pile of
