on the embers he did
bake/ ... And went
down with a relish
high,/ With steaming
tea and liver fry;
-/ And that by men
[sc. shepherds] so
much in need/ Was
well pronounced `a
glorious feed'.

Source: English Language in Aust. & NZ, The

Author: JOHNSON
Quote:
During the warm
months there was a
long season for
koninis from the
kotukutuku trees
(native Fuchsia)
then ... the
ramarama berries
(Myrtaceae) were
ripe.

Amongst them were
several varieties of
fine fuchsias.

Fuchsias were once
called "ladies'
eardrops". They
symbolised "elegance
and taste" in flower
language.

The scrambling
fuchsia, one of the
few native plants of
New Zealand that are
deciduous, seems to
demand a great deal
of moisture.

Some big fuschias,
by a looped bend in
the river, embower a
gurgling creek.

Author: LUSH
Quote:
After dinner we all
went into a small
wood near our house
to gather fuchsia
berries ... The lads
quickly dispensed
themselves over the
wood and climbed up
the fuchsia trees,
many of which were
exceedingly lofty.

stuff too!

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Fuchsia, Native, n. The name is applied to several native plants. ... (3) In New Zealand, to Fuchsia excorticata , Linn., N.O. Onagrariae. (Maori name, Kotukutuku, (q.v.) See also Tooky-took and Konini.

The native fuchsia [fn Fuchsia excorticata.] - an exile from South America - and the fierce bush-nettle [fn Urtica ferox.] are conspicuous amongst the undergrowth, together with the bush-lily [fn Astelia nervosa.], but we see but few species of the characteristic New Zealand daisy-trees [fn Species of Olearia.] or of the bushy Veronicas (koromiko), which are so conspicuous in other parts of these islands.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Some of the typical
terms used in
marbles referred to
the act of shooting
and the movement of
the marbles. Those
related to ways of
shooting marbles

firsts, fudging,
funks, funnicks,
funnigans, flunks,
forces, knee-high,
knuckle-down-stiff,
knuckles, and lasts.
Terms connected with
the movement of the
marbles were:
cannons, clears,
dead-stick,
double-hits, fires,
funs, gees,
haystacks, in smug,
keeps, kills,
kisses, lay-ups,
manyes, ones, pink,
ringer, rolls, scat,
screws, skinned,
skun, spiders,
sported-off, stays,
stops, tracks,
throughs.

Author: OGONOWSKA-COATES
Quote:
Ages of sheep.
Although there are
many variations, the
following names are
usually used: A
sheep is a lamb
until weaned. After
weaning a lamb is
called a hogget
until shorn. A male
lamb is a ram lamb
until castrated,
then a wether. A
female lamb is a ewe
lamb. After
shearing, a ewe or
ram lamb is usually
called a shorn
hogget until cutting
the first two teeth.
It is then called a
two-tooth. Some use
the term two-tooth
as soon as the lamb
is shorn. Next year
the sheep is a
four-tooth, then a
six-tooth and then
an eight-tooth or
full-mouthed sheep.
It is full-mouthed
as long as the teeth
remain perfect but
then becomes
broken-mouthed and
gummy.

Other miscellaneous historical (obsolete) names from the early 20th century include..Fuller's Earth, a predictable pun alluding to the prominence of Benjamin and John Fuller in the local theatre and cinema business.

and cinematic: from

the Fuller brothers,

of N.Z. theatres and
cinemas. (The Daily
Telegraph, July 23,

... `Captain Cooker'
is well known,
better known than

Author: HILGENDORF
Quote: FUMITORY (Fumaria officinalis andF. muralis) occurs in cultivated fields, although not very abundantly except in Wellington.

FUMITORY (Fumaria officinalis) ... native to Europe and Russia, is an important crop weed through the cooler temperate zones, and in New Zealand common in some districts, mainly between Christchurch and Oamaru.... SCRAMBLING FUMITORY (Fumaria muralis) ... native to Eurasia, is seldom listed as an important weed abroad, but is common in cultivated ground in New Zealand,. . .

The flower fungus, Aseroe rubra.., belongs to a strange family of fungi called stinkhorns, named for their use of unpleasant odours to attract the flies which spread their spores.

Author: HAY
Quote: One fungus (Hirneola, sp.) is gathered here to a small extent for export to China.

Piripi and Pene came
to ask me to cart
their fungus to the
beach for them. ...
[June 8] I shipped 4
bales of fungus for
Piripi ...

The fungus belongs to the same genus as the European Jews'-Ear (Hirneola Auricula-judae), a tough but gelatinous fungus formerly in reputation as an ingredient of gargles. The New Zealand fungus now under notice (Hirneola polytricha), is well described ...

The exports for 1899
were: Wool, 4,819
bales; fungus, 107
sacks;

Often when household
funds were low, a
few shillings were
obtained by selling
fungus, otherwise

Author: RICHARDS
Quote:
At one time Jacobs
leased about 2000
acres of the usually
useless [Chatham]
Tobacco Country. He
wanted it for the
fungus that grew so
abundantly on the
kopi trees which
formed the main
portion of that
forest. This he
gathered to export
to China. The very
large, soft circular
fungus could also be
induced to grow on
logs and roots split
open and placed in
an old tin shed.
There copious
watering soon
covered everything
with the huge white
growth and all
Jacobs had to do was
to pull it off the
logs and spread it
out to dry. A pile a
foot or so high
would only yield a
few handfuls of dry
chips. When ready
for packing it had
to be damped once
more to keep it from
turning into powder.
It never went mouldy
because it was a
mould to start with.
When first sent
abroad the Islanders
got 4d. a pound for
it, later only 2d.
Even at that price
they stripped the
forests and killed
the goose. Jacobs
seems to have been
the only one who
attempted to
cultivate it. The
Chinese used it for
soup (it makes a
thick, sticky,
rather tasteless
fluid when boiled),
dressing silk and
varnish.

CLATHRUS CIBARIUS, THE `BIRD-CAGE FUNGUS'. ... This fungus, known variously as `basket fungus,'`lattice fungus,', `Devil's purse,' `tutae whetu,' `tutae kehua,' belongs to the Phallaceae, a family included in the Basidiomycetes. It is found commonly throughout New Zealand during the late autumn and early spring. [Distribution.- Australia; Chile; ... New Zealand]

Author: PHILLIPPS
Quote: Little has been recorded of the bracket fungus [Polyporus] and its importance in the generation of fire. ... Dr G.B. Cone has spoken to an old Pakeha bushman who has used it in the Thames district where it was known as `punk' to the early settlers, who learned of its use from the Maoris. Punk burns very slowly and persistently. It can be put out only when smothered. ... Punk has now been recognised as the dried flesh of the Polyporus hosularus which may be found in many parts of the North Island.

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
[Waitara, Taranaki,
1899: reference,
game of Little Ring]
Many heated
arguments arose as
to who said
`everythings' or
`nothings' first. If
a player's `taw'
touched a marble and
lay alongside it,
the others would
shout `knuckle down'
just before his
turn. ... `Knuckle
down' meant that the
player had to hold
his taw close to the
marble attacked and
fire it in that very
inconvenient
position. ... When a
boy lost all his
marbles at play he
was `scat' [?related
to skint ?HWO] . ...
A `ringer' was a taw
which, when fired at
the commencement of
the game, lodged in
the track of the
ring itself; that,
and knocking a
marble out when he
`fired' were the
perfect shots. ...
To fire a shot while
holding the hand
nearer to the ring
than where the taw
had lain, was to
`funk', an
unforgiveable crime.

Author: SCANLAN
Quote:
`Reverend Mother
talks of when she
used to give you
marbles for being a
good little boy -
pee-wees and agates,
and stonies and
glassies and a big
tor. And once she
tried to play with
you, and you said
she funked because
her knuckle was
inside the ring.'

Author: SUTTON-SMITH
Quote:
Here are some
[marble] terms from
Taranaki around
1880-1890: firsts,
lay-up, stakes,
tips, sticking-taw,
nothings, anythings,
fade-it, knuckledown
stiff, dubs, finking
[sic, ?funking],
sips, spanning,
placing; and from
Dunedin School in
1949: knee high,
manyies, tracks,
screws, nuts,
sleets, kills,
forces, dig, dubs,
cheats.

Action terms which
refer to the
shooting of the
marbles are: Knuckle
down Stiff, Knee
High, Funks [Flunks
sic] or Funnicks,
Slips, Firsts and
Lasts and Forces.
... The term
`Knuckle down Stiff'
(Taranaki [18]80,
Gisborne [18]85,
Waitara [18]95) is
mentioned by [Lady
A.B. Gomme Vo. 1,
p.113]. ... As
Taranaki [18]80
says, `The term was
called out in order
to prevent too easy
a success against a
marble near the
ring'. It was less
advantageous to fire
with the hand on the
ground than with the
hand elevated,
perhaps at `Knee
High'.

ringer, rolls, scat,
screws, skinned,
skun, spiders,
sported-off, stays,
stops, tracks,
throughs.

protected since

after becoming
entangled in fishing
nets.

coast was the haunt

which was regarded

Mr P. Thompson read

This was the only
fur seal we saw
throughout the
cruise.

The bewhiskered New Zealand fur seal and Hector's sea lion were almost exterminated and have taken 150 years to come back. Ibid. 27 The Bountys are just a pile of lichened rocks, yellow tide-line bull kept their only vegetation. Discovered by Bligh in 1788 and ignored for 30 years, their New Zealand fur seals were then exploited mercilessly.

The issue revolves
around the
continuing
protection of cute,
brown-eyed fur
seals.

It is pointed out
that the monopoly
protested against
would curtail the
means of employment
of a number of
residents of
Stewart's Island,
Riverton, and the
Bluff, who for years
past have been
accustomed to join
in fur seal
expeditions.

Provided certain
rituals were
observed at kills,
and no blood was
spilt, nor carcase
flensed nor left
upon the camping
rocks, the fur-seal
took no heed of man.

On the rocks.. were
the fur-seals -
those of the
Aucklands being
famous for their
thick fur.

'Some assert,' said
Mr Eitel, the
secretary to Dr.
Mawson's expedition,
to the interviewer
last week, 'that all

been killed by man's
cupidity'

he thinks it
possible that the

Williams, at
Pakaraka, are
feeding four sheep
to the acre upon
land sown with
furze.

The major live fence
[up to the 1880s]
was gorse, or furze
as it was generally
known.

Author: Z.W.WELLS
Quote:
X cut saw, furze
hook, spade, ...

Well, I said, this
mud was wetting. -
Fuschia.

Author: TOWNSEND
Quote:
The fuschia AN is
fond of grows wild
here - also the
sweet Myrtle - the
supple-jack has a
sweet white flower
coiling round the
limbs of trees - but
it is a sad
annoyance in
clearing the Bush.

Since being released
from hospital
Fuschia has rung the
police most days to
see when something
would be done.

The fuschia and
lawyers are all
coming out in
blossom.

Have our fush and
chups accents given
us away?

Author: FRASER
Quote:
History tells us
that at least part
of Mr Coates's
analysis was
correct. Four months
later, on 18
September 1931,
however, a fusion
between the two
parties was
announced.

Author: GRANT
Quote:
After Labour
withdrew its voting
support [from the
United Party c1930],
the `fusion' of
United and Reform
... was inevitable.

Author: NEWTON
Quote:
... he had `got on a
bit of a fuss with'
the governess ...'

Several of them..
have recorded
details of their
daily lives.. rats
that necessitated
the erection of
futtahs (whatas).

Author: THORNTON
Quote:
Acland has defined
the term "futtah" as
a "station store
built on high posts
to keep rats and
mice out. Both name
and design are
borrowed from the
Maori." In the South
Island especially
this name, a
corruption from
"whata" was quite
common. ..E S
Elwell, who refers
to the structure at
Papakaio near Oamaru
as "the futtah, or
store,
weatherboarded, and
with a shingle
roof...."

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote:
Futtah: A food store
built on high posts
so as to deny entry
to rats and mice.
This system was
learned from the
Maoris and the word
is a corruption of
their whata.
Pronunciation has
also corrupted into
watty.

Author: THORNTON
Quote:
One of the very few
survivors of the
true futtah raised
high on piles is
that of Orari Gorge
station.. The futtah
is clad in
weatherboards..

futubaru cod-Maori
for rugby, Maori
being `hutuporo' for
football.

Author: R. MASON
Quote:
Future: (-1938 a
`corporation', a
`pukunui). The last
time I heard this
used was by someone
who had lived in the
Rangi-tikei,
Auckland, and
Wellington. It was
quite familiar to
me, but I could not
recollect definitely
any occasion on
which I had heard
it. Might have been
in Auckland, or
possibly from
friends in the
Rangitikei district.

It's "Fuzzrag" -
police newsletters
that not only name
offenders, but
vilify and shop them
for their previous
list of convictions.

Author: TAYLOR
Quote: FUZZWEED (Vittadinia spp.) ... The Australian plant, purples fuzzweed (V. triloba) has flowers purplish turning greyish. The native (V. australis) has flowers a dirty white.
purple fuzzweed [s] Vittadinia triloba (Gaud.) DC.
